In a recent development, IIT Kharagpur has decided to replace the usual Spring end semester examination with other considerations of evaluating student performance. This would include grades of mid-semester examination, assignments, viva, etc. A committee has been formed which will decide on these factors along with the grading scheme, supplementary examination and department change. The Institute will issue a circular based on the decision of the Senate meeting held on May 27, 2020. With this the Spring 2020 semester would stand closed. We appreciate the student leadership for their suggestions and the entire student community for their cooperation.

IIT Kharagpur Develops Mechanised Mobile Broom for Cleaning Large Public Spaces  Researchers at IIT Kharagpur led by Prof. Mihir Sarangi have developed a vehicle-based mechanized broom to clean the 2100 acre campus area. The technology which has been successfully tested across the campus during the present lockdown situation, has been proved to be highly flexible to suit Indian road conditions including those in semi-urban areas. It can be charged by both solar power and battery. Prof. Sarangi is hoping this would enable organizations and public bodies, with budget constraints, to adopt the system. Prof. Virendra K Tewari, Director, IIT Kharagpur, has planned to deploy the vehicle to be used on campus to adhere to social distancing norms for work to be delivered at public spaces.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kharagpur-develops-mechanized-mobile-broom-for-cleaning-large-spaces/

IIT Kharagpur will conduct a free online course on Robotics through the National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning (NPTEL) project. The 8-week long course is an All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) approved Faculty Development Programme (FDP). The course will be conducted by IIT Kharagpur professor Dilip Kumar Pratihar, an expert in  robotics, soft computing and manufacturing science.  Both undergraduate and postgraduate as well as professionals can take the course. The aspects of Robotics that will be covered over a period of twelve weeks are as follows: Introduction to Robots and Robotics, Robot Kinematics, Trajectory Planning, Robot Dynamics, Control Scheme, Sensors; Robot Vision, Robot Motion Planning, Intelligent Robot, and Biped Walking. Those who wish to obtain a certificate for the course will have to take an optional exam.   https://www.dqindia.com/iit-kharagpur-invites-applications-free-online-courses-robotics-nptel/

IIT Kharagpur is going to set up a Centre of Excellence on Medical Device and Diagnostics to foster innovation of affordable and indigenous medical devices and diagnostics in priority areas and promote entrepreneurship.   In January 2020, ICMR had given a call for setting up a Centre of Excellence based on which IIT Kharagpur had proposed for the set up with thrust areas encompassing artificial intelligence in healthcare, medical devices for screening and diagnostics in healthcare, medical implants, biosensors in healthcare etc.   “We thank ICMR, the apex body of Government of India spearheading biomedical research, for entrusting us with this responsibility. We look forward to working closely with ICMR and making meaningful contributions through these efforts. We had a rewarding experience in engaging with ICMR through a pilot ICMR – IIT Kharagpur MedTech internship program that drew great interest among engineering and medical students,” said Prof. V K Tewari, Director, IIT Kharagpur.   https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iitkgp-and-icmr-stepping-up-health-tech-for-india/

Dr.Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank, Hon'ble Minister, Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India acknowledges the noble work of the students of IIT Kharagpur associated with the Gopali Youth Welfare Society

From Director's Desk: Collaboration with ICMR   I am happy to share with all that our proposal to set up an ICMR - IIT Kharagpur Centre of Excellence on Medical Device and Diagnostics at IIT Kharagpur has been accepted for funding by Indian Council of Medical Research. We have also received another approval for setting up of ICMR – IIT Kharagpur Biodesign Fellowship Program and a Biodesign Centre in partnership with Midnapore Medical College & Hospital. The aim of these is to foster innovation of affordable and indigenous medical devices and diagnostics in priority areas and promote entrepreneurship.   We thank ICMR, the apex body of Government of India spearheading biomedical research, for entrusting us with this responsibility. We look forward to working closely with them and making meaningful contributions through these efforts. We had a rewarding experience in engaging with ICMR through a pilot ICMR – IIT Kharagpur MedTech internship program that drew great interest among engineering and medical students. In Phase-1 of IMPRINT projects, IIT Kharagpur worked together with ICMR to lead the Healthcare domain.   It is time to acknowledge the support that we receive from a large number of medical institutions who have been collaborating with us for long in this R & D space. We look forward to their continued support and seek more opportunity.   The coming together of ICMR and IIT Kharagpur is expected to give a big boost to already initiated R & D efforts at IIT Kharagpur that aim to lessen the burden of present pandemic. In the long run, this association will help us achieve what we have dreamt around our upcoming  Dr. B C Roy Institute of Medical Science & Research, a R & D driven super-speciality hospital and a medical college in our own campus, which is going to be the first among IITs.   We hope to blend our motto योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् in the activities of these centres and see its efforts humbly dedicated to the service of the nation.

INDIAN INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY KHARAGPUR  Administrative Notification No.  44 / 2020 Dated May 17, 2020  Ref :   1) Administrative Notification No.  29 / 2020 Dated March 25, 2020 2) Administrative Notification No.  38 / 2020 Dated April 14, 2020 3) Administrative Notification No.  42 / 2020 Dated May 03, 2020 4) Administrative Notification No.  43 / 2020 Dated May 04, 2020  In continuation of the above referred Administrative Notifications dated 25thMarch 2020, 14thApril 2020, 3rd May 2020 and 4th May 2020, the undersigned is directed to convey that keeping in view the order issued by the Union Home Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India vide No. 40-3/2020-DM-I(A) dated17th May 2020, the following are strictly implemented in the IIT Kharagpur Campus with effect from May 18, 2020 until further orders 1)      All offices of the Institute shall remain closed. However, online/distance academic and other activities shall continue as per re-revised academic calendar. 2)      Faculty members / Researchers including those working in projects / other Scholars & Fellows who are carrying out research / Non-Teaching staff (except employees attached to emergency services) of the Institute are permitted and advised to work from home / hostel as the case may be during the above period. However, in case of exigency of the works, any one may be advised to work in the office by the competent authority during the period. 3)      No Faculty members / Researchers / Students / Scholars / Fellows/ Project Staff / Non-Teaching Staff are permitted to leave or enter the campus until further orders, except for any emergency situation. Those faculty members/students/staff members/project staff who are presently outside the campus are advised to remain in the present place till the above period and work from that place. The campus resident who desires to visit Petrol Pump which is outside of the campus will be allowed only between 2.00 pm to 3.00 p.m. 4)      All emergency services will continue to remain functional. The concerned in charges/officers are requested to make a duty roster for deployment of minimum number of staff during the above period. The efforts should be made to manage the works from inside staffs especially in sensitive places. 5)      The academic campus of the Institute will be under complete lockdown. No faculty/student/staff/other members (except employees attached to the emergency services) / project staff/construction workers etc. will be permitted to enter in the Academic campus area of the Institute. In case of any emergency, prior permission is required to be taken and may be approved on case to case basis. 6)      The shops, including ration shops if any, dealing with food, groceries, fruits and vegetables, dairy and milk booths, meat and fish, animal fodder will remain opened upto 2.00 p.m. every day. However, the medicine shops will remain opened as usual every day. CELC is advised to introduce roster system regarding opening of the shops in the market t any point of time if the system of social physical distancing is not maintained/followed. 7)      The Banks, insurance offices if any, ATMs, post office, petrol pumps, LPG, medicine counter/shop inside the campus will remain open as per the advisory of Government of India.They are advised to evolve mechanism to reduce the number of customers visiting per day. 8)      The telecommunications, internet services, broadcasting and cable services, IT and IT enabled services as far as possible shall work from home. All other establishments may work from home only. 9)      All other commercial and private establishments including restaurants/eateries, barber shops, spas, salons, etc. inside the IIT Kharagpur campus shall remain closed. 10)     Movement of cycle rickshaws, auto rickshaws, taxis, cabs etc. are strictly prohibited inside the IIT Kharagpur Campus. However, movement of individuals and vehicles, only for essential activities are permitted with restrictions. Four wheeler vehicles will have maximum two passengers besides the vehicle driver, for two wheelers, pillion rider is not allowed. 11)     The movement of individuals shall remain strictly prohibited between 7.00 pm to 7.00 am, except for essential activities. 12)     No domestic servant/helper/gardener will be allowed to enter the IIT Kharagpur campus during the above period. 13)     Students/project staff are not permitted to go outside their respective Halls of Residence/VSRC as the case may be. In case of emergency, they may approach to the security at the hall/VSRC for help. 14)     Private canteen/night canteenin the hostel will remain closed during the above period. However, all mess of the halls of residences and food canteen for VSRC boarders (within VSRC campus) will remain open and mess staffs/workers and sanitary staffs/workers of the hall will continue to stay in the halls until further orders. 15)     All educational, training, research, coaching institutions/schools, recreation clubs, etc. shall remain closed. However, online/distance learning shall be permitted. 16)     Any social / political / sports / entertainment / academic / cultural / religious functions / gatherings / conferences / seminar etc shall not be permitted. All bookings made are cancelled. 17)     All places of worship shall be closed for public. No religious congregations will be permitted without any exception. 18)     IIT Kharagpur Campus residents are permitted to visit the Technology Market for day-to-day need during the above specified period only. However, they should carry IDs, use Mask and should keep safe distance as per guidelines issued in this regard. 19)     Spitting in public & work places is punishable with fine, as may be prescribed in accordance with its laws, rules or regulations by the State/UT local authority. The Campus residents are requested to avoid spitting in the public and work places. 20)     Consumption of liquor, cigarettes, gutka, tobacco etc. in public places is not allowed. 21)     Shops will ensure minimum six feet distance among customers and shall not allow more than 5 persons at the shop. 22)     Universal use of at least standard cloth face mask for everyone in-campus resident while moving around for market places, bank, hospital or any other common area to prevent the asymptomatic carriers from spreading disease will be mandatory as per guidelines of the Government of West Bengal. 23)     All members of IIT Kharagpur community are requested to follow the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for Health, Hygiene and Hospital regarding COVID-19 as notified earlier vide notification dated April 5, 2020 and also notification issued by the Government of India in this regard. 24)     In case of funerals, congregation of not more than twenty persons will be permitted. 25)     All emergency movement to and from IIT Kharagpur campus will be through Puri Gate only.  All other gates of IIT Kharagpur Campus will remain closed. 26)     All out of campus beneficiaries of BCRTH, including PRMS members are permitted to visit BCRTH on Monday & Wednesday only of every week from 4.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m.  However, in the event of emergency only on the advice of the doctor of BCRTH for emergency consultations, after obtaining security clearance, they are also permitted to visit BCRTH on any day. The security clearance will be given on the advice of the concerned doctor. Non-emergency visits, only for renewal of medicines will not be entertained/allowed except Monday and Wednesday from 4.00 p.m. to 6.00 p.m. as stated above. 27)     Persons above 65 years of age, persons with co-morbidities, pregnant women, and children below the age of 10 years, shall stay at home, except for essential and health purposes. 28)     No outside guests will be entertained in any of the guest houses in the campus during the above period. 29)     With a view to ensuring safety in offices and work places, the employees on best effort basis should ensure that Aarogya Setu App be installed by all employees having compatible mobile phones. Aarogya Setu enables identification of potential risk of infection, and thus acts as a shield for individual and the community. 30)     The notification supersedes all the prior administrative notifications as referred above of dated March 25, April 14, May 3 & May 4, 2020 in this regard.  All members of IIT Kharagpur community are requested to co-operate with security /emergency staff on duty to make our campus safe and secure from the coronavirus pandemic.          All Heads of the Department/Centre/School/Section/Unit are requested to bring it to the notice of all faculty/staff/students/project staff for wide circulation among IIT Kharagpur Campus Community.  Registrar

IIT Kharagpur has recently sent about 35 students to their home locations in Kolkata. This is one among the several student outreach initiatives taken by the Institute administration in the past two months while the campus adopted social distancing followed by the nation wide lockdown. Here is an account  of how IIT KGP is facilitating students on-campus and beyond and what are students saying about the initiatives taken by the Institute during #COVID #lockdown.   https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/kgp-cares-student-outreach/

Adopting Industry 4.0 in MSMEs – The Way Forward in Post Pandemic World.  Prof. Surjya K Pal talks about how technical institutions like IITs can support Govt. of India's economic reforms for MSME sector though adopting Industry 4.0, upskilling of industrial workforce, facilitating R&D and developing technological solutions for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises.  IIT Kharagpur took a lead in achieving the aforesaid goals by setting up the Centre of Excellence for Advanced Manufacturing Technologies supported by Dept. of Heavy Industries, Ministry of Heavy Industries and Public Enterprises, Govt. of India and an industrial consortium comprising six large scale capital goods manufacturers and a startup. The Centre has been designed to provide technological solutions, R&D facility in digital tools, new materials, additive manufacturing, automation, training of human resources engaged in production. The  interdisciplinary Centre has been conducting training programmes on Computer Numerical Control and has also developed a training module for industrial robotics and other short-term courses and training programmes.   https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/whats-next-for-msme/

The post-COVID industrial world would wake up to a new dawn towards the involvement of MSMEs in re-energizing the industrial sector. But before that the MSMEs need to be rejuvenated and technical institutions have a key role to play towards achieving this goal. Director IIT Kharagpur Prof. V K Tewari shares his inputs with The Kgp Chronicle on this topic.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/directors-talk-on-rejuvenating-msme-in-post-covid-world/

From the desk of Director IIT Kharagpur, Prof. Virendra Tewari  Dear IIT KGP Community and Well-wishers,  It pains us deeply to inform you of the loss of one of our own. Bhavanibhatla Kondal Rao, a bright young research scholar from the Dept. of Mechanical Engineering at IIT Kharagpur met with an unfortunate end. We learned about the incident at around 10.00 AM today. The medical officials were immediately called  and they rushed to the hall. After medical check up, they declared him dead. The local police were informed simultaneously and they also reached immediately and the formalities were completed. We have contacted his parents in Andhra Pradesh as well requesting them to come to campus. We have promised them every possible assistance that IIT Kharagpur can offer in this regard. The cause of death, which is suspected to be suicide, is currently under investigation. We hope speculative statements will be avoided by all concerned. Join us in conveying your sincere condolences and deepest sympathies to his family and friends and stand in solidarity.  Every Kgpian contributes in some ways to our society. The loss of a Kgpian is a loss to our society. As children are raised to step into IITs, they are not merely the pride of the parents but hope for the entire nation. Challenges will be there in life, even failure, but there are opportunities if we really want to dwell in optimism and positivity. I urge you to look beyond the hurdles which at present may seem like the most critical chapter of your life but are mere speedbreakers if you are able to envision your life in the long run. Also, connect with your friends who need your support. Witness the magic in your own life as you volunteer to help others. For any assistance, try to reach out to us, your faculty supervisors, the counselling centre and your peers. Talk to your friends and family, your seniors, your juniors, they are only a tap away from your phone in this century and at this time. #StaySafe #StayHappy

IIT Kharagpur has set up research funding for R&D work related to COVID-19.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kharagpur-to-fund-healthcare-technology-development-for-covid-19/ The researchers would be working on several technologies including design and development of rapid diagnostic kit, real-time PCR machine, body suit for COVID-19 patients, personal protective equipment for healthcare workers and portable shredder integrated with sterilizer, Hazmat Suit with forced purified and cooled air circulation for medical professionals, bootstrapping ambu-bag as automated ventilator, telemedicine for fighting viral pandemic, large scale production of recombinant proteins for vaccine and testing.  Dr.Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank, Hon'ble Minister, Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India appreciated and acknowledged the initiative by the Institute on his social media handle congratulating the Director Prof. Virendra Kumar Tewari and the team of researchers. https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kharagpur-to-fund-healthcare-technology-development-for-covid-19/ PMO India Department of Science and Technology, Government of India Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India World Health Organization (WHO)

Dr. Arindam Mondal, Assistant Professor at IIT Kharagpur’s School of Bioscience speaks with The Kgp Chronicle regarding frequently asked questions about novel coronavirus. https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/novel-coronavirus-an-insight-by-prof-arindam-mondal/ Dr. Mondal leads the Molecular Virology Laboratory in the School of Bioscience where they study human RNA virus replication and host pathogen interaction on molecular detail to develop novel strategies for therapeutic or prophylactic measures. Currently, his lab focuses upon influenza viruses as a model that causes mild to severe respiratory illness. Dr Arindam Mondal’s group in collaboration with Prof. Suman Chakraborty’s laboratory at IIT Kharagpur's Mechanical Engineering, is currently trying to develop of a paper-strip kit for rapid low-cost diagnostics of COVID-19 infection. This is a portable rapid diagnostic kit, which in combination with a smartphone app, can be deployed at community level in order to carry out extensive detections for the SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID19.

IIT Kharagpur has set up a disinfection tunnel to supplement sanitization of visitors entering the campus to provide essential services. Prof. Mihir Sarangi along with faculty and staff members from various departments have led this innovation to automate the process of disinfection by building a tunnel to spray atomised disinfectant on the visitors while they pass through the tunnel.  With proper implementation such sanitizers can disinfect articles of clothing and shoes for about 10 minutes. This technology however is  a supplement and not a substitute for hand washing or the need to wear face masks in public. Emphasizing this point, hand wash stations have been placed just outside the disinfection tunnel.  https://youtu.be/LX7H0-6XAR0

A joint research team, including a multidisciplinary team of researchers from IIT Kharagpur, use goat ear [bio-waste] to produce Collagen for cartilage regeneration therapy. https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/from-waste-to-health/  Researchers at IIT Kharagpur have found that copious amounts of Collagen can be isolated and purified in a cost-effective way from the cartilage of disposed goat ears, which is a commonly available bio-waste product. Not only that, they have also prepared a Collagen infused injectable hydrogel that could be used in cartilage regeneration therapy. Using a novel addition to the existing process, the researchers, led by Prof. Santanu Dhara of the School of Medical Science and Technology of IIT Kharagpur, have shown that the isolation process could be simple, cost-effective and fast.   The team included Priti Prasanna Maity, Debabrata Dutta, Sayan Ganguly, Kausik Kapat, Krishna Dixit, Ramapati Samanti, Prof. Narayan Chandra Das, Prof. Amit Kumar Das and Prof. Dhara from IIT Kharagpur, Prof. Amit Roy Chowdhury and Dr. Pallab Datta from IIEST.

At a time when a billion+ Indians are under home quarantine, eHealth technologies are crucial. Four starts-ups confounded by Alumni of IIT Kharagpur have developed technologies to offer assistance towards surveillance, mass-scale sanitization and automatization of dissemination of official information related to novel coronavirus. https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/alumni-innovate-covid-19-health-technologies/  Innovaccer, co-founded by Abhinav Shashank and Kanav Hasija from 2010 batch, has developed a self-assessment smartphone app to identify at-risk parents.  Intugine, co-founded by Harshit Shrivastava (2016 batch) and Ayush Agrawal (2018 batch), has developed an SMS-based location intelligence platform to ensure social distancing norms are being followed.  Airlens Minus Corona a bot co-developed by Debayan Saha (2012 batch) which the innovators claim might be able to sanitise public spaces by using charged water droplets which are ionised using the viral discharge.  Denguebot.in, a digital platform of Apollonius Voicebot developed by Souva Majumder (2013 batch) is making voice automated information available from World Health Organization (WHO), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India and MygovIndia and address people's queries regarding the social distancing, hygiene lifestyle.  This article only shares information about technological innovations by the alumni and is neither an endorsement nor can be used as a statement of validation  for the above mentioned interventions. If you are alumni, faculty or student of IIT Kharagpur and working in the following areas, please share your story on media@iitkgp.ac.in.  Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India Dr.Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank

IIT KGP Startup - InfinityBox has emerged winner of Hult Prize Regional Summit 2020 at Beirut. The team has qualified for the Hult Prize Boston Accelerator and will compete with Top 50 Startups worldwide.  Started by a group of students from IIT Kharagpur, InfinityBox aims to change the dynamics of the food delivery industry by addressing the challenge of plastic pollution. They aim to replace single-use plastics with reusable containers, providing millions of customers with the opportunity to be a part of a sustainable future. On opting-in for an Infinitybox, an average customer’s order would be delivered in a reusable and completely recyclable container which is to be returned after use.The entire operation, from collecting and cleaning the containers and returning them to the restaurants for the next delivery, is streamlined as per set SOPs. Critical to Quality parameters have been set for hygiene.  InfinityBox also conducted 3 pilots so far reducing almost 50 kg of single-use plastic. They have partnered with a top food aggregator for a tech-enabled pilot in Mumbai. The startup, on being operational, soms to reduce approximately 200,000 kg of single-use plastic in the next 2 years.

What if mobile numbers can help monitor large number of home-quarantined individuals and ensure they follow social distancing, and all that using only SMS-based user consent to initiate the tracking? Intugine co-founded by IIT Kharagpur alumni Harshit Shrivastava (2016 batch) and Ayush Agrawal (2018 batch) are trying to do their bit in the fight against #COVID19 by using their flagship product 'Mobile Number Location Tracking'.   The Kgpians claim that their location intelligence platform, which is based on cell triangulation technology, can work without installing any application, i.e. even on basic phones, which makes it easy to implement. The company announced that this solution can help monitor tens of thousands of quarantined cases in an effective, least intrusive and scalable manner, on a single dashboard with a central control tower, reducing the pressure on the ground teams to visit each location and ensure adherence.   “Our logistics platform fits seamlessly in providing a solution to the coronavirus monitoring. Upon understanding it better, we quickly tweaked our platform by conducting a pilot in a handful of districts to check the feasibility,” says Ayush Agrawal. He confirmed getting positive response as well in detecting the breaches of home quarantined cases and reaching out to appropriate authorities who can put the platform to use for large scale surveillance.  https://yourstory.com/2020/04/coronavirus-startup-intugine-technologies-helping-

#Covid19 has paced up the transition to distance learning. While institutes are racing to shift courses online, students are engaging en masse with e-books. Digital libraries and publishers have risen to the occasion, offering more and more free content and curating personalised collections so that people can continue to read and learn without disruption. In the Indian context, the relatively young National Digital Library of India (NDLI) – an initiative of Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India developed by IIT Kharagpur – has established itself the as country’s largest online learning platform. A premier gateway to over 48 million e-books and knowledge products across disciplines, it has nearly 3 million regular users today.  An op-ed by Prof. Parthapratim Das, Principal Investigator NDLI and Eric Falt, Director and UNESCO Representative to Bhutan, India, Maldives and Sri Lanka.  Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India UNESCO New Delhi Office Dr.Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank  https://theprint.in/opinion/covid-19-put-brake-to-academic-activity-but-digital-libraries-can-ensure-continuity/397092/

Students from IIT Kharagpur have finished among the toppers in the CoreNet Global Academic Challenge 5.0 organized by CoreNet Global Summit Singapore. The team from IIT Kharagpur comprised third-year undergraduate students Vikrant Gupta (Mathematics and Computing), Krishnam Kapoor (Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering), Amrit Goswami (Industrial and Systems Engineering, Financial Engineering), and Eknoor Malhotra (Civil Engineering). https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kgp-among-topper-at-asia-pacific-global-conference/  Their problem statement involved preparation of a comprehensive action plan for the recession-proof real estate portfolio of an American multinational manufacturer of home applications. The team emphasized on minimizing the negative impacts of such recession proofing in case the anticipated economic downturn does not materialize.   The Asia-Pacific global conference which was held in March 2020 had participation from 24 leading universities across 18 countries. Among the other toppers are University of Sydney and Delft University of Technology, Netherlands.   https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kgp-among-topper-at-asia-pacific-global-conference/

An innocuous looking pouch. But as you open it and place it on top of your knee that has been bothering you no end, a warmth emanates and spreads to your aching joint. This is ‘Heat Pax’, the “Air activated body warmer”, as the label says. Inside though, a marvellous chemistry is at work. The airtight wrapper of this pack contains fine iron particles combined with vermiculite (a form of clay which holds water) and carbon or charcoal. When the wrapper is torn and the contents are exposed to air, the iron, highly reactive in its ground form, reacts with the air exothermically, producing oxide a la rust, and heat. The charcoal disperses the heat. “Someone has just commercialized rusting,” guffawed Prof. Chacko Jacob while handing out packets of ‘Heat Pax’ for all to see. Speaking on ‘Nanotechnology: Hype, hope or reality’ at the recently held Science Communication Conclave (Feb 28-29) at IIT Kharagpur, Prof. Jacob was explaining to his audience the science of the small that makes such amazing chemistry possible. With the Materials Science Centre of IIT Kharagpur for close to two decades, Prof. Jacob specializes in making nano structures through the chemical vapour deposition (CVD) technique.  The Power of Small - Read Full Story https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/the-power-of-small/

Alumnus Sudipto Das, his neighbours, and batchmates from IIT Kharagpur from Bengaluru, have developed a simple model to distribute groceries to migrant labourers at the micro level ensuring social distancing, easy logistics and avoiding local commuting. They have arranged for local grocers to distribute packed grocery items (rice, lentils, potato, onion, chillies, cooking oil, biscuits, soap) to the migrants in their localities while the cost for the items is being donated by the group and well-wishers. This simple model can be replicated by anyone in their locality.   “The idea is to stay at home, respect the lockdown but still do whatever we can at a micro level to minimises the movement of people.” For details email: sudipto@sudiptodas.com.  https://www.thehindu.com/society/an-apartment-in-bengaluru-is-distributing-groceries-to-daily-wage-earners/article31237291.ece

Dr. Prith Banerjee, Chief Technology Officer of Ansys and Distinguished Alumnus Awardee of IIT Kharagpur has joined the Board of Directors of PanIIT USA as a Prominent Alumni.   Dr. Banerjee graduated in Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering from IIT Kharagpur in 1981 with the prestigious President's Gold Medal. His success in academia and industry has been exemplary. He has been the Dean of Engineering at University of Illinois and professor at Northwestern University.   Dr. Banerjee founded AccelChip and BINACHIP in the domain of electronic design automation. He served as the senior vice president of research at Hewlett Packard, Head of HP Labs, Managing Director of Global Technology R&D at Accenture, CTO at Schneider Electric.

IIT Kharagpur researchers rom Ranbir and Chitra Gupta School of Infrastructure Design and Management (RCGSIDM) and Department of Civil Engineering, IIT Kharagpur, have taken an initiative to carry out a study on travel and #socialdistancing perspectives of Indian citizens during the recent outbreak of #COVID_19. The study throws light on understanding people’s preparedness in case of a #lockdown, their travel behaviour and their perceptions during #CoronaVirus outbreak and assessing impact of travel restrictions and social distancing on different aspects of life as per people’s perceptions.   The work will eventually help formulate potential strategic interventions and policy measures for combating any future events of similar nature. It also aims to formulate and assess the likely effectiveness of different strategic interventions pertaining to travel and social distancing for minimizing the spread of COVID-19.   https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/iit-kharagpur-initiative-to-study-on-travel-during-covid-19-outbreak-behaviour-impacts-and-interventions/articleshow/74822565.cms

Mudita Kumar, Ananya Singh Parmar and Anuranjan Singh, final year undergraduate students of BArch (Hons) at the Department of Architecture and Regional Planning, won the ‘National Competition for Students 2019 for the Best Innovative Use of Steel in Architecture’ organised by INSDAG (Institute for Steel Development & Growth) recently.   Their brief was to design an international cricket stadium with a seating capacity of 45,000 with a dedicated space for a cricket academy using steel. The stadium was required to have an open parking space for 2,500 vehicles, modern facilities, proper signage and make ample use of natural lighting and artificial lightings.   The team was mentored by Prof. Sumana Gupta of the Department and went on to create a structure made up of eight arches. They studied the Wankhede and Sydney Cricket Ground as part of their work that saw a lot of team synchrony.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/every-setback-is-an-opportunity-to-learn-and-grow/

#Herd_Immunity’, a much discussed issue now the world over, and #Rnaught (#R0) – both the terms came up during a discussion on public health by Prof. Sangeeta Bhattacharya of the School of Medical Science and Technology, IIT Kharagpur at  recent Science Communication Conclave organized at IIT Kharagpur. She spoke about the threat to public health from novel #CoronaVirus-19 and drew attention to Herd Immunity’ and R0 numbers for #nCovid19.  Herd immunity is the number that describes how many people in a population need to be immune to that particular pathogen to prevent transmission. R0 is the basic reproductive number of the pathogen and describes how contagious it can be.  Read More on The Kgp Chronicle https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/organized-efforts-and-informed-choices/

IIT Kharagpur researchers have developed an energy-efficient technological process to conduct biological cell research. The technology can be used for cell patterning function used in tissue engineering, neuron network formation, protein patterning, designing of cell-based biosensor, bio-printing, drug development and many more.  This pioneering work, which is now available to scientists working in the field of cell patterning, has recently been published in Analytical Chemistry, a flagship Journal of the American Chemical Society's ACS Publications. https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.analchem.9b03364  The Microfluidics research group of IIT Kharagpur, led by Prof. Suman Chakraborty, has now made this breakthrough. He collaborated with fellow researchers Prof. Ananadaroop Bhattacharya, an expert in Thermal Engineering and Prof. Tapas Kumar Maiti, an expert in Biotechnology, along with doctoral students Golak Kunti and Tarun Agarwal.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/conserving-energy-in-cell-research/

Dr. Priyanka Dey & Dr. Shankha Pratim Bhattacharya, Assistant Professors at the Department of Architecture and Regional Planning, IIT Kharagpur, have received the Best Paper Award at the 3rd edition of Thanima - International Conference on Design, Pedagogy and Contextual Aesthetics in the category "Traditional and cultural rootedness: contextual aesthetics".  The conference was jointly organized by Department of Architecture and Planning, NIT Calicut, Indian Institute of Architects, Calicut Centre, and the Existential Knowledge Foundation, Pune.  Dr. Priyanka Dey works in the areas of Sustainable Community Planning, Community & Behavioral Studies in Planning, and Housing and Community planning. Dr. Bhattacharya's research interests include Building Physics and Energy Efficient Design, Building Construction and Management, Earthquake resistant building design and Disaster Management.

Students from IIT Kharagpur Ahana Khandelwal (B.Arch. 4th year), Divya Goyal (B.Tech., CH 4th year) and Manthan Doshi (DD, MT, 4th year) have secured 2nd Runners-up position in Meraki - FIIB's annual B-Plan Competition 2020, a PAN-Asia competition or students with exceptional venture ideas. The IIT KGP team WLOOPs proposed a waste management startup model that focused on a "zero waste-producing system that generated profit by segregating waste at the point of the source itself. Prof. V K Tewari, Director, IIT Kharagpur shares his vision on technology development for common man at the strategic conclave Tech4Bharat recently organised by PAN IIT Alumni India. The key feature of Tech4Bharat was the launch of a IIT Directors Forum attended by the Directors of majority of the 23 IITs.   Talking at the Conclave, Director Prof. V K Tewari reminded of the success of the older IITs and the contribution of the alumni which has led to 23 IITs. The Director spoke about revisiting the teaching-learning domain at IITs to evaluate the contributions and their impact – whether in agriculture and food engineering, in the area of manufacturing, cyber security, architecture and regional planning, naval architecture, mining. The focus for every academic and research units would be now on innovating hardware and software or the system which are result oriented and solution oriented for the common man.   https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/tech4bharat/

Insightful talks by IIT Kharagpur faculty experts at the Science Communication Conclave 2020 to facilitate science communication, demystifying science and technology from the laboratory to media, the real story behind the science news. Prof. Swagata Dasgupta spoke about the art of science storytelling through protein and enzyme research. Prof. Bhargab Maitra focused on creating forgiving urban infrastructure to ensure road safety. He briefed on Urban  Transportation, Road Traffic, Emissions, Road Safety Audit. Prof. Saibal Gupta's talk highlighted alternate #Mars like topography on Earth, minerals known and unknown. Prof. Sudeshna Sarkar unraveled basics of #ArtificialIntelligence & #MachineLearning, #DeepLearning along with healthcare applications. Prof. Abhijit Mukherjee covered a whole host of work in water safety, groundwater depletion and recharge.   The talks were followed by a panel discussion on the Role of Alternative Media in Taking #Science to a Wider Audience. Satarupa Sen of Citizen Matters remarked about the vantages of publishing on online media, experimental modes etc. Prof. Swagato Chatterjee of Vinod Gupta School of Management, IIT Kharagpur pointed out the critical aspect of marketing research work on mass media. Dr Satadal Saha from SMST focused on the narrative and sensationalization of the science news on social media. Sujoy Dhar of India Blooms opined on the emergence of integrated and convergence media while maintaining factual checks and ensuring editorial quality. Prof. Prof. Jenia Mukherjee shared how she has been instrumental in using social media to explain complex research right from the Lab to the end-user.  Dr Meher Wan CSIR-NISCAIR talked about formats & platforms required for generating two-way communication including informal communication, simplified programmes for common people.  Deputy Director Prof. Sriman Kumar Bhattacharyya shared his insights on representation of research & innovation on media and the importance of #Science Communication Conclave   More on the second session:  Health Tech & Biomedical Entrepreneurship - Prof. Suman Chakraborty  Nano Materials & New Materials - Prof. Chacko Jacob  Covering Public Health - Prof. Sangeeta Bhattacharya  Waste Management - Prof. Brajesh Dubey  Food Security - Prof. Dillip Kumar Swain  Vigyan Katha Sagar - Prof. Partha Pratim Chakrabarti

The Clinical Biomarkers Discovery Laboratory at IIT Kharagpur is actively involved in using the newly emerged field of metabolomics, which is capable of providing biological end-point markers of the cellular processes that occur as a result of disease. The lab focuses on the use of metabolomics for comprehensive identification of disease biomarkers and understanding of the pathogenic mechanism underlying complex human diseases.   Prof. Koel Chaudhury, who heads the lab, talks to the KGP Chronicle about how she has used the metabolomics approach to investigate women’s health, the progress her team has made and the future challenges.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/the-evolving-grammar-of-healthcare/

IIT Kharagpur’s Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness submitted its final report for the New Town Happy City project to the Housing Infrastructure Development Corporation (Hidco), giving suggestions as to how New Town could be developed as a Happy City.  The IIT team explored various issues, including subjective well-being, community infrastructure and other key issues related to New Town with the help of Hidco and NKDA officials in the last three years to come up with their report. The quality of life, subjective wellbeing, needs, aspirations, community facilities and infrastructure of New Town were assessed and evaluated in terms of other smart or smart-to-be cities in the country. On the centenary year of the discovery of ‘Macromolecules’, the International Conference on ‘Green and Sustainability in Polymers and Functional Materials: Opportunity and Challenges' organized by the Rubber Technology Centre, IIT Kharagpur contemplated the future of polymers.  Held under the #SPARC scheme and in collaboration with the University of Melbourne, scientists, faculty members and technologists talked about green polymerization techniques, sustainable functional materials and their use – from tires to drug delivery.  Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India

Researchers from the School of Medical Science & Technology at IIT Kharagpur have identified new drug repurposing candidates for induction of fetal hemoglobin to treat beta-thalassemia patients.  To find out which drugs could be used for possible repurposing the researchers led by Prof. Nishant Chakravorty at the School's Regenerative Medicine Lab studied the working of microRNAs which regulate the pathways along which the production of fetal hemoglobin is stimulated.  The researchers observed Curcumin, found in turmeric, and Ginsenoside, found in the roots of Ginseng, both known for their medicinal properties, could go a long way in treating blood disorders like thalassemia and sickle cell anemia. These two plant ingredients, together with approved drugs such as Valproate and Vorinostat were found to be ‘most suitable for future clinical trials’.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/new-repurposed-drugs-methodology-identified-by-iit-kharagpur-researchers/

A study by IIT Kharagpur's Centre for Oceans, Rivers, Atmosphere and Land Sciences (CORAL) and Department of Architecture and Regional Planning confirmed that the intensity of urban heat islands is positive in most cities (up to 2°C) in all seasons during day and night.    The study ‘Anthropogenic forcing exacerbating the urban heat islands in India‘ has been published in the international Elsevier publication Journal of Environmental Management (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvman.2019.110006).  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/whats-heating-india/

Across India many traditional and commercial art forms reflect the country's rich artistic heritage. Does this idea of heritage also stretch to the lives of the people who make it? Would this heritage have been preserved without their role in the sustenance of this art through their generational participation in its making?  Academics from IIT Kharagpur and beyond, activists, conservationist architects, and research scholars revisited these questions and raised new ones as they participated in a unique workshop titled “Urban Riverine Heritagescapes of Bengal: From Nostalgic Yearnings to Visions of a Resilient Future”, on January 28-29 organized by the Department of Humanities and Social Sciences in collaboration with the Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/outlining-a-heritagescape/

A study of 44 large Indian cities conducted by IIT Kharagpur researchers, suggests that urban areas are taking longer to shed heat, despite having greenery in surrounding rural or suburban areas. Evidence from the study suggests that more green spaces within the city’s boundary could reduce the temperature in the city and outlying areas.  One of the reasons could be the “slow and consistent” increase in the background temperature of cities. This increase is a signature of man-made actions influencing global warming and the local climate, state the scientists Prof. Jayanarayanan, Kuttippurath, lead author Sarath Raj and other scientists from the research team at IIT-Kharagpur who carried out the study.  https://india.mongabay.com/2020/01/cities-taking-longer-to-shed-heat-despite-surrounding-greenery-study/

Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur is organizing a first-of-its-kind Science Communication Conclave during February 28-29, 2020. The Conclave will bring together researchers and science journalists in a two-day workshop for exchange of ideas, knowledge and resources, paving the way for better communication of scientific information and developments to a wider, general audience.  We invite journalists, communication/PR officers, science writers, students who are either pursuing journalism studies or are interested in science writing, to participate in this Conclave to   1) interact with and learn from top journalists and communicators in the field  2) learn how to read academic publications on research in diverse fields 3) understand the areas of research notably aligned with current national priorities in policy and governance 4) network with science journalists and leading scientists  Registration Open: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc-KF0CBanE286_l4BJ0NxsxnZ2CfrvW5VwF4zzY_Mnuscb2Q/viewform  For more information visit: https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/science-communication-conclave/

Researchers at IIT Kharagpur have developed specially treated paper scaffolds for cell culture related applications.  Scientists are increasingly using various three-dimensional cell culture strategies that allow cells to grow or interact with their surroundings in a way they actually do inside the body.  The research group led by Prof. Tapas Kumar Maiti of the Department of Biotechnology, IIT Kharagpur has developed paper-based devices using LaserJet methodology (to defines cell culturable area) followed by (3-Aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES) or glutaraldehyde/PAMAM treatment of the devices. This increases the interaction of the cell or other biological macromolecules (such as proteins/DNA) with the paper matrix.   These established 3D cultures on the paper matrixes (“in vitro paper-based tissue models”) could be extended for in vitro applications such as on-paper coculture models, on-paper gene expression analysis (immunocytochemistry/in-cell ELISA), drug screening and cell invasion assays. Further, such 3D culture could also be used to address relevant biological questions pertaining to cell-matrix interaction, cell-cell interaction, matrix confinement effects and so on.  https://kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/crafted-from-paper/

"Life loses half its interest if there is no struggle-if there are no risks to be taken" ~ Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose, September 22, 1920  Challenges are opportunities for new avenues to explore, new methods to experiment, the future to carve. Struggles are as inevitable in life as a crawling caterpillar transforming itself into a butterfly, as a newborn seeing the light of this world and growing up each day. Those are the pathways of nature. In our lives, we have our goals to achieve, our visions to fulfill. Every Kgpian aspires such excellence which reflects in their holistic student life. We hope we are able to share the motivation with the youth of India to work towards greater good and wellbeing.

A team of five students from Vinod Gupta School of Management - Madhav Krishna, Nishant Kumar, Suraj Bhandare, Anusha Rao and Arkajeet Santra have secured the Runner-up position in Stock-Trak Global Portfolio Simulation Competition organized by SMU Singapore for the best-managed portfolio.  Sponsored by City-SMU Financial Literacy Program for Young Adults, the competition saw 50 teams from all over the globe participate in the portfolio optimization exercise. The teams were required to trade in the stocks listed on NYSE on Stock-Trak virtual trading platform, which is used by academic institutions, corporates and finance professionals across the globe to trade in equities, bonds, options, futures, commodities and more.  The team from VGSoM managed to deliver a return of 7.51% in just 6 weeks, missing the top position by a whisker. They outperformed all other teams in Sharpe Ratio which is the measure of risk-adjusted return of a financial portfolio. Prof. Prabina Rajib from VGSoM, IIT Kharagpur and Prof. Aurobindo Ghosh from SMU, Singapore were instrumental in guiding the students throughout the course of the competition on various topics like the construction of portfolios and advanced portfolio management skills.  The competition tested the students on their skill with managing a healthy portfolio and comprehension of the latest developments in financial markets. The students were constantly on their feet, juggling academics and trading, even at odd hours during the night in keeping with the New York time-zone. A total of five teams consisting of 25 students from VGSoM, IIT Kharagpur participated in the event as part of the Inclusive and Immersive Experiential Learning (I2XL) Project in Advanced Portfolio Management by Singapore Management University. The award is a testament to the financial acumen of students and knowledge imparted by faculties positioning VGSoM as one of the top institutes in the field of Finance.

A study by researchers at IIT Kharagpur investigated whether economic development had an effect on groundwater pollution and human health as measured by the incidence of water-borne diseases. It also sought to gauge India’s preparedness for achieving Goal 6 of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, which aims to achieve clean water and sanitation for all by 2030.  Using night-time light data as a proxy for economic activity, researchers report a decrease in the incidence of acute diarrhea after 2014, when India launched a national cleanliness mission.  https://www.natureasia.com/en/nindia/article/10.1038/nindia.2020.6

In recently concluded two workshops under the Scheme for Promotion of Academic and Research Collaboration (SPARC) of the Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India, experts from IIT Kharagpur, other Indian universities, University of Pennsylvania, Curtin University and others brought forward new technologies for green energy sources and construction processes. The focus was on the bracing of green processes and products by the global scientific community in the pursuit of a sustainable future. SPARC helps improve the research ecosystem in India by facilitating academic and research collaborations between Indian institutions and the best and selected institutions across the world’s 28 nations. Internet of Things (IoT) is presently a hot technology worldwide. IoT cuts across different application domain verticals ranging from civilian to defense sectors such as agriculture, space, healthcare, manufacturing, construction, water, and mining.   Learn online from IoT expert Prof. Sudip Misra, Professor at the Dept. of Computer Science & Engineering, IIT Kharagpur on Swayam, an initiative of Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India.  https://swayam.gov.in/nd1_noc19_cs65/preview

Learn online from Prof. Debarati Sen about Spread Spectrum Communications and Jamming on Swayam https://swayam.gov.in/nd1_noc20_ee34/preview  Spread Spectrum Communications is the core technology for secured Defence Communication Systems. It is also applied to several modern commercial communication systems e.g. CDMA in 3G, and upcoming Millimeter-Wave Communications. Hence all Defence R&D labs under the Ministry of Defence will be in need of the course.  Who can learn? Practicing engineers, Technical and Non-technical managers of telecomm companies, Students preparing for competitive exams with Signals and Systems subject  The present course introduces the basic principle of spread spectrum techniques, a key concept of code designing supported by Galois field mathematics, understanding Jamming environment and interference handling mechanisms. The theoretical principles are tempered with their practical significance to cope up with the interest to both researchers and system designers. Learning is facilitated by streamlined derivations, tutorials, and assignments. Several systems examples help students understand the concept and tutorials offer quick practice. After an in-depth exposure to spread spectrum techniques and wireless cellular environment the course takes a thorough tour of training on wireless multiuser system design with spread spectrum technique in MATLAB platform. The course ends with an expose to cdma2000 and WCDMA protocol structure and a brief introduction to a low probability of intercept methods.

Learn Transport Phenomena from Prof. Sunando Dasgupta.  This is a fundamental subject for all Chemical Engineering students and is also important in disciplines as diverse as Mechanical Engineering, Biotechnology and Nanotechnology. Over the last few decades, the subject has revolutionized the way engineering science is taught. This course deals with the unified treatment of the different transport processes, ubiquitous in the industry as well as in nature. Momentum, heat and mass transfer are taught together due to the underlying similarities of the mathematics and molecular mechanisms describing such processes. The students will be made aware of the core scientific connections and will be encouraged to solve problems based on relevant analogies.  https://swayam.gov.in/nd1_noc20_ch06/preview

Drying of Saraswati like river and Meghalayan drought caused the decline of Harappan city Dholavira:  Reveals IIT Kharagpur study.  This research team from IIT Kharagpur, Archaeological Survey of India, Deccan College PGRI Pune, Physical research laboratory, and Department of Culture, Gujarat, dated archaeological remains from all the stages and also inferred climate shifts through time which led to the rise and fall of the Harappan city. The study has just been published online in prestigious Wiley Journal of Quaternary Science.   “Our data suggest that prolific mangroves grew around the Rann and distributaries of Indus or other palaeochannels dumped water in the Rann near southern margin of Thar Desert. This is the first direct evidence of glacial fed rivers quite like the supposedly mythological Saraswati, in the vicinity of Rann” said IIT Kharagpur’s Prof. Anindya Sarkar who led the research.   The lead author of the paper and a PhD student at IIT Kharagpur Torsa Sengupta said, “the early to Mature Harappan snail isotopes suggested that the mangrove was fed by Glacier River debouching in the Rann of Kutch. However, during late Harappan period the meltwater contribution and seasonality reduced coinciding with the fall of Dholavira.”  Read Journal Paper: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/jqs.3178  https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/science/iit-kharagpur-study-reveals-decline-of-harappan-city-dholavira-was-caused-by-drying-up-of-river-and-drought/articleshow/73066330.cms

Nearly 1,100 scientists, practitioners and experts in groundwater and related fields from 92 countries have called on the governments and nongovernmental agencies to "act now" to ensure global groundwater sustainability. This is critical for supplying drinking water, ensuring food security, adapting to climate variability, supporting biodiversity, sustaining surface water bodies and meeting the UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).  Abhijit Mukherjee, Associate Professor at the Dept. of Geology and Geophysics at IIT Kharagpur, who is a part of the global scientist group said, "we, in India, are abstracting the largest volume of groundwater in human history and are rapidly depleting a relatively non-renewable natural resource that is essential for our survival."  https://m.economictimes.com/news/science/over-1000-experts-call-for-global-action-on-depleting-groundwater/articleshow/72964806.cms

By 2022, India aims to install 73 indigenous supercomputers across the country. In the first phase of the National Supercomputing Mission, parts for the supercomputers were imported and assembled in India. This phase witnessed Param Shakti supercomputer that has been installed at IIT Kharagpur. While two more have been set up at IIT BHU and IISER Pune, another three will be operational by 2020 — at IIT Kanpur, JNCASR Bengaluru, and IIT Hyderabad.   In the next phase C-DAC is designing processors for 11 more supercomputers with a cumulative capacity of 10 petaflops. These will be installed at different IITs, NITs and IISERs.   https://theprint.in/science/india-to-build-11-new-supercomputers-with-indigenous-processors-developed-by-c-dac/339196/

A recent study by researchers at Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur (IIT-KGP) has revealed that abrupt changes in the Indian monsoon in the last 900 years decided the course of human history in the subcontinent. A paper titled “Abrupt changes in Indian summer monsoon strength during the last 900 years and their linkages to socio-economic conditions in the Indian subcontinent” by Anil K. Gupta, professor at the geology and geophysics department of IIT-KGP, highlights that decline of Indian dynasties was linked to weak monsoon and reduced food production.  https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/monsoon-decided-history-of-indian-subcontinent/article30371856.ece?homepage=true

Globally one of the prominent issues today in terms of environment is the Plastic Pollution. To understand the issue of plastic waste management and to come up with the possible realistic solution to this problem Prof. Brajesh Dubey and his graduate students had designed an online MOOC course on this subject last year funded by Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India. The first offering in 2019 Spring witnessed more than 8000 students taking advantage of this course globally. Prof. Dubey and his research team are re-offering this course in Spring 2020.   Specifically, this course will focus on: 1. Introduction of Plastic pollution as a global problem today. 2. What is Plastic Waste? The Magnitude of the problem on global scale and in Indian context. Plastic in Ocean and impact on sea life and economy. 3. What is the nature and complexity of this problem and what could be the best way to manage the plastic waste and how to mitigate the risk from plastic waste. 4. Plastic Waste Management Rules, Recent Plastic Bans and the use of Extended Producer Responsibilities (EPR) concepts in managing Plastic waste in India. 5. Best Practices of Managing Plastic Waste from around the World including use of Plastic waste in road (experience from Indian context and other countries) 6. Way forward – how to manage this waste stream applying state of the art technologies  Check below for details on registration and other relevant information.

IIT Kharagpur has set up a Joint PhD Program with The University of Auckland first of its kind for a Kiwi university with an Indian university. The programme, set to admit the first batch of students in Autumn 2020, will initially focus on Engineering but is open to all other subject areas.  Some of the research areas identified for collaboration include advanced manufacturing, cyber-physical security, and advanced materials, as well as affordable healthcare and intelligent transportation technologies, confirmed Prof. S K Sriman Kumar Bhattacharyya, Director IIT Kharagpur.  University of Auckland Vice-Chancellor Professor Stuart McCutcheon called it a historic agreement that recognizes the importance of top institutions engaging internationally.  Dean International Relations Prof. Baidurya Bhattacharya called it a part of IIT Kharagpur's strategic engagement with the southern continent. " I am looking forward to welcoming the University of Auckland students and faculty into our campus at Kharagpur in the near future," he said.  http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kgps-new-joint-phd-with-auckland-university/

How was your tea yesterday - on the occasion of International Tea Day? #InternationalTeaDay Here is a trivia about IITea, the garden-fresh tea from IIT Kharagpur grown at the Heritage Tea Garden spanning over 15 acres.  To address the growing demand for tea, attempts have been made to expand the tea growing areas beyond the traditional zone of North Bengal and Noth-Eastern states. The acidic laterite soil of South Western Bengal with artificial elevation turned out to be an ideal ground for meeting the soil requirement for growing North Bengal tea.  To protect the plantation from the hot climate (44c in summer), tree spices Siris (Albizia Lebbeck) have been used as a shade tree. Other species of plants such as turmeric, ginger, black pepper, clove, etc. are planted on the periphery of the garden along with useful plants such as sandalwood, lemongrass, citronella, Guava, sapota, and amla. A sprinkler irrigation system is used to irrigate the tea garden. For the sensitive nature of tea growing, additional care is taken with regards to maintenance under adverse geo-climatic conditions. Some important operational works to maintain the Heritage Tea Garden are plucking, pruning, skiffing, manuring, drainage and irrigation, shady tree maintenance, weeding, application of bio-pesticide for preventive measures and removal of pests from the garden, processing and manufacturing of tea, maintenance of tea machinery.  The present project was initiated in March 2000, for further cultivation of tea and standardization of package of the practice of tea cultivation. Today the tea is processed & commercialized as Green Tea and CTC available at Forever Kgpian Brandstore and exported as well. https://international.iitkgp.ac.in/brandstore/Boxed_Tea/

In a significant boost to its ongoing academic exchange programs with Australian institutions, IIT Kharagpur has instituted competitive high-value scholarships for students from The University of Melbourne , Australia enrolled under the Dual Doctoral Program jointly conducted by the two institutions.  Prof. Sriman Kumar Bhattacharyya, the Director IIT Kharagpur made the announcement at the launch of the Melbourne India Partnership Program and Academy Conference at Melbourne on December 9, 2019. The scholarship (AUD 30000 per year) which will be highly competitive will be offered initially to two inbound foreign students from the prestigious Australian university starting from academic year 2020-21.

Soma Bhattacharya, Graduate Student at Vinod Gupta School of Management, IIT Kharagpur and Prof. Parama Barai, Faculty of Finance at VGSOM writes about career in Financial Analytics, FinTech and diverse role in Business Intelligence in the December issue of Careers360   The Vinod Gupta School of Management, IIT Kharagpur offers various subjects in the domain of Financial Analytics. To start with, it introduces the students with corporate finance and financial accounting, followed by deep dive into various stochastic processes in finance, financial institutions and markets, derivatives and risk management, financial econometrics, and risk modelling to name a few. These subjects help the students to grasp the domain of finance and apply analytics to it. Also, the School offers various electives in this domain like business accounting and investment analytics, banking and financial management analytics. Simultaneously, MBA students interested in Financial Analytics augment their data science and analytics expertise by learning subjects offered from Computer Science and Engineering Department, Centre of Artificial Intelligence and Centre for Computational and Data Sciences. Obviously, the positioning of a management school within an engineering umbrella provides the students of both management and engineering to exploit the synergistic learning environment, and enrich themselves in a manner that is not possible at any standalone B-School of the country.   Full article is available on the December issue of Careers360

The DHI Centre of Excellence in Advanced Manufacturing Technology at IIT Kharagpur will be conducting a training programme in Computer Numerical Control (CNC) in February 2020 for industry personnel and others. "Re-skilling to the MSME on CNC, Advanced Manufacturing topics is very much required for the growth of the MSME," said Professor in-charge of the Centre Prof. Surjya K Pal. The CNC training programme conducted in November 2019 has received high positive feedback from the participants. The centre is also planning to give training on Robotics in June.  About the Centre:  The DHI Centre of Excellence in Advanced Manufacturing Technology has been established at IIT Kharagpur through the support of the Department of Heavy Industry of Ministry of Heavy Industries and Public Enterprises, Government of India, along with a consortium of top six industry members in the country such as Tata Motor, Tata Consultancy Services, Tata Steel, Tata Sons, BHEL, and HEC. The centre aims to stimulate the innovation to manufacture smart machines in the capital goods sector.   This centre offers a unique platform for collaborative, consortium driven infusion of advanced technologies in the manufacturing area, which is in harmony with the 'Make-in-India' initiative of the Government of India. The centre will initiate innovative and top-quality research focused to the industries on Specialty materials, Design and automation, Additive manufacturing, and Digital manufacturing and Industrial Internet of Things. The centre will boost innovative interventions in the advanced manufacturing domain by enabling an ecosystem among Institutes of higher repute, heavy industries, and also the MSMEs and start-ups. The centre looks for active participation in this ecosystem for a collaborative research in the proposed areas.  The centre also houses an Innovation Lab to facilitate the culture of innovation and open engineering. The Innovation Lab invites MSMEs and the Start-ups to grab opportunities of getting an end-to-end support from the experts including access to various state-of-the-art facilities for early prototyping of their product. The centre also welcomes bright and talented scholars with high value doctoral fellowship to support its activities.  For details, please visit: http://www.coeamt.com

IIT Kharagpur is organizing the 85th Annual Conference of Indian Mathematical Society from November 22-25, 2019.  The conference is intended to keep abreast of the latest developments in the field of Mathematics. http://www.ims2019.iitkgp.ac.in/  The subject classifications include: (A) Combinatorics, Graph Theory and Discrete Mathematics. (B) Algebra, Number Theory and Lattice Theory. (C) Real and Complex Analysis (including Special Functions, Summability and Transforms). (D) Functional Analysis. (E) Differential / Integral / and Functional Equations. (F) Geometry. (G) Topology. (H) Measure Theory, Probability Theory and Stochastic Processes, and Information Theory. (I) Numerical Analysis, Approximation Theory and Computer Science. (J) Operations Research. (K) Solid Mechanics, Fluid Mechanics, Geophysics and Relativity. (L) Electromagnetic Theory, Magneto-Hydrodynamics, Astronomy and Astrophysics. (M) Bio-Mathematics. ( N ) History and Teaching of Mathematics.  More details about the IMS can be found at http://www.indianmathsociety.org.in/

A joint #SPARC workshop organized by IIT Kharagpur and the University of Melbourne earlier this month identified the key challenges to integrated urban water management. While several participants believed that a greater role for private players was the answer to India’s problems many experts spoke on the importance of data-based management and the importance of making these systems accessible to all stakeholders, which will create transparency across different domains of the water sector.   SPARC or the Scheme for Promotion of Academic and Research Collaboration is a program of the Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India to promote strong research collaboration between Indian Research groups with top research group in the leading Universities of the world, in areas that are at the cutting edge of science or with direct social relevance to the mankind, specifically India.    http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/whats-in-my-water/

Omkar Roy, 5th-year Dual Degree student from the Dept. of Chemical Engineering at IIT Kharagpur has won first prize in "Amethyst: Technical Case study Competition" by Dr. Reddy's Laboratories Ltd. Started in 2016, Amethyst is an initiative of Dr. Reddy's to bring students closer to its work culture and make them aware of the brand.

IIT Kharagpur students who are volunteering at the Gopali Youth Welfare Society have recently completed a two-day training of farmers from a nearby village, on innovative low-cost techniques to boost their income. Farmers attending the workshop at the Precision Farming Development Centre at IIT Kharagpur were acquainted with techniques of micro-irrigation and drip irrigation that require less water.  https://www.telegraphindia.com/states/west-bengal/iit-changemakers-for-village/cid/1718860

IIT Kharagpur Young Innovators Program demonstrated how school going students have been viewing energy and environmental concerns. Not only two among the top three but a majority of the projects focussed on technological ideas to offer clean energy and a healthier environment. Women's hygiene and elderly care were the two other themes receiving appreciated by the judges. Students from international schools were found to be experimenting with AI-based solutions as well.  #YIP has been providing a platform to students from classes VIII-X to showcase their ideas, learn and collaborate, and inspire the seeding of dynamic ideation and innovations in the years to come.  https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/childrens-environmental-concerns-find-voice-at-iit-kharagpurs-young-innovators-program-2019/articleshow/72032431.cms

Did you know about a lab in KGP that allowed you to tinker around and have fun building stuff in your free time? The Scholars' Avenue caught up with Professor Vikranth Racherla of the Department of Mechanical Engineering regarding the DIY lab. Find more below!  Via: The Scholars' Avenue

Children’s environmental concerns found a voice at the 3rd edition of the Young Innovators Program at IIT Kharagpur, quite similar to those being raised across the world by school-goers. The participants offered technological solutions for a green and healthy environment through clean energy, water, sanitation and cleanliness, Artificial Intelligence etc.   Director IIT Kharagpur emphasized on the execution of the ideas towards real-life problem-solving.  The winners, Pritesh Deb, Divyan Sahoo and Ankit Pradhan from KiiT International School, Bhubaneswar, ideated a green water dispenser for the use of the differently-abled which could be operated by foot or bodyweight through a simple lever mechanism. The user could use the water to take a shower, water plants or bathe a guide dog.  A charcoal-based filter made from coconut shell & corn cobs was the idea of Siddhanth Yellanki & Shreyas Bhargava from Bharatiya Vidya Bhavans Public School Hyderabad to reduce vehicle emission. They were awarded 1st Runners-up.  The 2nd Runners-up was awarded to P Pranavaditya, Raj Bhattacharjee & Shreyas Biradar from Brahm Prakash DAV School Hyderabad for ideating Astron telescope with 7 plane mirrors set in a honeycomb structure to capture high-quality images during space missions.  The third edition of the Young Innovators Program saw participation from schools across India and six countries in South East Asia and the Middle East.  The event received enthusiastic support from corporate groups like ICICI Bank which was the event sponsor and Indegene and the alumni community including the illustrious alumnus of IIT Kharagpur and US-based entrepreneur Shri Vinod Gupta.  http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/work-some-and-play-some-more/

The IIT Kharagpur campus came alive today with the arrival of 35 teams of school children from all over India, as well as south-east and west Asia for the Young Innovators Program. For many of the children and their teachers and parents, it had been a long journey from home, but the excitement of reaching their destination and being part of the milling crowd of participants and guests refreshed them in no time. The children especially got down to the business of knowing each other almost immediately. As the day wore off, it was difficult to believe that some of them were meeting each other for the first time. http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/the-show-begins/

IIT Kharagpur’s Vinod Gupta School of Management has signed an MoU with Singapore Management University for ‘SMU-IITKGP Inclusive and Immersive Experiential Learning (I2XL) Programme’. The programme is aimed at providing a managerial education and business school experience like no other – one that encourages students to apply classroom concepts in a global business environment. The scope of the MoU will include student projects and immersion programmes, reciprocal exchange of research and teaching staff, research and other collaborations.  https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/news/iit-kharagpurs-vgsom-launches-collaborative-programme-with-smu/articleshow/71919461.cms

IIT Kharagpur's Department of Ocean Engineering & Naval Architecture is organizing the 6th International Conference on Ship & Offshore Technology ICSOT- INDIA 2019 in association with The Royal Institution of Naval Architects on November 7-8, 2019. http://www.icsot2019.iitkgp.ac.in/  Themed 'Dynamics of Ocean Structures', this conference seeks to explore current trends and projected future changes regarding the dynamics of marine vessels and structures related to marine operations and the generation of renewable energy. The main aim of this conference is to disseminate research and development activities concerning marine structures focused on innovative and practical solutions for energy efficiency and economy.  Researchers from top institutions in India, United Kingdom, Norway, Portugal, Australia, Italy, in the domain of international maritime, are going to present and discuss the latest developments in the design, analysis and construction of ships and offshore structures which will contribute towards sustainable growth and development of the global marine industry.   Topics to be discussed: Structural Mechanics; Ocean Environment; Ship & Offshore Hydrodynamics; Ocean Energy Hydroelasticity; Port & Harbour Engineering; Coastal Hydrodynamics; Design & Production of Marine Structures  https://erp.iitkgp.ac.in/InfoCellDetails/resources/external/cepdata?course_id=IIT/CEP/CON/CON/2018-2019/NA/172

A study conducted by Prof. Indrajit Dube and Prof. Dipa Dube from the Rajiv Gandhi School of Intellectual Property Iit Kharagpur, recommends the introduction of mandatory Continuing Legal Education for lawyers every year to be eligible to practice in any court. The study was funded by the Ministry of Law and Justice. The proposed system could help ensure legal and judicial reforms, and contribute to strengthening ethics and behaviours reflecting the country’s societal values. https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/to-raise-bar-iit-kharagpur-mooted-annual-course-for-lawyers/articleshow/71947340.cms

Can a Dhobighaat generate electricity? Researchers from IIT Kharagpur led by Prof. Suman Chakraborty have been able to generate electricity from wet clothes using commercial super-capacitor. In the process, the researchers were able to reliably charge up to around 10 volts in almost 24 hours. This stored energy is enough to glow a white LED for more than 1 hour.  https://www.livemint.com/news/india/iit-kharagpur-researchers-use-wet-clothes-at-dhobi-ghat-to-generate-electricity-11572845626851.html

IIT Kharagpur together with NBIRT is working towards developing a Micro Solar Dome to provide clean energy to the marginalized sections and improve their socio-economic conditions. The project headed by Prof. Priyadarshi Patnaik is aimed to generate employment for small scale industries such as repair work and night-time manufacturing, help children study at night, improve social interaction and activities women in the evening. The project intends to provide 44,000 MSDs in households of rural marginalized communities in 10 states – West Bengal, Chattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Kerala, Assam, Odisha, Tripura, Manipur, Rajasthan, and Bihar.  For more information visit The Kgp Chronicle http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/lighting-up-lives/  #renewableenergy  #cleanenergy #sustainabledevelopmentgoals #solar  #sustainability #energy #climatechange #environment #iitkharagpur

Prof. Atul Jain, Assistant Professor at the  Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, IIT Kharagpur has recently been awarded 1st Prize in the DRDO Dare to Dream Innovation Contest. The novelty of his research is in increasing the applicability of composites which otherwise faces the challenge of large amount of #waste in the manufacturing industry such as commercial aircraft.  The #Composites Group led by Dr. Jain is developing easy manufacturing methods to use the in-process waste and fabricate composites with reasonable properties. They are using an integrated approach to both the manufacturing and mechanics of composites.
