Gone #Green for Four Decades - Before anyone could have thought of Green Diwali, it was adopted by students of IIT Kharagpur in early 1980s in the form of Illumination and Rangoli. It has become a long-standing tradition which enables thousands of students in the campus celebrate ecofriendly #Diwali. Illumination is a festival in its own rights at IIT Kharagpur thanks to the creativity, teamwork and skills of the student community. Watch the beautiful mytho-historical portrayals made by lighting earthen diyaas tied on bamboo canvases, all prepared by the students which can only find their parallel in the works of professional artistes.  http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/its-illumination-time/

Lightbulb Sun: How IIT-Kharagpur's Invention Can Light up Villages With Pinch of Salt, Piece of Cloth  The method, that aims to fulfill power requirements through nanoscale energy harvesting, is cheaper than solar panels and sources energy through clothes put up for drying in open spaces.  https://www.news18.com/news/india/lightbulb-sun-how-iit-kharagpurs-invention-can-light-up-villages-with-pinch-of-salt-piece-of-cloth-2362919.html

Better #sanitation made #groundwater safer, says researchers from IIT Kharagpur lead by Abhijit MukherjeeGroup which will give a fair chance to reduction in diarrhoea & child #mortality below the age of 5 years. It addresses UNGA's Sustainable Development Goal 6. #SDG. https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/better-sanitation-made-groundwater-safer-says-iit-study/story-8RsHC0RABRMUplzgO0tVYJ.html  The study, published in a Nature group of journals, Scientific Reports on Wednesday, shows that the concentration of faecal coliform in groundwater reduced by 38.5% between 2002 and 2017. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-019-50875-w  “This is probably the first time we are systematically studying the actual impact of improvement in sanitation conditions in India and its impact on the drinking water quality and #health . . .,” said Abhijit Mukherjee, the lead author of the paper and the associate professor of Hydrogeology in the Department of Geology and Geophysics at IIT Kharagpur.  “Improving sanitation and access to safe #drinkingwater will not only reduce bacterial #diarrhoea and the resulting deaths in children, but also improve various nutritional parameters,” said Dr KC Tamaria, paediatric consultant at Safdarjung hospital.  Hindustan Times  Ministry of Jal Shakti, Department of Water Resources, RD & GR  UN-Water  World Health Organization (WHO)

IIT Kharagpur congratulates Prof. Manoj Tiwari Dean, Planning & Coordination and Professor at Dept of Industrial and Systems Engineering for being appointed as the Director of National Institute of Industrial Engineering, Mumbai.  Prof. Tiwari is world renowned for his research contribution to the field of Operations and Supply Chain Management, with over 300+ publications and multiple research and industrial funded projects. He is an INAE Fellow, and rated second among researchers working in Logistics and Supply Chain Management in India (White paper published in TU Dortmund University, Dortmund Germany in 2012 on researchers working in Logistics and Supply Chain Management in India)  The Kgp Chronicle brings you an account of Prof. Tiwari's gurukul http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/to-sir-with-love/

Superspecialty services, MBBS programme, medical research, mobile health units and a lot more - the superspecialty hospital of IIT Kharagpur, Dr B C Roy Institute of Medical Science & Research will be the hub of a unique Heath Ecosystem model in Eastern India. The hospital will be run on a cross-subsidy model in a not-for-profit mode. There will be free beds as well as beds which would be charged as per the rates in the central and state health insurance schemes ~ said Prof. S K Bhattacharyya, Officiating Director IIT Kharagpur. Basic diagnostics and treatment will be done by mobile units, which will reduce the patient load in the hospital ~ said Dr Satadal Saha, project director and visiting faculty at IIT Kharagpur. http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kharagpurs-healthcare-ecosystem/

It’s that time of the year again. With only a few days remaining for Diwali, it brings me immense pleasure and joy to remember Illumination, a celebration of the rich heritage of IIT Kharagpur. With a history of more than 40 years, the culture of Illumination and Rangoli has stood the test of time and has forged strong bonds between the students who continue to celebrate it with full passion and enthusiasm.   These breathtaking structures are made possible by the students who work day and night to provide the structure the grandeur it deserves. Another indispensable part is Rangoli. These huge murals made on the floor have lately been associated with innovations like laser shows, illusions and many more.   Beyond the countless nights of hard work lies a strong guiding principle of togetherness. The joy of celebrating Diwali, the festival of lights far away from their homes together, in an eco-friendly way. Illumination is more than just an event, it’s an emotion in itself. Being carried forward by generations of students proudly over their shoulders, the true culture of KGP is here to stay and celebrated all over.  #GreenDiwali #FestivalofLights #Deepavali  Video by Click Kgp

"We plan to start the OPD services this year. By early next year, we plan to start the indoor facilities in the first phase with 400 beds. Once the hospital is operational, we plan to roll out the MBBS curriculum as per MCI guidelines," said Prof. Sriman Kumar Bhattacharyya, Officiating Director IIT Kharagpur  The plan in the second phase is to scale it up to a 750-bed superspecialty hospital.  https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/iit-kgp-to-start-mbbs-course-with-50-students-in-2021-22/articleshow/71678351.cms

IIT Kharagpur's Department of #Architecture and Regional #Planning has ventured into the relatively new area in India - #Brownfield redevelopment. Prof. Animesh Mukherjee and his fellow researchers have developed AI based algorithms to quantify bias in news articles in coverage, word choice and topic choice.  As India crosses the half a billion smartphone users' mark, it is more important than ever to characterise information available online through automatic algorithms and auto-updating knowledge bases to restrict the spread of falsehood.  The project has recently received 'Ethics in AI Research Award' from Facebook.  The team now plans to extend the reach of their study to local and digital media outlets. On the future roadmap of this project, Mukherjee said they have plans to develop browser extensions to show bias score in real time.  https://www.asianage.com/technology/in-other-news/290919/iit-kgp-faculty-wins-facebook-award-for-research-in-targeted-media-bias.html

Facebook Awards IIT KGP's AI Research  Animesh Mukherjee, Associate Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at IIT Kharagpur has been selected for the Ethics in #AI Research Award by #Facebook in the ‘operationalizing ethics’ category for his project “Targeted Bias in Indian Media Outlets” which deals with the burning issue of fake news.   The award-winning project is part of collaborative work with Prof. Pawan Goyal and Ph.D. student Souvic Chakraborty  http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/facebook-awards-iit-kgps-ai-research/  The Award is part of Facebook’s initiative to encourage research on AI #ethics and address intricate challenges and complex ethical questions in the AI domain.   #FakeNews

Vision Prabaho, under the aegis of Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness, IIT Kharagpur organised 'Green Chintan' - an environmental workshop on poster and model / prototype competition for school students (classes V-VI and IX-X). Prof. Partha P Chakrabarti was the Chief Guest for this noble initiative by the environment evangelists from the student community of IIT Kharagpur.  Prof. Saamdu Chetri from the Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness was the guest of honour. The workshop was moderated by Prof. Priyadarshi Patnaik, Head, Dept. of Humanities and Social Sciences and Rekhi Centre of Excellence for the Science of Happiness.  Expert speakers at the event included: Prof. Anuradha Choudry, Dept. of Humanities and Social Sciences Prof. Jenia Mukherjee, Dept. of Humanities and Social Sciences Prof. Manas K Mondal Distinguished Visiting Professor, IIT Kharagpur Prof. Subir Paul, School of Planning and Architecture, New Delhi

Spoofing is a critical concern for anyone today thus leading to global researchers devising various anti-spoofing techniques. What are some of these global experts saying on the popular domain of Audio-Visual which often comes under such attacks?  IIT Kharagpur brings you eminent experts in this domain to speak on 'Anti-spoofing Strategies for Unseen Audio-Visual Attacks'.   (1) Prof. Raghavendra Ramachandra. Dept. of Information Security and Communication Technology, Norwegian University of Science and Technology - Smartphone-based Biometric Authentication  (2) Prof. S R M Prasanna, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, IIT Dharwad - Challenges in Antispoofing of Speech Signals  (3) Prof. Naveen M B, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, IIT Dharwad - Signal Processing in 5G IoT  (4) Prof. K. Sreenivasa Rao, Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kharagpur - Unsupervised Audio Indexing and Retrieval  Date: October 1, 2019 Time: 10.30  AM - 4.30 PM Venue: Takshashila Building, 2nd Floor, Conference Room  The workshop organized by the Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kharagpur has been sponsored by Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India and #SPARC.

IIT Kharagpur alumnus Romil Barthwal (MTech/CS-IT/2012) has achieved the highest frontier of mountaineering – Mount Everest.   Popularly known as Delhi Rommel, this ultra-endurance sports enthusiast encourages the current generation of young Kgpians to pursue a lifestyle which will help build endurance and resilience towards real-life situations.   A list of the peak expeditions by Romil Barthwal: Mt Kedardome (6800m) Mt Golep Kangri (5900m), summiteer & team Leader Hanging Peak, Siachen (5300m), summiteer & team Leader Mt Stok Kangri (6153m), summiteer & team Leader Mt Saruchi Lungpa (5400m), summiteer & team Leader Mt Lobuje, Nepal (6100m), summiteer & team Leader Mt Kun (7077m), summiteer & team Leader Mt Everest (8848m), summiteer & team Leader Unknown Peak in Mamostang Area (5900m), summiteer & team Leader Unkown Peak in Siachen (5400m), summiteer & team Leader  http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/the-summit-it-is/

India is living beyond its available water resources . . .  Widespread occurrences of natural groundwater contaminants along with emerging pollutants, increasing food demand associated with the growing population, and effects of climate change have further compounded the problem ~ Prof. Abhijit Mukherjee, Dept. of Geology and Geophysics, IIT Kharagpur.  Groundwater storage is influenced primarily by a very delicate balance of certain factors, which needs detailed scientific evaluation and understanding. Prof. Surjya K Pal has been appointed as the Lord Kumar Bhattacharyya Chair Professor of Manufacturing in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at IIT Kharagpur for the academic year 2019-22.  The chair has been set up by alumnus Prof. Tapan Bagchi [DSC/IM/2012], Former Director, NITIE Mumbai and Former Dean, SP Jain Mumbai & Dubai, in the memory of Prof Lord Kumar Bhattacharyya (1940 - 2019), Founder Chairman, Warwick Manufacturing Group (WMG), UK, Former Professor, University of Warwick, UK.  Prof. Pal is faculty at the Mechanical engineering department, IIT Kharagpur, Professor in-Charge, DHI Centre of Excellence on Advanced Manufacturing Technology, Associate Dean of Alumni Affairs, Chairman, Steel Technology Centre and Executive Advisor, Science and Technology Entrepreneurship Park. His key research areas include Modelling and Simulation of Manufacturing Process, Friction Stir Welding, Ultrafast Cooling methodologies for metal strips in the rolling process and Industry 4.0.  Know more about Prof. Surjya K Pal: http://www.iitkgp.ac.in/department/ME/faculty/me-skpal

Short-term course on 'Advances in Remote Sensing Techniques for Water Quality Estimation' being offered by IIT Kharagpur from September 9-13, 2019 under TEQIP - KIT initiative of National Project Implementation Unit (NPIU), Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India for implementation of World Bank assisted projects in Technical Education.  This course has been devised to train the academicians and water managers on the basic concept of GIS and Remote Sensing techniques to process the optically sensitive parameters of water pollutants both in the stagnant and moving water bodies, the physics behind the integration of pollutant concentrations with the band-specific reflectance of the satellite images, etc. For more information visit the page: https://erp.iitkgp.ac.in/InfoCellDetails/resources/external/cepdata?course_id=IIT/CEP/STC/TQ/2019-2020/WM/43  IIT Kharagpur undertakes such short-term programmes on various subject areas which are of interest for industries and academia for upgradation of domain knowledge. For more information visit: http://www.iitkgp.ac.in/events

IIT Kharagpur extends its heartiest congratulations to Dr. G. C. Mitra - being conferred  the prestigious Distinguished Alumnus Award from Shri Ramesh Pokhriyal 'Nishank', Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India, at 65th Annual Convocation of the Institute. RP-Sanjiv Goenka Group Chairman, Mr Sanjiv Goenka also graced the occasion. Dr Mitra, a Padma Shri awardee and a former bureaucrat, has won widespread recognition for his technological capabilities. He retired from service as Engineer-in-Chief and Secretary to the Government of Odisha (CMO Odisha). The #cyclone shelters constructed in the state under his watch from the Prime Minister's support fund has saved the lives of millions of people in the state, also during the time of recent Cyclone #Fani.  Dr. Mitra was conferred the Padma Shri in 2003 for his outstanding work in Odisha. He is also Fellow of the Institution of Engineers (India).

The Ritesh Ranjan Memorial Scholarship was awarded to Aniruddha Saha of Mechanical engineering department, IIT Kharagpur by Director IIT Kharagpur on the occasion of 69th Foundation Day of IIT Kharagpur The scholarship was initiated by Mr Parijat Ghosh and his fellow batchmates in memory of Ritesh Ranjan (1997 / B.Tech / ME), in 2018. IIT Kharagpur celebrated its 69th Foundation Day on 18th August 2019 with a range of activities. A quiz programme was organized by IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club on this occasion. Six schools in and around Kharagpur sent in seven teams, from classes 8 to 12. Prof Anandaroop Bhattacharya kicked off the session with a motivating speech. A one hour of nerve-racking session saw the students take on a mix of easy, tricky and tough questions amid loud cheering from the crowd. Team-2 from DAV School Midnapore walked away with the first prize, followed by St. Agnes School and Hijli High School in the second and third positions, respectively. Ms Satarupa Sen Bhattacharya gave away the prizes to the winning teams. All pictures courtesy Branding And Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur Check out the photo story.

An ultra-low-cost, paper-strip and smartphone based diagnostic device has been innovated by Prof. Suman Chakraborty and his research team which can perform various pathological tests by using a tiny drop of blood taken from a finger-prick. While under laboratory conditions each test cost ₹1 or even less, the cost is expected to marginally vary in case of commercialized product.  https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/iit-kharagpur-researchers-develop-low-cost-blood-test-device-119081300132_1.html?fbclid=IwAR0CU3YdLWhp9ZApzRdj9xezxx8UpYLCSBeCz1eeWQtMMHMDWOAjxVi5Wqc  Extensive validation tests have been conducted for blood glucose and haemoglobin at laboratories as well as in the field, both in clinical environment and in remote villages with limited clinical facilities with the help of visiting faculty and medical entrepreneur Dr. Satadal Saha  The background research work has been supported by the Royal Academy of Engineering, United Kingdom, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, Govt. of India, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology, Government of India Govt. of India, Department of Science and Technology, Government of India, Indian Council of Medical Research  and Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India through the IMPRINT India initiative, in various stages.

“We cannot stop natural disasters but we can arm ourselves with knowledge: So many lives wouldn’t have to be lost if there was enough disaster preparedness”- Petra Nemcova  Being prepared to respond to a disaster improves the odds of restoring oneself to the point prior to the disaster. A deep understanding of both an upcoming and an already occurred disaster is necessary to handle the adversities. By introducing 'Disaster Management' theme in IIT Kharagpur #YIP2019, we seek to encourage ideas that can help in overcoming the disastrous effects of a calamity either by pre or post-disaster management techniques. #YIP Ministry of Human Resource Development, Government of India Visit us: http://www.yip.iitkgp.ac.in

Had a fruitful discussion on R&D / academic work in new and emerging technologies in aerospace industry at the 3rd Advisory Committee meeting of HAL Chair at IIT Kharagpur. The meeting was chaired by Prof. Sriman Kumar Bhattacharyya, Director IIT Kharagpur and co-chaired by Shri Arup Chatterjee, Director, Engineering and R&D, HAL with Prof. Bhrigu Nath Singh, HAL Chair Professor, Dept. of Department of Aerospace Engineering, IIT Kharagpur, Shri D K Sunil, AGM, Design - RADAR, SLRDC, HAL, Hyderabad, Shri Asish S Dutta, HoD (EL & AV), ARDC, HAL, Bengaluru, Prof. M K Laha, Acting Head, Dept. of Aerospace Engineering, IIT Kharagpur, Prof. Prabir Biswas, Head, Dept. of Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering and former Chair Professor. Also had detailed discussion on development of robust mechanisms for the research collaborations between IIT Kharagpur and Hindustan Aeronautics Limited in time to come.  The Chair currently focuses on research areas: Radar related technologies and processes, integrated electronic warfare technologies and techniques, spread spectrum techniques, terrain simulation techniques, L band power amplifier, airborne antenna radiation pattern analysis tools and techniques, compression/decompression algorithm and image processing techniques, airborne system simulation, design algorithms, technologies, airborne system analysis and design validation, etc.

'The Broken Amoretti', a novel by Sudipto Das, an IIT Kharagpur alumnus, is based on KGP, its surroundings and the "life" that goes around it. Delving deep into the many fascinating and unique aspects of the KGP ethos, culture and traditions, it's the story of an unprecedented pursuit of identities, overcoming societal norms and taboos, and realizing the true essence of relationships that can't be chained by stereotypes.

Can Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning be used for cancer detection? The traditional Indian snack just got a production upgrade. The puffed rice (#muri) is usually made by heating rice kernels under high pressure in the presence of steam.  IIT Kharagpur researchers at the Rural Technology Action Group (RuTAG) in collaboration with the Design innovation Centre and IIT Kharagpur Agricultural and Food Engineering Department, designed an integrated motorized muri-making machine, that produces 30-40 kg Muri / hr as against 4 kg/hr by traditional method with uniform quality. The machine is being widely used in South Tripura and Dhalai districts in Tripura. Learn more about the department and its innovations, here: http://www.iitkgp.ac.in/department/AG…

The traditional paddy milling practices including hand pounding/foot pounding (Dhenki) are still in vogue in interior villages. The traditional dhenki involved two persons for dehusking and yielded 4 - 5kg / hour milled rice. At IIT Kharagpur, the Rural Technology Action Group (RuTAG) in collaboration with the Design Innovation Centre and the Agricultural and Food Engineering Department, IIT Kharagpur have come up with one low-cost domestic level mechanized #dhenki with a capacity to yield 14 - 15 kg/hour milled rice. These are being widely used in the north-eastern states of India, with the most productivity in Twipura village (Block: Kika, Dist: Gomoti), Government of Tripura Get more information about the department here: http://www.iitkgp.ac.in/department/AG

The Rural Drinking Water Technology Hackathon at IIT KGP showcased cost-effective and simple methods of water purification  http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/simple-and-viable/?fbclid=IwAR1xYzkjpfyIZ88V2yJ_LaLUNWyGKVdlLURVmnlvoXscYrPXWBHUCEqAe7g

Three postgraduate students and research scholars from the School of Water Resources, Jadavpur University (Debdas Chowdhury, Saurabh Kumar Basak and Priyabrata Mandal) emerged winners of the two-day Rural Drinking Water Technology Hackathon (May 13-14, 2019) organized by the Rural Development Centre (funded by the Design Innovation Centre) of IIT Kharagpur, in association with The University of Edinburgh. The young researchers advocated the use of rusted nails for the #adsorption of arsenic at the minimal cost of Rs 2,000 per household. They also showed the use of the dual media filter for removing #arsenic and #fluoride from water.

Ms Usha Kumari, from the Department of Chemical Engineering, IIT Kharagpur sealed the second spot with her innovative approach to water purification. She devised a way to remove #arsenic and #flouride from the water with #alumina activated by #sulphuric acid. She adds yet another feather to the cap of this prestigious institution.  The aim of the 2-day Rural Drinking #Water Technology #Hackathon (May 13-14, 2019) was to explore cost-effective and innovative solutions to address the challenges related to drinking water problems in rural India.

The two-day (13-14 May, 2019) Rural Drinking Water Technology Hackathon at IIT Kharagpur in association with The University of Edinburgh ended today. Prof. Sriman Kumar Bhattacharyya, Deputy Director, IIT Kharagpur handed over the cash prize for the second runner-up position, jointly shared by Siddharth T, from NIT Warangal and Neelanjan Dutta, from IIEST Shibpur Siddharth demonstrated how plants could be used for #phytoremediation and Neelanjan showed how #electrocoagulation removed arsenic from water.

From fully automated, solar powered, lithium battery operated water purification unit to the ubiquitous ‘matka’ or clay water pot – the Rural Drinking Water Technology Hackathon at IIT Kharagpur brings together an array of techniques and technologies on display on May 13-14, 2019. Regulars at Kshitij, IIT Kharagpur and others are most welcome to visit this one unique project. The Hackathon is in association with The University of Edinburgh and sponsored by the Design Innovation Centre at IIT Kharagpur

IIT Kharagpur offers Full Scholarship Program for Students of #SAARC Nationality (excluding India) under the Asoke Deysarkar International Program (#ADSIP) For details download program literature: https://international.iitkgp.ac.in/static/website/ADSIPflyer20190207v1.2.pdf  Close on the heels of setting up exchange programs with universities in Canada, the United States, Australia and Europe, #IITKGP proudly presents the Asoke Deysarkar International Program (ADSIP) - a full scholarship program for SAARC nationals. Funded by distinguished alumnus, entrepreneur and philanthropist Dr. Asoke Deysarkar, the program supports full-time students and research scholars from SAARC countries to study at the most reputed technical institute in India. Each application will go through a rigorous selection process and the successful candidates can spend a summer/winter/ or an entire semester to study, work on a research project, collaborate with our global partners, and experience this unique country, all living and travel expenses paid.  Interested students can write to ir-office@adm.iitkgp.ac.in  For more information about international programs at IIT Kharagpur visit: https://international.iitkgp.ac.in/

Recently, Vinod Gupta has set up Prof. A S Davis Endowment Chair Professorship in the area of Thermodynamics to carry out the state-of-the-art teaching, research and other development in the Department of Mechanical Engineering. Humans of Kgp  Read the launch story on alumnus Samarth Mahajan by Satarupa Sen Bhattacharya on The Kgp Chronicle http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/humans-of-kgp/  There may be reams written about the emergence of a technology institute, nestled in a relatively remote corner of India, as a globally acknowledged and revered seat of academics and research. But what transforms an institute into an institution? And what breathes life into this seat, making it what it is -- the one and only IIT KGP?   Many things, of course, but most notably its people. The Humans of KGP.   This column is a paean to all those people, those who were and those who are; those who have enriched as well as those who have been enriched by this microcosmic universe on campus, in one way or the other. Their stories, in their own words.

Researchers from the Centre for Oceans, Rivers, Atmosphere and Land Sciences (CORAL) at IIT Kharagpur develop new model to predict the Indian Monsoon Rainfall. Published in Scientific Reports, the study reveals, the study reveals that the Summer Monsoon Rainfall variability is governed by the surface temperatures of the Eastern Pacific, Central Pacific, Atlantic and the north Indian Oceans, and equatorial zonal winds. However, the winter Monsoon Rainfall variability is largely controlled by the surface temperature of the North Atlantic and extratropical oceans  Read More . . . http://www.kgpchronicle.iitkgp.ac.in/iit-kgp-brings-new-model-to-predict-the-indian-monsoon-rainfall/

Foreign Training Program (FTP) is a unique initiative by IR Cell through which students get an opportunity to pursue research internship in a foreign university. This program commenced last year with the motive of simplifying the complete process to secure an FT. It is very well said that every accomplishment starts with a decision to try, and certainly we have been able to accomplish this through FTP. Now is the time to reveal the stats! With around 20 projects garnered, 26 selected students and multiple overwhelming offers from various established universities such as Northeastern University, New Castle University, Stockholm University to mention a few, IR cell takes pride in announcing the grand success of the program. To add further to the list of our achievements, we received an invitation to collaborate with EPFL University, ranked 12th in the QS Ranking. If you want some easy and quick avenues for your dream Universities, remain in touch with us. We have everything streamlined through the Foreign Training Program. Don’t miss the chance to add a golden feather to your hat…

Vision Probaho of IIT Kharagpur celebrates World Environment Day ’18  Vision Probaho, a fledgling eco-conservation cum awareness forum created by a section of IIT Kharagpur’s research scholars, marked the occasion of World Environment Day 2018 with a string of events on June 5. The day started with a pedal and plant initiative involving a cycle rally, which was followed by a plantation drive. Several students enacted a street play to highlight issues arising out of the irresponsible use of non-biodegradable products and the way this is accelerating the destruction of the environment. Students of the Institute also showcased the floral diversity of the campus in a photography exhibition.  A few of the campus luminaries shared their insights and exchanged ideas on conservation efforts. Dr Souvik Bhattacharyya, Vice-Chancellor, BITS Pilani, and former deputy director, IIT Kharagpur, who was present at the event, stressed on the need to reconcile economic growth with utmost care for the environment. He pointed out that reckless industrialisation, without proper checks and balances in place to prevent environmental degradation, would take us to a point of no return.  “To ensure the sustenance of vital natural resources, one must stop prevaricating and emphasise on the development of greener technologies that are in consonance with the preservation of the environment,” said Dr Bhattacharyya. He also asked the organisers to increase their outreach so that local villages can be incorporated in the conservation effort. His observation was supported by Mr Pranab Kumar Bachaspati, environmental activist. He talked about how the involvement of local communities in environmental conservation and restoration programmes can go a long way in creating a sustainable ethos of growth and environmental protection. Mr Bachaspati also shared snippets of his conservation efforts along the banks of the Kangsabati river.  Mrs Barnali Chakrabarti, who has mentored IIT Kharagpur’s green campus programme, highlighted the perils of the use of plastic in daily life. She argued strongly in favour of a personal pledge, whereby one would undertake to abandon the use of plastic in one’s life to an extent that was logically permissible. She highlighted the plight of local farmers who have suffered crop damage due to contamination caused by the plastic waste generated by IIT Kharagpur.  Prof. William Kumar Mohanty, President, Technology Students’ Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur, emphasised on the need to bring Vision Probaho under the ambit of Gymkhana to make it easy for the organisation to function within the campus.  The formation of Vision Probaho is evidence of the seriousness with which students of IIT Kharagpur address the issue of environmental degradation. Earlier this year, they had welcomed in their midst Tarak Chandra Pal, a cyclist who has been travelling around India to spread awareness about the need to plant trees among school and college students. A ‘pedal and plant’ rally had been organised on the occasion. The Institute’s students have been holding occasional roadside meetings to discuss with campus residents about ways to combat the plastic menace.  India was the global host for this year’s World Environment Day, whose theme was “Beat Plastic Pollution”. Before signing out, do consider the following facts: •In the last decade, we have produced more plastic than in the whole last century  •Every year, the world uses up to 5 trillion plastic bags  •Each year, at least 13 million tonnes of plastic end up in the oceans  •50 per cent of the plastic we use is single-use or disposable  •We buy 1 million plastic bottles every minute

Kgp is a magic ride for all of us. It is a mixed bag of happiness, despair, and wonders. It has never failed to Stupefy all those who have set foot here and we hope this journey has been as fantastic as Alice’s adventures down the Rabbit Hole, as magical as Harry’s stay at Hogwarts and as adventurous as Bilbo’s quest for the ring that ‘rules them all’ for the entire graduating batch. IIT KGP has set the precedent by encouraging the next generation of IITian alumni donate to their parents’ alma mater.   Shion Deysarkar, the scion of IIT Kharagpur alumni and US-based entrepreneurs Dr. Asoke Deysarkar and Dr. Ruma Acharya Deysarkar, has agreed to create an endowment for an amount of USD 300,000/, to set up three Chair Professorships at IIT KGP’s Asoke Deysarkar and Ruma Acharya Centre of Excellence in Petroleum Engineering.   "My parents have given me a lot of things and it is difficult for a child to give his parents back something and I see this as a small way to help my parents continue their work at IIT KGP and carry on their legacy." said Shion Deysarkar  https://www.facebook.com/thebetterindia/posts/10156310761329594

Arihant Binaykia, Asish Kumar Mishra and Pranshu Jain, Final Year Undergraduates at IIT Kharagpur have secured the Runners-up position at the Citi Campus Innovation Challenge 2017-18’ organized by Citibank, India. The team has been ranked 1st among all technical institutes which included all major IITs and BITS.  The ‘Citi Campus Innovation Challenge’ is a premier campus competition that requires teams to come up with innovative products and solutions in the banking and financial space. The competition was held across 21 premier engineering institutes and B-Schools in India including the top 7 IITs and 5 IIMs. The 2017-18 edition of the competition required the teams to design a vision for ‘The Open Banking Revolution in India'.   The IIT Kharagpur team showcased their Analytical, FinTech and Entrepreneurial skills to come up with an innovative idea to revolutionize the lending space in India.   A total of 250+ teams went through a rigorous 3 round evaluation process, out of which 16 teams qualified for the 2nd round, and only the best 6 teams made it to the 3rd Round to reach the National Finals. The teams were invited to present their ideas in the National Finals at Citibank Head Office, Mumbai which was judged by Citi India’s leadership.   Congratulations!

#IITKGP celebrated Ek Bharat Shrestha Bharat  IIT Kharagpur celebrated the ‘Ek Bharat Shrestha Bharat’ initiative by MHRD, Government of India, in its campus premises on 30 and 31 Jan 2018. This program is the first in the series of cultural celebrations proposed by the Government of India and will be subsequently followed by 15 more such cultural days in the campus.   Ek Bharat Shrestha Bharat initiative is aimed at celebrating the diverse linguistic, cultural and religious traditions that hold together our composite national identity.   On 30th and 31st Jan 2018, IIT Kharagpur celebrated and showcased the rich cultural and social heritage of Tamil Nadu and Jammu & Kashmir.   The program has been designed by the students of the institute under the aegis of Technology Students’ Gymkhana at IIT Kharagpur assisted by the Art & Cultural departments of the states of Tamil Nadu and Jammu & Kashmir.   “This year-long initiative will definitely prove to be a catalyst in narrowing down the distances in terms of connect and communication and bring about an amalgamation of cultures from different spectrums of our society” Prof. William K Mohanty, President, Technology Students’ Gymkhana.  The event featured some unique cultural representations from the states which otherwise remain unknown to the rest of the country. These included Mayilattam (Peacock Dance), Silambattam (Indian Martial Art from Tamil Nadu) & Bull Dance, Karakattam (Water Pot Dance), Kavadi Attam (Burden Dance) & Puliyattam (Tiger Dance), Devaraattam (Folk Dance Preserved by Kattabomman Dynasty at Madurai) & Moonkilpatham,  Naiyandi Melam (Mockery Dance using Unique Percussion Instrument) from Tamil Nadu and Hiran Dance (J&K), Balti/Ladakhi Group Song by J&K students, Bacha Nagma Performance (J&K).  Apart from contributing around 103 artists from their states to perform various cultural activities, both these states also put up their authentic food and merchandise stalls inside the Institute premises for the benefit of the IIT community and students.

IIT Kharagpur and Tata Medical Center Kolkata launched collaborative programs for Students and Medical Professionals. Director IIT Kharagpur signed MoU with Dr. Mammen Chandy, Director of Tata Medical Center, Kolkata on January 4, 2018.  From the academic year of 2018-19, IIT Kharagpur in collaboration with Tata Medical Center will be conducting an integrated M.Sc. - Ph.D. programmes on medical physics (required for radiation therapy and safety in cancer patients), nuclear medicine (required to diagnose as well as treat many diseases) and molecular medical microbiology (required to fight infections optimally). One of the highlights of the course is going to be the first certificate program in clinical oncology from India, where postgraduate oncologists will work within specific areas of interest with basic science and engineering experts to combat cancer.

#Samsung India and #IITKgp signed MoU to set up Samsung Digital Academy at the Institutes’ campus, thereby strengthening commitment towards the government’s Skill India mission and also bolstering the Digital India initiative. The Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kharagpur, would host the Samsung #Innovation Lab and will train students on the Internet of Things.  https://www.telegraphindia.com/calcutta/hands-on-lessons-for-iit-students-178187  Speaking on the occasion, Mr YoungKi Byun, MD, Samsung Research & Development Institute, Delhi said, “Samsung is happy to partner with IIT Kharagpur to help students leverage the growing digital technologies market, especially Internet of things which is the future of connectivity. With Samsung Digital Academy, students will be able to hone their programming skills on Tizen, the operating system for IoT. We are committed to work in the field of next-generation technology development and participate in the growth of advanced research areas of IoT. Innovation is the future and we at Samsung encourage students, on a regular basis, to develop their talent.”  Prof. Partha Pratim Chakrabarti, Director, IIT Kharagpur said, “We are delighted to work with Samsung for this initiative. The partnership will help our students in developing their skills in the emerging areas of IoT and Artificial Intelligence. The students enrolling for the courses will be able to utilize this opportunity to be part of an exciting, new era in smart devices that will help shape the future.”

Watch IIT KGP Researchers Prof. Animesh Mukherjee and Mayank Singh answer some interesting questions regarding the destiny of research papers - whether they get increasingly popular or lose popularity as time passes by, what other papers would gain from the loss of this popularity?   WATCH, LIKE and SHARE and make it the MOST WATCHED VIDEO with maximum view count to help this IITKGP research, the ONLY INDIAN scientific work, to COMPETE with other projects in the ACM SIGKDD 2017, one of the top CS conferences in the area of Data Mining and Data Sciences.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fhGewF4Xyo0  The researchers have shown in their work on modeling how the flow of citations, coming to a paper, is diverted to other research papers. In this work, they talk about how research papers that get older by time lose their potential citations. They have proven that new papers that cite these older papers steal the incoming citations. They have also proves that this stealing (or relaying from the old to the new) effect becomes more prominent as time passes by. This work has been accepted among 131 (out of 748 submissions) research ideas from all around the globe.

Her father worked in the circus. He discovered his daughter’s uncanny ability to calculate while teaching her a card trick when she was just 6. At this point, she had no formal education. Her father quit the circus and she was taken on road shows that displayed her ability to compute numbers.The crowds went wild. In 1944, her father took her to London.Then Europe.Then US. Spectators, scientists, psychologists from around the world were all spell-bound. In 1977, she gave the 23rd root of a 201-digit number in 50 seconds. On 18 June 1980, she demonstrated the multiplication of two 13-digit numbers picked at random. This event was recorded in the 1982 Guinness Book of Records. Writer Steven Smith said, "the result is so far superior to anything previously reported that it can only be described as unbelievable". Even today, #Shakuntala #Devi stands testimony of humans over computers and mind over matter. As we pay tribute to this stellar woman on today's #WOWW, we would like to draw your attention to her book 'Figuring: The Joy of Numbers', which is available as a free resource on National Digital Library of India - http://bit.ly/2pu0IXR - Many of the methods used by Devi to do mental calculations are mentioned in this book. #WonderfulWomenOnWednesdays #ShaktuntalaDevi #WhatAGirl #HumanComputer Image courtesy - http://stepanov.lk.net/mnemo/pek2.jpg

Quantum Biomimetics: Can We Learn to Fly like Birds, Smell like Animals, Cook like Plants?  Talk by IITKGP Alumnus Prof. Swaroop Ganguly (EC/99), faculty at IITB, Dept. of Electrical Engineering Date: May 8, Time: 4 PM, Venue: A-102, Dept. of E&ECE  ABSTRACT: It is strange and fascinating, and probably also true, that non-trivial quantum effects play functional roles in biological systems. I shall talk about two such systems: the avian compass (navigation by magnetic field sensing in birds), and olfaction (the sense of smell). At each stop along this tour in biophysics, the engineer in me will emerge and wonder whether we could apply this science to make something useful. I shall narrate, in brief, recent efforts in my group to model these quantum biological systems and explore the possibility of electronic devices inspired by them.  SPEAKER BIO: Swaroop Ganguly got his BTech from IIT Kharagpur, and MS-PhD from UT Austin. Thereafter, he held R&D positions at UT Austin, Freescale, Tokyo Electron and IMEC before joining IIT Bombay in 2009, where he is now Associate Professor, PI of the Centre of Excellence in Nanoelectronics, and Co-PI of the Research Park. He has over 100 publications in peer-reviewed journals and international conferences. His research interests revolve around the physics of nanoelectronic devices. He likes to teach physics to engineering students.

Prof. Chhanda Chakraborti, Professor, Department of Humanities & Social Sciences has been awarded the Shastri Fellowship 2016-17 by the Shastri Indo-Canadian Institute (SICI), MHRD, Government of India.

She was born on 31 March 1865 to a land-rich, orthodox family in Kalyan, #Maharashtra. Her family bankrupt, she was married at the age of 9 to a widower, 20 years her senior. At 14, she gave birth to a baby boy, who dies 10 days after. In 1883, with encouragement from her husband, Anandi set sail by herself for #America. Her son's death had spurred her evermore to take up medicine. A woman of fragile health, but indomitable spirit, Anandi enrolled herself to the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania (now absorbed into Drexel University College of Medicine) She graduated with an MD on 11 March 1886; the topic of her thesis was "Obstetrics among the Aryan Hindoos". On her graduation, Queen #Victoria sent her a congratulatory message. In late 1886, Anandibai returned to India, receiving a hero's welcome. The princely state of Kolhapur appointed her as the physician-in-charge of the female ward of the local Albert Edward Hospital. Read about this extraordinary woman in #marathi: http://bit.ly/2oWqWpz  or in #bengali:  http://bit.ly/2pvsUfy  from the archives of National Digital Library of India #WWOW #WonderfulWomenOnWednesdays #WomenInScience

This is to remind you all that the session of Career Conclave organized by CDC, on preparation for Machine Learning/Data Analytics profiles, is scheduled to be held at Kalidas Auditorium at 6:00 pm today. Anyone who is remotely interested in ML/DA companies should definitely attend this session, especially those in their pre-final or pre-internship year. Over 30% UG students were placed in a Data Science Profile this year. At least 25% profiles open for any given department were Data Science profiles. Given the number of opportunities for everyone, irrespective of the department, we highly recommend that you attend the session even if you are remotely interested in this area. As mentioned previously, the session will be hosted by Kumar Krishna Agarwal (Goldman Sachs and Xerox Research), Bhupendra Bule (Quantiphi), Manish Goyal (SAP Labs) and Ashish Kumar (Cognizant).

IIT Kharagpur researchers have developed a rock stethoscope, which will foretell vital rock information and failures to prevent any accidents during mining. The equipment is already being employed at the Asansol coal mines and is being tested in Madhya Pradesh. This technology will prevent the hundred or so mining accident related deaths in the country every year.  Kudos to the team!

Spirituality providing the 360 degree finishing to Science  https://iitkgp.org/content/iit-kharagpur-inspires-students-venture-synthesized-platform-science-and-spirituality  The All India Science and Spiritual QuestConference (AISSQ) held at IIT Kharagpur by Bhaktivedanta Institute, Kolkatafrom 30th Oct – 2nd Nov 2015 aimed to bring forward this synthesis of science and spirituality as scientists from various domain starting from theoretical physics, molecular biology, mathematicians, engineers gathered together from across the world explaining this integral connection with spirituality on various facets of scientific experiments and studies as is being conducted for decades now.   The Conference saw students’ participation from more than 50 Indian educational institutions some such being IISC Bangalore, BITS Pilani, VIT, Osmania University, IIT Varanasi, IIT Bombay, ISM Dhanbad, IIEST, Delhi University, NIT Rourkela, NDRI Bangalore, JNTU Hyderabad, ISI Kolkata, TIFR etc.

IIT Kharagpur Students Sweep American Express AnalyzeThis 2015 by winning the first three prizes  American Express Campus Analyze This is a data analysis competition organized by American Express, a multinational financial services corporation headquartered at the World Financial Center, Manhattan, New York City, United States.  The aim of the competition is to offer the students a pedagogical and professional experience in the analytics industry and the opportunity to explore analytics from a practical perspective. This project is a part of American Express campus communication strategy and aims to enhance students’ creativity and enrich their knowledge of analytics in general.  Eligibility: Open for B.Tech, B.Arch, Dual and M.Sc. Integrated Courses.  https://in.axpcampus.com/AnalyzeThis/competition.php

Chance to put your name into the history of IIT Kharagpur!   Design the official Mascot of KGP. Themes: 1. Bengal Tiger 2. Ant 3. Panda 4. Bengal Cat  Any picture of a paper drawing, a Photoshop Design or any visual representation of the idea is acceptable. Designs along with a short write-up on the design specification (for example, reasons for choosing a nerdy design, or reasons for putting a hat on the mascot, or any other design feature justification would do) is to be sent to the mascot.iitkgp@gmail.com.  Deadline: 1st November 2015.  Incentives: Win exciting goodies. Bragging rights are complementary.  Important Note: You might send your designs on some other theme as well, but you need to send another small write-up along with it. The article will describe the reasons behind selecting that theme as the mascot of IIT KGP.

IIT Kharagpur ties up with Three Universities in Israel and Two in Jordan

Photos of Signing of MoUs with Universities of Israel in the presence of the Honourable President of India. As Director IIT Kharagpur I was privileged to be the Leader of the Academic Delegation from India. The Indian Ambassador, Shri Jaideep Sarkar who is also an Alumnus was also present and played a key role in forging the 8 MoUs signed by three Indian Institutions with Israel counterparts. Let us hope IIT Kharagpur continues to lead in the research collaborations in the near future. We are planning some unique student exchanges, faculty visits and research workshops and projects.

He is now working on development of a joint program between Kharagpur and leading US universities where US students will come to IIT Kharagpur for training.

Announcements Details:  Greetings from British Council!   This is to inform you that British Council has announced The Education UK Alumni Awards to celebrate the achievements of alumni who have studied at UK universities in the last ten years. The awards honour the outstanding achievements made by business professionals, entrepreneurs and community leaders who can demonstrate how their UK education has impacted on their subsequent success.   There are three award categories:   ·        Professional Achievement Award – recognising UK alumni who have distinguished themselves through exemplary leadership and achievements in their professional industry ·        Entrepreneurial Award – recognising UK alumni who are active in initiating or contributing to innovative new business opportunities that have the potential for strong growth ·        Social Impact Award – recognising UK alumni who have made an exceptional contribution and commitment to creating positive social change and improving the lives of others   WHO CAN APPLY?   The Education UK Alumni Awards are open to individuals who are ·        residing in India; and ·        alumni of a recognised UK higher education institution* who studied at this institution for a minimum of one term/semester within the past ten years (i.e. in/from 2005 or later).   Applications have opened now and would close by 31 October, 2015. Reviewing and shortlisting will take place in November and December 2015, and you will be informed of the status of your application by late December 2015/January 2016. The winners will be announced in March 2016 over a high profile event which would be attended by leaders from government, industry and education, as well as other outstanding UK alumni.   Both the finalists and the winners will become a part of a new international UK Alumni Award Network. The first-ever Education UK Alumni Awards were launched by the British Council in September 2014 for UK alumni across India, mainland China and the USA. This year we are expanding the awards to ten countries.   To apply for an award this year, please see the details on how to participate, or nominate others on our website: http://www.britishcouncil.org/education-uk-awards   Here, we encourage you to apply/nominate/share UK alumni awards information within your network.   For further queries, please contact my colleague Anwesha Majumder, Project Manager, at Anwesha.Majumder@britishcouncil.org.

The Scholars' Avenue will be conducting an AMA session with me, Atal Ashutosh Agarwal, Vice President, Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur on Tuesday, 8th September from 8 pm to 10 pm at reddit.com/r/thescholarsavenue.  Just to give an insight: AMAs or "Ask Me Anything"s are posts on reddit, where users can collectively interview the host. Users post questions on the host's post, and the host responds to them. All sorts of people have hosted AMAs in the past - from celebrities, astronauts, CEOs and Presidents to common people with interesting jobs (you can find them at reddit.com/r/IAmA). These can provide fascinating insights into the lives of people who we might never meet, otherwise. They can also serve as a platform for public figures to interact with their audiences.  We encourage you to ask me about halls, academics, internships, placements, campus initiatives, Gymkhana activities, or anything else that's on your mind. All students, faculty members and alumni are welcome to participate!  Note: To post questions, you must have a reddit account. It's extremely simple to sign up for one - you don't even need to provide an email id. The AMA post will be made on reddit.com/r/thescholarsavenue on Monday evening. Navigate to reddit.com/r/thescholarsavenue, open the post and submit your question as a comment. To ensure that your question reaches me, post your questions before the AMA begins at 8pm on Tuesday.

IIT Kharagpur is the national leader for the central-government approved Global Initiative of Academic Networks (GIAN) plan that paves way for the entry of foreign faculty into Indian institutions in higher education. Aiming to increase the footfall of eminent scientists and entrepreneurs from abroad in Indian institutes, the project has secured funds of Rs 35 crores. IIT Kharagpur is the national coordinator for this programme across all institutions in India and the group leader for IITs, NITs, IIITs and IIEST. The programme plans short-term and semester-long courses for foreign faculty in India and has scheduled 500 courses for the academic session 2015-16. The website for this programme would be launched soon at gian.iitkgp.ac.in.

As we celebrate, Today is a Day of our Remembrance of our Dedication to the Service of the Nation:  "For our motherland ... nothing is dearer than her service, ... everything else is to be directed to that end. If you will study, study for her sake; train yourselves body and mind and soul for her service. .... earn your living that you may live for her sake. ... go abroad to foreign lands that you may bring back knowledge with which you may do service to her. Work that she may prosper. Suffer that she may rejoice. All is contained in that one single advice --- Nothing Is Dearer than Her Service."  Excerpts from a Talk given at the Bengal National College on August 23, 1907 by SRI AUROBINDO (born August 15th 1872)

We mourn the sad demise of our revered ex-teacher, Prof B N Das, of E&ECE. A academician and researcher of the highest order, a giant who helped build the formidable reputation of IIT KGP as a centre of excellence in Microwave and Radar Communications, who was revered by the leadership in India's key programmes of Space and Defence, he remains in our hearts as the loving father-like teacher whose caring scolding, eye for quality work, and his constant encouragement for IIT Kharagpur alumni in the highest academic circles, We, especially my generation, who studied with his son, will miss him dearly.

Silent Contributors from KGP in preservation of Heritage Site: Over the last decade, IIT Kharagpur's senior faculty, Prof Anandapran Gupta and Prof G C Mitra have been silently helping the Archaeological Survey of India restore and preserve the Sri Jagannath Temple in Puri, especially its structural aspects and preventing it from rapid breakdown. Much of the credit for the temple remaining in good shape in recent times is due to their support to the Government. This news is about the recent help given by Prof A P Gupta to the Archaeological Survey of India is rare as the Professors always wanted to remain away from the limelight. Professor Satyabroto Sinha is no more.  I am saddened to inform you the demise of Prof. Satyabroto Sinha, former Professor of Electrical Engineering Department who left us on 17th July (Friday) at around 2-30 P.M. in a Kolkata Hospital. Prof, Sinha had a long and illustrious association with the Institute since his joining as a Lecturer in 1961 till 2005, when he retired as an Emeritus Professor. In between, he had held several positions like Dean (Planning), Coordinator- Technology Development Mission (TDM), Member- Board of Governors, Vice president – IIT Teachers’ Association and many others. Known to be an outstanding teacher, a versatile researcher, a great orator and above all, one of the finest human beings in the campus who was respected by all, his demise is a great loss to his students and the Campus Community.
IIT Kharagpur Announces Distinguished Alumnus Awards 2015. The Awards are to be conferred on Sunday, August 9, 2015 during the 61st Convocation.

A REVERED IITKGP TEACHER LEFT FOR HIS HEAVENLY ABODE  Our beloved former Professor & Head of the Department of Electrical Engineering, Prof. Ajit Kumar Chattopadhyay has left us for his heavenly abode on 15th July 2015 at around 8 PM after a major cardiac arrest.  Prof. Ajit K. Chattopadhyay received his BE in Electrical Engineering from erstwhile BE College Shibpur now known as Indian Institute of Engineering Science & Technology (IIEST), M Tech degree in Electrical Machines from IIT Kharagpur, and the PhD degree from the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (UMIST). He joined the Electrical Engineering (EE) Department at IIT, Kharagpur in 1960, became a Professor in 1976 and the Head of the Department during 1992-1995.  Prof. Chattopadhyay has done pioneering work on cycloconverters. Understanding the bright future of power electronics, he took leadership to start a laboratory and research/industrial consultancy in this area in IIT Kharagpur. He has authored more than 140 research publications in the field of Electrical Machines, Power Electronics and Electric Drives. A prolific researcher he built the foundation of Power Electronics related research activity at IIT Kharagpur and was a pioneer in power electronic research in India putting the Institute in the world map in the field of Power Electronics.  Prof. Chattopadhyay became the first Life Fellow of IEEE from IIT Kharagpur. He was also Fellow of the National Academy of Engineering (India), Life Fellow of IE (I), IETE (I) and of the West Bengal Academy of Science and Technology. He received the Bimal Bose Award (1986), Bharatia Cutler Hammer Prize (1986), Tata Rao Prize of IE (India) (1993) and the Distinguished Alumnus Award (2006) of IIEST, Shibpur. He was elected as a Distinguished Lecturer of the IEEE Industry Applications Society. After retirement he became Honorary Emeritus Professor, Department of Electrical Engineering at IIEST.  Everyone has to leave, but Professor Chattopadhyay lived in style and touched all whoever came in contact. He will be ever remembered by all his students, colleagues and friends. We pray peace for the departed soul and deeply express solace for the bereaved family.

KGPians qualifies for finals of Greening contest by Schneider Electric at Paris - Read their Success Story  Go Green in the City – by Schneider Electric is a global business case challenge wherein university students, in teams of two, are required to submit an innovative and efficient idea for energy management of smarter cities. As part of the competition, it is compulsory to have a female member to foster gender diversity. Since this competition is organised on a huge scale, it draws much fanfare on social networking sites. The competition is organised in three stages. In the first stage, teams are required to submit a 4 slide presentation explaining their idea. In the second stage, the top 100 teams are allotted a mentor from Schneider Electric. Following this the top 100 teams develop an 800-word synopsis and video presentation. In the third round, the top 12 teams with the most promising and innovative ideas are flown to Paris for the international finals where they battle it out for the top spot. The top teams are offered a job at Schneider Electric and as part of their prize are given the opportunity to travel any two countries free of cost! It was last July when the results of GGITC 2014 were announced when two IIT Kharagpur students got acquainted with it. The team comprising of Spoorthy Kotla (Department of Biotechnology) and Mohamad Meraj Shaikh (Department of Architecture) took part in this year’s edition and have successfully made it to the international finals to be held in Paris. To top it up, they are the only team to have qualified from India and would, therefore, be representing the country at the international finals to be held in Paris.  The Stimulus - Although frankly, the opportunity to travel to “Paris” should be luring enough for anyone to take part, the motivation to go through with this challenge, in the words of Spoorthy, was that “it offered a unique opportunity to come up with an innovative solution that could change our perspective towards energy management. Apart from that, the fact that we would get to work with a mentor from Schneider Electric was equally compelling”. After a thorough analysis of the competition through blogs of past winners and scrutiny of the official site, they decided to participate.  The Preparation - As Meraj puts it “We started out by gathering as much information as possible. We did get some help from our seniors who had taken part four years back and had made it to the finals. We then studied the company portfolio to get a basic idea of what the company specialises in. Our approach was that, since it was a business case competition, our solution would be more apt if it was not only innovative but at the same time aligned itself with Schneider’s business portfolio”  The Execution - This was the most difficult part as one of them was not present on campus. Spoorthy says, “Although I was on campus, my teammate was on his compulsory six-month internship and therefore coordination and discussion was an issue but never a deterrent to our motivation. Most of our discussions took place via chats or hangouts and having worked together previously on other competitions, we were well aware of our strengths and weaknesses; so accordingly we used to split the work”.  The Claim-to-fame idea - When asked about the strategies used to their advantage, Meraj says, “Our idea was that of ‘Electricity Trading’. The idea actually popped up when we were reading an article on clean energy published by Google, it talked about how today’s renewable energy won’t really save us; it was rather an effective demand response strategy that could turn the tables. It was only after this, that the idea of selling electricity came to our minds. The difficulty was that, it is not physically possible to sell electricity. So we came up with an innovative bidding system that could solve this issue”. Spoorth says, “I still remember how difficult it was to come up with the bidding process; we’ve spent sleepless nights only developing the bidding process and removing errors if any.”    The Professor in charge - Although there was no professor in charge they did get a lot of help from Professor Ram Babu Roy from the Rajendra Mishra School of Engineering Entrepreneurship. Spoorthy says, “Having studied Business Plan Engineering under him in my 3rd year, I approached him once our selection to the second round was confirmed. He helped us out in developing the financial aspect of our case study”.  Any suggestions that you would like to give to other students who may participate next year? The students further send a word for future participants of the competition, as Meraj puts it,” The competition is totally different from other case study competitions in its approach. Definitely it requires a lot of hard work and patience but it’s definitely worth it!”  IIT Kharagpur congratulates both of them on their success and wishes them best of luck for the final round to be held in Paris.

Partnership with BEML to give New Focus on R&D in Core Engineering Design for IITKGP On Friday, IIT and BEML (Rail and Metro Division) have signed an MoU for carrying out R&D on Rail Technology. BEML and IIT Kharagpur signed the MoU with a vision to be in the forefront of the emerging areas of railway rolling stock, including medium speed / high speed rail car and metro projects, with indigenously developed technologies. The proposed areas of cooperation include, bogie design, 3 phase propulsion system controls, EMI/EMC studies, alternate car body material, etc. It was a great experience to visit the plant, see how the latest metro rail cars are manufactured from scratch with high quality control and discuss new research opportunities in core engineering design. This is a great opportunity for our researchers at faculty and student level.

Stable Marriages in the Offing!!: Joint Seat Allocation for IITs, ISM, NITs, IIITs, GFTIs to use an adaptation of the Nobel-Prize winning Algorithm originally developed by David Gale and Lloyd Shapley and later studied in depth by Alvin Roth, contributions for which Shapley and Roth got the Nobel Prize in 2012 (Gale unfortunately died in 2008 and apparently dead people are not awarded Nobel Prize)  This time there is going to be joint seat allocation of the NITs/IIITs/GFTIs and IITs/ISM. While there will be multiple merit lists, merit lists for NITs /IIITs/GFTIs with /without Architecture using a combination of JEE(Main) and Board percentile and another merit list for IITs & ISM based on JEE(Advanced), candidates will fill in only one choice sheet with their options. The merit lists have many sub-merit lists depending on the category (General / OBC /SC/ST) of the candidates and the subgroups of PwD (Challenged) candidates among these categories. Effectively there are 30+ merit lists and a complex set of Business Rules for Allocation.  The problem of allotting seats from multiple merit lists (while maintaining merit priority of each merit list and candidate optimal solutions in case of multiple solutions) with all the intricacies of the Indian system containing various category seats and business rules is not a trivial issue. Moreover there could be upto 12+ lakh candidates for 86 Institutions covering IITs, ISM, NITs, IIITs and some GFTIs.  The allocation algorithm developed jointly by the IITs and NITs for this purpose is a 'candidate optimal scheme' based on the path-breaking Gale-Shapley method of deferred acceptance. However, it will have several additional features to take care of various issues unique to the Indian admission system of categories, multi-round allocation with various options of freeze, float, slide etc., across rounds a link to the original paper of Gale and Shapley is provided below. NIC is doing the implementation under the supervision of the Joint Seat Allocation Authority (JoSAA) formed by MHRD.  Soon a portal for Joint Seat Allocation will be up with all the required information.  I will also try to post more information as the time approaches.  Here is the original 1962 paper by Gale and Shapley:  http://www.econ.ucsb.edu/~te…/Courses/Ec100C/galeshapley.pdf  http://www.slate.com/…/nobel_prize_in_economics_lloyd_shapl…

We lost another gem - Soumyadeep Basu -- in an accident in Ladakh.  We mourn the loss of Soumyadeep Basu, student of Dept. of Physics. Soumyadeep went to Ladakh with his parents when their car met with an avalanche on their way to Leh on June 8, 2015. Both Soumyadeep and his mother Prof. Rajashree Basu (faculty of Political Science at Rabindra Bharati University) passed away. Soumyadeep's father Dr. Padmanabha Basu, scientist with Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics, fortunately survived the avalanche and the freezing temperatures. We pray for his speedy recovery.  With Soumyadeep's demise, not only IIT-KGP has lost a soul of its own but the country has lost a talented youth. May his soul rest in peace. We also pray for his family to bear this terrible loss.

Call for Support: The Food Sustainability Pilot Project under the Unnat Bharat Abhiyan abut which I posted earlier is producing tangible results which are being felt by the farmers themselves. A bumper crop in spite of a serious pest attack which would have otherwise destroyed the whole effort! We are receiving requests from all over to replicate this. Can Alumni help garner funds from various organizations through Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Funding?  This should not be difficult if alumni talk to their organizations or other agencies who may be keen to support such a scheme. Adopting a village will costs around Rs 20 lakhs to Rs 25 lakhs depending on size, population, activity, etc. After that they are expected to become self sustainable in 3 to 4 years. We already got requests from more than 15 units! Let us know if some organization wishes to adopt a village for this activity.  Please get back to us on how you can help organize funding so that we can scale this all over the state and country. You may contact the Lead Faculty in this project Prof P B S Bhadoria of Agriculture & Food Engineering or our Dean (Sponsored Research & Industrial Consultancy) or may also write to me (PPC or Director)  I would like to remind you that decades ago IIT Kharagpur was responsible for modernization of lakhs of rice mills in the country. We can repeat this in a larger scale with help from all. Looking forward for your cooperation and support.

On World Environment Day 2015 - We have decided to undertake a new mission  IIT Kharagpur Pledges to revamp its almost crippled 50 year old sewerage system to make it more environment friendly, conserve and reuse water, and help create a more Eco-friendly environment. Yesterday we reviewed the initial plans and decided to go ahead. It is estimated to cost about Rs 45 crores over a period of 3 to 4 years. We are now working out the details. Suggestions may be sent to Prof M M Ghangrekar, proponent and Prof-in-Charge of this ambitious Project. We need your support.  We request all members of the IIT Kharagpur Community, including departments, hostels and campus residents to take some steps to help create a more nature-friendly campus. Action taken for the same may please be intimated.

NMEICT T10KT Programme on Teaching Introduction to Algorithm Design from IIT Kharagpur:  Last week, Prof P P Das, Prof Pallab Dasgupta and myself (P P Chakrabarti) just completed a full programme on interacting with 7200 teachers live on how to teach the foundation course 'Introduction to Algorithm Design' under the MHRD NMEICT Programme on Talk to 10K Teachers (T10KT).  The effort has been very rewarding from the feedback received from the participants who wanted continuity in the interaction.  It was a very interesting experience where we first had an interaction with 221 coordinators who came to IIT Kharagpur in March 2015 for a week long interaction. The lectures were video recorded.  Subsequently we had a set of preparatory assignments to all the 7200 participating teachers who watched the earlier videos and answered assignments. During the last week we interacted with about 7200 live for 6 days across 221 centres.  We now plan to take this further to the level of students and create a repository of teaching and support material.  In order to take this forward, a Facebook site has been set up in the link given below:  https://www.facebook.com/t10kt.algorithms  We will be putting up material on this and look forward to comments and suggestions. We hope that with support from all, we will be able to help the large student community grappling with this core course

We Lost Anirban  I had put up a post earlier requesting support for Anirban Bhattacharya, our PhD student suffering from cancer.  Informing you with a heavy heart that we lost Anirban after a long and valiant fight with cancer. He breathed his last in the ICU of Apollo Hospital Kolkata yesterday evening May 31 2015. In my opinion he was one of the most brilliant PhD students in recent times -- a wonderful, simple, every smiling and humble person, who stayed back in KGP to pursue research in India on a difficult topic. He was close to some very good research results when disease struck him.  Till the very last he used to talk about IITKGP. He considered this his home. He leaves behind two aged and extremely ill parents whom he used to look after. He was their only child.  We would like to thank everyone who supported him in so many ways during this period of great suffering and turmoil. It would have been very difficult to carry out this battle so long without the overwhelming support from all over.  We hope that we will be able to put in something in his memory.

Team Saans, part of COEO Labs is an IIT Kharagpur medical technology startup , which develops innovative medical devices that focuses on trauma, emergency and critical cases of patients. Team Saans which emerged winner at Empresario - Social Track, a Business Model Competition by Entrepreneurship Cell, IIT Kharagpur conducted in association with International Business Model Competition(IBMC), an internationally recognized B-Model competition co-hosted by Harvard, Stanford and Brigham university and as a result got a direct entry into the Semi Finals of IBMC. Team Saans has made us proud as they come up as the finalists at IBMC 2015. A Survey for Alumnus Shail Kumar's upcoming book  Shailendra Kumar, IIT KGP alumnus is writing a book on India. Titled *Superhighway to India's Golden Age*, he says that it is a non-fiction narrative about India's future and how to get there. Shailendra wants to hear from you. Could you share your thoughts by taking a brief 2-3 minute survey at:  Survey: goo.gl/xLRSOv. The survey ends on Sunday May 31st.  Shailendra is planning to publish select thoughts from this survey in his book. He has also offered to give a free copy of the book to everyone whose quotes are published. You can visit his Facebook Page <http://goo.gl/g8gQeY> and check some of the selected quotes.  It would be great for KGP students and alumni, a group that is *Dedicated to the Service of the Nation*, to share their thoughts to the important question of defining India's new Golden Age.

The Honourable Minister for Human Resources Development, Smt Smriti Zubin Irani made a short two hour visit to IIT Kharagpur , May 27th 2015. During the visit she reviewed the various projects related to National Digital Library, Virtual Laboratories, SandHI (Science & Heritage), Future of Cities, Unnat Bharat Abhiyan, etc. She viewed the interactive Course on T10KT where 7500 teachers were participating live. Subsequently she visited the Membrane Separation Laboratory in the Chemical Engineering Department where prize-winning technology developed by IIT Kharagpur for Dialysis and Arsenic Filter were demonstrated. Several new ideas and suggestions came up in the meetings. The HRM posed several challenges for IIT Kharagpur to take in the near future.

Sad to hear that legendary scientist John Forbes Nash, Jr. - The 'Beautiful Mind' Mathematician, recipient of two of the highest prizes for science (Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences 1994 for contributions to Game Theory and Abel Prize in Mathematics 2015 for contributions to Non-linear Partial Differential Equations) has died in a car crash yesterday, May 23rd 2015. In 1978, Nash was awarded the John von Neumann Theory Prize for his discovery of non-cooperative equilibria, now called Nash equilibria. He won the Leroy P. Steele Prize in 1999. In 2010 he won the Double Helix Medal. For years he battled what was said to be severe mental illness. A book was written and subsequently a movie was made on his extraordinary life. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Forbes_Nash,_Jr.

Announcing the 'Prof R P Gokarn Grants in Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering / Maritime Technology' -- An Alumnus honouring his revered Professor. We thank Tilak (my batch mate and hall mate) not only for his generous contribution but more for his remembrance of great teachers who built IITKGP. We look forward to more such donations from alumni honouring jewels like Prof Gokarn. Mr Tilak Sarkar ( B Tech 1985), through the Tiara Charitable Foundation, has set up a grant in honour of our teacher, distinguished academic and gentleman extraordinaire, Prof R P Gokarn. The grant called "Prof R P Gokarn Innovation Grant" shall be in the categories of 'Marine Design and Innovation Challenge Grant', High-Value PhD Fellowships and Visiting Faculty / Professor of Practice / Workshops. Prof. R P Gokarn (Ex-Professor of Naval Architecture and Ex-Dean of Post Graduate Studies I.I.T. Khargpur) is a world renowned authority on Naval Achitecture and propeller design with over forty years teaching experience. Prof Gokarn is also a Distinguished Alumnus of IIT Kharagpur During the thirty-nine years that he was at IIT Kharagpur, Professor Ramchandra Prabhakar Gokarn taught a variety of subjects including Resistance, Propulsion and Manoeuvrability of Ships, High Speed Marine Craft, Ship Power Systems, Stability of Buoyant Systems, Shipyard Organisation, Shipbuilding Management, and Ship Performance. The Grant is in keeping with a philosophy of honouring an inspirational Professor, an influential academic and gentleman extraordinaire who has influenced countless batches of students of IIT Kharagpur with his very special personality and achievements and hopes this Award will be a source of inspiration and pride to the recipients and to the Grant. The primary recipient of this Grant is the Department of Ocean Engineering and Naval Architecture, represented and administered by the Dean, Alumni Affairs, Indian Institute of Technology (Kharagpur). It is intended mainly to undertake and develop innovative multi-disciplinary research or experimental projects with special emphasis on Marine Design and hope to generate research and empirical material for both academic papers for Academic and Conference journals as and as well as patentable ideas and inventions. http://www.tiarafoundation.com/rpg.html https://www.linkedin.com/pub/ramchandra-gokarn/21/ab5/5a8

New Nepal Earthquake!! Speculation is rife on what is in store.  Nepal Earthquake of 2015-05-12 12:35:19 (UTC+05:30) of Mw 7.3 triggered at 18km (11mi) SE of Kodari, Nepal with an intensity of MM VII, MM Intensity III/IV felt in Kolkata and Kharagpur and one of its aftershocks as recorded by IIT Kharagpur Broadband Seismological Observatory. (Few graphs courtesy Prof Shankar K Nath who is also in charge of Kolkata Microzonation)  It is turning out to be alarming with so many such happening and speculation is rife amongst scientists. Here is a blurb from a highly reliable expert and an attached press note:  "this is a new EQ not an aftershock...is 83 km east of Kathmandu..150 km east of 25th april EQ epicentre....overlapping 1934 EQ ...it is propagating eastward....such things are known from subduction zones like Andaman but unheard in Himalayas...I just speculated that the adjacent old faults might be stressed...but we do not understand the process really...I am afraid north bengal er besh chap ache in coming days.... Kolkata it was huge this time relatively"

First Pan IIT Workshop on IMPRINT for India was held in IIT Kanpur on 11th May 2015 -- IITs and IISc to develop Policy Roadmap for Ten Technology Domains. Big Challenge and Opportunities ahead. IITKGP Team was represented by Prof Sunando Dasgupta (Dean SRIC), Prof Anupam Basu (CSE & Chairman CET), Prof Suman Chakraborty (ME and Head SMST), Prof Goutam Saha (E&ECE and PIC IPR&IR) and myself. Under the initiative entitled "IMPacting Research, INnovation and Technology or IMPRINT for India", MHRD has given the IITs and IISc the responsibility to develop an Education and Research Policy Roadmap for Ten Technology Domains. IITKGP is Coordinating two critical thematic areas and participating in all areas. The TEN technology domains/themes and coordinating institutes for IMPRINT for India are: i.Health care: IIT Kharagpur  ii.Computer Science and ICT: IIT Kharagpur iii.Energy : IIT Bombay iv.Sustainable urban design :IIT Roorkee v.Nano-technology hardware: IIT Bombay vi.Water resources andRiver Systems: IIT Kanpur vii.Advanced materials: IIT Kanpur viii.Manufacturing IIT Madras ix.Defence: IIT Madras x.Environment Science and Climate Change: IISc, Bangalore Suggestions / Inputs etc are welcome. Photo (courtesy Prof Goutam Saha) shows three IIT Directors in the middle (KGP, Kanpur and Roorkee) and some other participants. Many others from avrious institutes who participated are not in the picture
