IITKGP remembers Kaviguru Rabindranath Tagore on his birth anniversary through its unique heritage art of Rangoli

Rabindra-Rachanabali Online -- IIT Kharagpur's Homage to Kaviguru Rabindranath Tagore on his Birth Anniversary. The entire set of literary works of Rabindranath Tagore (as compiled by Viswa Bharati in their Rabindra Rachanabali) has been digitized in a Unicode compliant manner, so that it is accessible, indexable and searchable on line. This stupendous work was achieved by the Society of Natural Language Technology Research (SNLTR), IIT KHARAGPUR, and IIEST (then BESU). Incidentally, SNLTR is also headed by Prof. Anupam Basu, Professor of CSE and currently Chairman and Head CET, of IIT Kharagpur. The site may be accessed at  http://www.rabindra-rachanabali.nltr.org

IITKGP sets up Advanced Multi-Photon Imaging facility for Neurophysiology and Brain Research The multiphoton imaging system at IIT Kharagpur from Bruker Fluorescence Microscopy Unit (earlier Prairie Technologies) is setup primarily for deep live animal neurophysiology experiments and can be adapted to perform fluorescence microscopy experiments in many fields like tissue engineering, physiology, developmental biology and others. In comparison to confocal microscopy, multiphoton imaging allows deeper imaging into biological tissue, and hence is extensively used for thicker tissue specimens, such as brain slices or tumor or lymph node explants, as well as in intravital imaging in small animal models. The Lead Researcher for this facility is Prof Sharba Bandyopadhyay. Some details are available in  http://informationprocessinglab.weebly.com/about-pi.html

National Digital Library Project Takes off May of you may have heard that IIT Kharagpur is leading the prestigious National Digital Library Project for India. This is a project driven by the MHRD and overseen by the PMO. It aims at a transformational platform to usher in Digital India by integrating all knowledge producing sources in the country and disseminating the information to enable all categories of students from the lowest level to the highest (is there a highest category student?) to use and contribute to it. All libraries, institutions and agencies of the Government have agreed to heartily participate in this new 'movement' as we call it. The support is overwhelming. The task is daunting. The team is working hard. On April 21, 2015, we quietly inaugurated the arena in the Central Library where this project will be carried out. We seek support, good wishes and blessings of all in this really ambitious and difficult project.

Distinguished Alumnus to return to teach and collaborate Prof Kalyanmoy Deb, http://www.egr.msu.edu/~kdeb/ , Herman E. & Ruth J. Koenig Endowed Chair in the Michigan State University Department of Electrical and Computing Engineering, and a Distinguished Alumnus of IITKGP has agreed to come once every year for the next few years to teach at IITKGP and participate in research collaborations.We plan to develop a unique research group in the area of optimization and computing with him as a key catalyst. Prof Deb is one of the most highly cited researchers in the area of evolutionary computing and optimization whose NSGA-II Algorithm is a household name for researchers in this area. He is an ASME Fellow and also a Bhatnagar Prize and Infosys Prize winner. I am proud to say that my classmate has agreed to commit himself to teaching and developing research programmes at his alma mater. He will be here when the next semester begins! Students, look out for the announcements for his course, talks and interactions

Ace mountaineer and KGPian Malli Mastan Babu passed away during his mission to climb the Andes mountain summit. Forty-year-old Babu, a native of Nellore in Andhra Pradesh, was in South America to climb the 21,748 feet-high Cerro Tres Cruces Sur. At the base camp on March 24 the weather deteriorated, he has been missing since then.   Babu was a top Indian mountaineer, having achieved the feat of becoming the "fastest seven summiteer" in the world (172 days in 2006, during which he climbed seven summits on seven days of the week in each calendar month).  He was the 1st South Asian to reach the summit/top of the highest peak in 9 countries out 12 of South America continent. He was the 1st Indian to trek & climb through all the passes between Mt. Sagarmatha (Everest) & Mt. Khangchendzonga.   Babu was an alumnus of IIT Kharagpur. He received M.Tech in 1998 in ECE Automation and Computer Vision. His life will serve as an inspiring story for the alumni and students of IIT Kharagpur. The Institute and the alumni community mourns the loss of this adventurous soul and pray for his family in this the bereavement.

Shifting of ERP support service from Department of ISE to renovated first floor of Integrated Information System (formerly RRSC)  ERP support services will move to its new location at 1st floor of  "Integrated Information System (or IIS)" building (formerly Regional Remote Sensing Centre of RRSC as it was called) which is opposite to the old building (where IIT KGP started its operation first) starting from 830 AM of 5th December 2014.  While all ERP services will continue to operate uninterruptedly at CIC the support service will not be available during the period 5th December 2014 to 7th December 2014.  The present phone numbers, viz., 81016 (ERP office), 81017, 81018 and 81019 (ERP help lines) will remain fully operational at the new location.  Users of the ERP system are requested to kindly bear with us so that the shifting of operations base can be done.  All effort shall be done to go on line as early as possible and users will be informed immediately thereafter.  ERP gratefully acknowledges support of the Department of ISE, all faculty, staff and successive Heads of the Department for having graciously hosted the ERP laboratory at the Department ever since ERP started operations in 2008 under supervision of Prof. R. N. Banerjee, former Professor of the Department.  ERP gratefully acknowledges the support of CCM, Civil Works, Electrical Maintenance, Water Works, Sanitary Section, Refrigeration and Air-conditioning, CIC and the networking group, Telecom Centre and various sections of the administration who worked to ensure that the first floor of former of dysfunctional RRSC building could be renovated at such a short time.  ACSSC will also move in once the ERP functions have stabilized and ERP working with ACSSC develops the required program modules for the accounts unit.  Renovation of ground floor of IIS for housing of a new Data Centre, Development server with test bed, the archival room along with the near Disaster Relief Centre to be housed at CIC is in the planning stage and will be implemented as fast as possible.  D Bhattacharya Chairman ERP and Head ACSSC Materials Science Centre

Hult Prize At IIT Kharagpur  IIT Kharagpur presents the first ever "Hult Prize at IIT Kharagpur" - a quarterfinal round of the Hult Prize 2015- one of the world's largest student social entrepreneurship competitions. Named as of the top 5 ideas changing the world by President Bill Clinton and Time Magazine, and referred to as the "Nobel Prize for students" by Noble Peace prize winner Prof. Muhammad Yusuf, the annual hult prize event is aims to identify the most compelling social business ideas and launch the next wave of social entrepreneurs.  The event to be held on November 8 in IIT Kharagpur will finalize IIT Kharagpur's direct entry into the Regional Finals to be held in March. Close to 45 teams are brainstorming solutions to the issue of Early Childhood education in urban slums. The event is seen as a huge accelerator to KGP's already growing entrepreneurial culture!  #hultprize

Nimble is a gesture control device, developed by a group of 3rd year kgpians, that fits comfortably on the wearer’s fingertips. This gesture control technology turns the 15 feet in front of any screen into a highly interactive control area, in which your fingers can be used to magically control a screen, presentation or game. Sub-millimeter accuracy paired with incredibly low latency makes Nimble the ideal gesture control system, and the hardware expansions allow for up to eight users, which is more than any competitor.   They have developed a great product, now all they need is your support to bring it into market. You can support them by contributing to the Indiegogo campaign through the following link: http://bit.ly/intugineIG  #IITKharagpur #Startups

IIT Kharagpur selected for Rubber Asia Award for outstanding achievement in the field of Rubber Technology Education in India.  The selection is based on the Institute's excellent track record over the years in imparting high quality of Rubber Technology education in India, creating generations of illustrious Rubber Technologists of our country. The excellent faculty and the well-equipped laboratories etc. were also taken into consideration for the Award.  The prestigious Award will be presented to IIT Kharagpur by a renowned dignitary at a grand and colorful function in connection with India Rubber Summit & Dinner 2014, organized by Rubber Asia at 7 p.m. on Saturday, September 20, 2014, at Hotel Crowne Plaza, Kochi.

Dear Kgpians,  This is the cause of a Cancer Patient which needs your attention. Soumyadeep Haldar is a 17 years old boy suffering from Blood Cancer (or Leukemia) and is currently being treated at Tata Memorial Hospital in Mumbai. He is nephew of Mr. Biswanath Dikshit who is a contractual staff in the Ranbir and Chitra Gupta School of Infrastructure Design & Management, IIT Kharagpur. Soumyadeep has been studying in 12th standard with Hijli High School. His full treatment will cost more than INR 12 lakhs and his family is having a tough time in raising the money.  We request you to kindly help in raising money for the unfortunate boy as he is also a part of extended IIT Kharagpur family and contribute in saving a life. It will be great to reach the students (across all levels, using the communication-platform of Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur), faculty, and non-faculty alike and raise money, as even a small amount will make a big difference to him. Please find enclosed a notice, in this regard, requesting donation, forwarded by Prof. (Dr.) Joy Sen, ex-President (TSG), and Head, RCGSIDM.  Donation can be made in cash or online. For online donations, follow this link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1--qNgDcFLf3AGS5eqj50a1i8gk4OS9qojZqIme1__jc/viewform?c=0&w=1&usp=mail_form_link.  For further details, please contact Sunny Bansal, Ph. D Student, IIT Kharagpur at e-mail: ar.sunnybansal@gmail.com, Ph. +919674704832.  Looking forward for your kind assistance.Please share this post with your Friends so as to spread the information.

कबीर दास द्वारा लिखी गई यह पंक्तियां जीवन में गुरु के महत्व को वर्णित करती हैं :  गुरु गोबिन्द दोउ खडे काके लागूँ पाँय बलिहारी गुरु आपने गोबिन्द दियो बताय  Teacher's Day is a Special celebration conducted by educational institutes to honor Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan and to encourage the contribution of teachers to the society.  Teachers Day is observed to mark the birth anniversary of Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan. Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan (1888-1975), former President of India, was one of the most erudite of Hindu scholars of all times. He was at once a philosopher, author, statesman and educationalist - and India celebrates his birthday - the 5th of September - as "Teacher's Day" every year.

Information related to B C Roy Technology Hospital communicated by Prof Chhanda Chakraborti, Prof-in-charge, B C Roy Technology Hospital  I am happy to announce that the website of B C Roy Technology Hospital is now launched.  The url is: http://www.bcrth.iitkgp.ernet.in/  The website is supposed to give an idea about the B C Roy Technology Hospital and the services and facilities that are available. In addition, the information about the timings, the organizational structure, contact details of the medical officers, etc can also be found on it.  A portal for feedback and suggestions will be added soon. I sincerely hope that this website will help to bridge information gap (if any) about BCRTH, and will convey about the continuous effort of the BCRTH team to provide curative, preventive and health promotion services to the campus community.  Suggestions for further improvement of the website may be sent to Prof-in-charge, B C Roy Technology Hospital

In memory of Late. Prof Somnath Sen Gupta, Space Technology Students' Society, IIT Kharagpur (spAts) has started 'Prof. Somnath Sengupta Memorial Lecture Series'.   Dr Somnath Sengupta was a professor in the Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur. He also served as the Dean, Undergraduate Studies (UG) and Continuing Education (CE).   The first lecture of this lecture series will held today at S.N.Bose Auditorium at 6 pm and it will be delivered by  Dr. Abhas Mitra, Theoretical Astrophysics Head of Bhabha Atomic Research Centre,Mumbai ( BARC) with a short introductory Speech by Prof Souvik Bhattacharyya, Deputy Director, IIT Kharagpur.

The Nehru Museum of Science and Technology is undergoing a renovation programme supported by the Ministry of Culture, Government of India under which a docu-feature film has been conceived and produced by the museum team on the history of the Hijli detention camp and its transformation towards IIT Kharagpur.   The title of the movie is “Hijli Detention Camp to IIT- An Untold Saga”. The film would be shown in the projection room of the museum for the visitors. The primary objective of the movie is to make people aware about the history of the land where IIT Kharagpur is situated, with special focus on the unknown facts of the Hijli Detention Camp building and the history of the cradle of the IITs. M/S AlterEgo Films of Mumbai has developed the film with the direction of Sri. Pinaki Sarkar. A majority of the cast members of the film are the staffs and students of IIT Kharagpur and comprises of shots from various locations of the IIT Kharagpur campus.    The premier show of the film will be shown on the Foundation Day (18th August) programme’ 2014 at the Netaji Auditorium Hall of IIT Kharagpur at 12.05 pm.   You all are invited.
The classes will remain suspended on 18th August, 2014 on the occasion of Institute Foundation Day. #hbdkgp

The Career Development Centre of  IIT Kharagpur is striving hard to increase the number of available internships through campus. Hence, CDC is reaching out to the students themselves to share their past records of internships, training experiences or any other industrial contacts. This will help the students in getting their internships acknowledged by CDC officially. As a result of an initiative of Food & Mess Monitoring Committee a new fine system for the eateries, situated inside the campus, has been introduced. If any eatery is found to be culprit of violating norms like Selling products above MRP , Selling expired products, Increase in rate without approval from CE&LC, Engagement of child labor , Non installation of water purifiers for drinking water or Multiple complaints registered on online portal by students then a fine of Rs 5,000 will be imposed on them. Non-payment of the fine will lead to an increased fine of Rs. 15,000 and a further reluctance will lead to the eviction of the eatery.  The student fraternity is encouraged to report any malpractice found in any eatery on the complaint portal at http://www.fmc-mmc.org/  Source: FMC/MMC IIT Kharagpur

The Sixtieth Annual Convocation of the Institute will be held on Saturday the 26th July 2014. All students graduating in the session 2013 – 2014 are eligible to be awarded the degrees at the Convocation either in person or in absentia.  For Award of Degree in Person:  1. Register in the Exhibition Hall (Ground Floor of Main Building) between 9.30 a,m and 12.30 p.m. on July 25, 2014 and produce the receipt of the amount paid.  2. Collect the Convocation Scarf from Exhibition Hall.  3. Attend a full-scale rehearsal of the Convocation on July 25, 2014 at 3.00 p.m.  4. Follow the guidelines (to be circulated to you on July 25, 2014) for the Convocation on 26th July, 2014.  5. Follow the dress code given below for both the rehearsal and the actual Convocation: a) For Boys: Light colour plain full-sleeve shirt (no printed design) dark colour plain trouser (no printed design) and shoes with socks b) For Girls: Light colour plain sari or light colour plain Salwar Kurta (no printed design) with scarf and ladies shoes.  6. Registration for participation, attendance in the rehearsal, and the dress code are mandatory, failing which no recipient will be permitted to attend the Convocation.  Use the #kgpconvo hashtag to share convocation messages, pics or your experience with us.

Kgpian Shrey Goyal has won the Project Firefly Current Affairs award by Credit Suisse for his paper "Mind the Development Continuum Gap: From Aid to Self-Help." He was selected via a double blind review process by a board of academic experts including Nobel laureate Prof.Eric Maskin, Prof.Barry Eichengreen (UC Berkeley) and Prof.Amitabh Mattoo, among others.  Shrey had been the recipient of the Akili Grand Prize at the World Conference On Youth 2014 in Colombo, Sri Lanka earlier this month, and was a contributor to the Post-2015 Development Agenda discussions. He also received the Center for International Private Enterprise Essay Award by the National Endowment for Democracy, Washington D.C. for his views on democracy and economic reform.   We wish Shrey all the best for his future endeavours.

KGPian Saugata Gupta appointed Marico MD & CEO  KGPain Saugata Gupta (89/BTech/CH), CEO, Marico has been appointed as Managing Director and CEO of Marico Ltd., a leading consumer products company in the beauty and wellness space. Saugata graduated from IIT Kharagpur in 1989 with a B.Tech. degree in Chemical Engineering.  Mr. Gupta will join the Board of Directors effective April 1, 2014. Saugata joined Marico Ltd in January 2004 as head of Marketing and was promoted as CEO of Marico's India business in 2007. Prior to joining Marico, Saugata was Chief of Marketing and Group Sales at ICICI Prudential Life Insurance. Saugata started his career with Cadbury's where he spent 9 years in various roles in Sales and Marketing. Saugata has 20 years of experience primarily in the FMCG sector.   Read more at:http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/companies/saugata-gupta-appointed-marico-md-ceo/article5829531.ece

Use #kgpsop for SOP box discussions.  The academic year is almost coming to an end, and it's time to elect the new representatives of the official Students' body - the Technology Students' Gymkhana. As you might be well aware, candidates contest for the posts of the Vice President, General Secretaries (Social & Cultural, Sports & Games, and Technology) and for the positions of Secretaries of the events in the respective general Championships.  For the Vice President and the General Secretaries, there is a special event called the Statement of Purpose (SOP), where candidates introduce themselves and initiate a healthy discussion on the proposals they plan to implement if they are elected. Needless to say, the SOP is a critical event in deciding the merit of the candidate's plan of action and his overall motivation for participating in the electoral process.  In order to know the candidate better, understand how it would impact your stay here if he is elected, and witness a critical scrutiny of the proposals for their feasibility, and thereby decide on how to use your precious vote, attending the SOP is a necessary (though not obligatory) exercise.  SOPs take place in the Basketball court near the Gymkhana.  Here's the schedule:  31st March (Monday) General Secretary, Sports & Games - 5 pm to 7 pm Vice President - 8 pm onwards  It is expected that every responsible voter in the campus would visit the SOP box and judiciously decide his electoral choice.
You all are invited!

A team from IIT Kharagpur, selected to represent India at the global level of the Hult Prize competition, came out third in its regional finals held at Sao Paulo on 8th March 2014. Hult, the world's largest student competition for social welfare, provided the platform where this group of young enthusiastic entrepreneurs presented their socially-responsible business idea of 'Sanitrashion' - which proposed the utilization of waste (trash) as the means towards assuring affordable and accessible health care in urban slums. Pitted against mighty opponents, this team came out with a podium finish, astounding all present with their innovative idea which was hailed as out-of-the-box by the jury and lauded as unexpected and awe-inspiring by many. Building on this success, these students plan to start their pilot in the Indian slums by this summer. IIT Kharagpur wishes the team good luck for their future endeavors.

My Imprint presents 'Graduating Class Gift' for Class of 2014!  Your Gift; You Decide !!

My Imprint Program is designed for all the final year students of the Institute to welcome them formally to Alumni Community of IIT-KGP & to make them aware about the facilities provided to them as being an alumnus/alumna of the Institute. This program is on the floor since last 3 years and also facilitates the final year students to give back to their Alma Mater by contributing their caution money.  Starting from this year, we have come up with a new feature that 50% of total caution money collected will be utilized in an area chosen by the final year students (out of 3 options given in My Imprint form as well as on ERP). The highest voted option will go to the My Imprint Class Gift Committee (student committee formed) and after consultation; one specific preference will be chosen which will be called as CLASS GIFT 2014 (named after the passing out batch of 2014). This will be a living memorial of their bond with the Institute and will mark their legacy.  Full Announcement:https://iitkgp.org/index.php/event/announcements/1111-my-imprint-program-presents-graduating-class-gift-2014

IIT Kharagpur develops food in a tube for malnourished kids  Dr. H.N Mishra, "100gm of this paste can provide 500-550 kilocalorie. The dosage will vary from child-to-child. Regular children can also have it but not as a proper meal. The next step is to broaden the scope of this product, which we'll take up after the pilot project of 100kg/day automated production unit is final by June." Latest update on Sahil Jalan's rescue :

Latest update on Sahil's Rescue: NDRF team has completed the search on two possible location till now. They did the recon on the third and will be continuing the search tomorrow too. They were hoping to find something till now, unfortunately we don't have any good news as of now. Due to efforts of Dean we have got air support from Indian AirForce too. They too did the proper recon of the area and couldn't find anything. We are thinking of putting the word out among the people residing near the end where the river enters Tamil Nadu to be sure. Please do share word in social networking sites too. We are collecting the contact numbers of all local and national dailies to ensure proper spread. If anyone has any contact, do share with us, Aayush Bhaskar, Piyush Jaiswal, Mudit Sharma, Mayank Baliyan or Vishesh Gupta. 9635149392, 8105338915, 9739906304, 9741178012, 9739662503, 09818498220 numbers respectively.  Thank You for all your support. Please feel free to contact.

Contraceptive developed by IIT-Kharagpur professor tackles baldness  It's a male contraceptive that can prevent baldness, regenerate hair and prevent prostrate cancer.  Trust Sujoy K. Guha, a professor at IIT-Kharagpur, and his team that has upgraded the RISUG contraceptive to this end. The drug, originally developed at IIT-Kharagpur by Guha, has moved a notch up by using a technology - a first in the world - that will generate a new nano drug inside the human body. It is with utmost sadness that we announce the death of Professor Somnath Sengupta.  Dr Somnath Sengupta , professor in the Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur, passed away on Saturday at Columbia Asia Hospital in Kolkata.   Dr Somnath Sengupta was a professor in the Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur. He also served as the Dean, Undergraduate Studies (UG) and Continuing Education (CE). He had authored a number of journal and conference papers of international repute. He had also contributed significantly to distant learning education through a number of video and web courses. He was a member of IEEE.  Rest in peace, Dr. Somnath Sengupta.

The Hult Prize  Foundation recently announced that IIT Kharagpur has advanced to the regional finals of the Fifth annual Hult Prize. The Hult Prize is the world’s largest student competition and start-up platform for social good. In partnership with President Bill Clinton and the Clinton Global Initiative, the innovative crowdsourcing platform identifies and launches disruptive and catalytic social ventures that aim to solve the planet’s most pressing challenges. Student teams compete in six cities around the world for a chance to secure US$ 1 million in start-up funding to launch a sustainable social venture.  Among all the IITs, the teams have been selected only from IIT Kharagpur.There are 4 teams that are selected from IIT Kharagpur and they are heading to participate in regional finals of San Francisco, Brazil, London and Dubai respectively.  To learn more, visit www.hultprize.org

IIT Kharagpur creates record among all IITs, over 1,000 students get jobs  IIT Kharagpur has set a record among all IITs with more than a thousand of its students securing cushy jobs in the first phase of campus placements, officials said on Wednesday.  Around 1,010 students of the Kharagpur campus accepted job offers in the first round of placements, which ended in December.  At IIT Mumbai, there were 900 offers while IIT Delhi got about 750 offers and IIT Kanpur had around 700 offers.  IIT officials said, Kharagpur has achieved a new record with the maximum number of students getting jobs in the IIT system in one phase.  Read the full article at: http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/iit-kharagpur-creates-record-among-all-iits-over-1-000-students-get-jobs/article1-1168376.aspx

IIT Kharagpur students develop mobile app that detects skin cancer, diseases    A mobile phone application which can assist clinicians perform fast and accurate diagnosis of skin cancers and ailments has been developed by a team of IIT Kharagpur students comprising Kausik Basak, Debdoot Sheet, Phani Krihna Karri of SMST and Tomaghna Ojha of SIT.The name of the team is SInCLAIR, IIT Kharagpur and the topic is "Skin lesion diagnosis with in-situ imaging and characterization through learning of multispectral signatures for augmentation of clinical Insight in effective rural healthcare delivery".    The application 'ClipOCam-Derma', which can be used on any smartphone, has been developed in the School of Medical Science and Technology at IIT Kharagpur, led by research scholar Debdoot Sheet.    Read the full article at:http://gadgets.ndtv.com/apps/news/iit-kharagpur-students-develop-mobile-app-that-detects-skin-cancer-diseases-461991

Workshop on Big Data Analysis by FICO    Today, businesses and the internet are entwined together like never before. The huge amount of complex data flowing in from this infinite source has led to the emergence of new technologies to handle it, slowly rendering the traditional database systems obsolete. Sample this- how exactly are Facebook, Google, Amazon or Walmart able to process your requests in a split second, along with many millions others?    The answer lies in a new technology developed by the tech giants.    Big data is a popular (and perhaps overused?) term used to describe the exponential growth in the complexity and availability of data. And more and more firms are becoming reliant on data; because more data leads to accurate analyses, which helps in better decision making, hence boosting operational efficiencies, risk and cost reductions and profits.     Come, take some time off your study sessions, and take a tour of the world of data, guided by FICO, an American multi-national company and a veteran in the data business.    Venue: B R Seth seminar hall, Dept. of Mathematics  Date : 16th Nov 2013  Time : 6 pm    Here goes a little something for reading through to the end! http://i.imgur.com/HGo9TcO.gif

On the occasion of Children’s Day, IIT Kharagpur students who are a part of Gopali Youth Welfare Society are organizing an interactive session and drawing competition for the students of Jagriti Vidya Mandir, an English-medium school for children from underprivileged families. During the interactive session, the young children of JVM shall be told about the significance of Children’s Day and about the life of Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru.    They have also conducted a mega drive and went door-to-door in all the Halls of Residence to collect old newspapers for the ‘PaperKraft’ project. The drive saw an overwhelming response and more than 500 Kilograms of newspaper was collected.    Gopali Youth Welfare Society is an NGO run by a team of students and professors of IIT Kharagpur, which works for the welfare of the people of Gopali village, located close to the institute campus. The society runs a number of projects for the welfare of the rural populace, including Jagriti Vidya Mandir, an English-medium school for children from underprivileged families and Paperkraft, an employment-generating scheme for rural women, under which they make paper bags from old newspapers collected from the IIT campus.    Recent paper collection drive:  http://goo.gl/jsofBh

Prof. MK Tiwari of the department of Industrial Engineering and Management has been found to be the "top contributor to the International Journal of Production Research". The journal is more than 50 years old in the domain of Production Research and is published by Taylor and Francis, UK. Recently on the eve of celebrating their Golden Jubilee, a survey article was published in this journal with title The origins of research and patterns of authorship in the International Journal of Production Research by Timothy D. Fry, Joan M. Donohue, Brooke A. Saladin & Guangzhi Shang. They found Prof Manoj Kumar Tiwari to be number one in top 100 hundred authors contributed in the last 50 years. Prof Tiwari attributes this honor to the hard work done by his students. Our hearty congratulations to professor MK Tiwari on his achievement.  Source: आवाज़ , IIT Kharagpur

Celebration of Diwali at IIT Kharagpur :  This is how our Alumnus, Devendra Purbiya, an IIT graduate-turned-full-time-photographer describes Illumination: Illu is artistic, big, grand and huge. It also burns lakhs of rupees in a few minutes! But that’s not what Illu should be known for. To an outsider not associated with IIT Kharagpur, Illu or Illumination is an enigma. “It must be their college fest – these IITians like to keep fancy names,” some say. But Illu is a celebration of Diwali on campus, and a very hatke celebration at that. It is an eye-opening journey, an experience that lets every IIT KGP-ian go back to campus every year. The aim of this book has been to cover the entire landscape of Illu, and the photographer has been able to paint the picture with as much attention to fine detail as to the panorama.  He has also written a book titled "Illuminati: The Engineering Of Illumination" and has also compiled this video.  For more Illumination photos, you can refer to: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Illumination-at-IIT-Kharagpur/152749858092645

Next Android version could be named by IIT Kharagpur Students!   Google's Android versions were traditionally named after sweets. After the announcement of the latest version as Kitkat, a group of students from IIT-Kharagpur have written an open letter to Google's Senior Vice President and Android in-charge Sundar Pichai( who is an IIT- KGP alumni and institute silver medal awardee), requesting him to name the next OS version as Lassi.       "Android has literally created a revolution in India. The introduction of something which coincides with the present Indian line of thought ensures an immediate conversion of the present Google app users and those unfortunate users who are not yet associated towards your upcoming launches. Your actions will certainly have a unique impact on the Indian market as is evident from the large proportion of the mobile economy that you dominate. Keeping this in mind, we, the students of the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur (sounds familiar?), would humbly like to propose an idea which may help your business empire in India and beyond become more and more profound. We would like to suggest that the very next version of Android be named on one of the most popular Indian dessert, “Lassi”. As you must be very well aware, Lassi, the humble Indian sweetened yogurt based drink, is a traditional chilled beverage of India served with an assortment of flavorings. Lassi symbolizes the purity and delicacy of Indian culture. This explains the huge cult following that lassi commands all over India. Lassi in its different forms encompasses the whole of Indian subcontinent which in a way reflects the versatility and extent of Indian culture.", says the letter by the student group.    Not only IIT KGP, another group of some 500 Indian tech start-ups too has launched a campaign to name the next version of Android as Ladoo. As Mr.Pichai is of Indian origin and the reasoning seems valid enough, soon there may be an Android Version named after an Indian delicacy.     Article: http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-09-11/software-services/41969487_1_android-os-sundar-pichai-lassi    #IITKgp

"SOCCER IS NO MORE BOUNDED TO THE HUMAN DOMAIN, ROBOTS HAVE CREPT INTO IT!"     Kharagpur RoboSoccer Students' Group (KRSSG) comprises of a bunch of ardent robotics technocrats from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur working together to build autonomous soccer-playing robots under the collective guidance of Prof. J. Mukhopadhyay and Prof. S. Sarkar from the department of Computer Science and Engineering, Prof. A. K. Deb of Electrical Engineering and Prof. D. K. Pratihar of Mechanical Engineering .The team marked its inception in August 2009 with participation in RoboCup at India Challenge which was held at IIT Kharagpur itself. This event was the first of its kind in South East Asia and with this India joined the elite body of only 18 nations worldwide to have a Robot Soccer league of their own. Since then there was no looking back. Lessons learnt, it was back to the drawing board. Therefore the team reorganized into a research project. There is an element of professionalism in all aspects of functioning of the group. For the sake of effective management of the group, it is divided into three sub-teams: Mechanical , Embedded Electronics and Coding teams, and each team in turn has a hierarchy. The Management team on the other side ensures the smooth functioning of the project.  The main objective of the group is to build and study co-operative multi-agent systems in highly adversarial environments. The group aims to participate mainly in 2 international events which are organized worldwide, RoboCup and FIRA. Apart from participating in international competitions the team also conducts Code-o-Soccer, an in-house strategy based coding event, as well as participates in several exhibitions. We also had the opportunity of participating in the FIRA RoboWorld Cup held in Bangalore in August 2010.We were the only Indian team to participate in the Mirosot League back then. Buoyed by the developments in this field, the team was all set to participate in FIRA 2013 at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.     Federation of International Robot-soccer Association or simply FIRA is the Robotic equivalent of the real world soccer association, FIFA. Every year it organizes a Robot Soccer World tournament with multiple leagues to participate in. It is the dream of every robotics enthusiast to be able to witness the glory that FIRA is. KRSSG, represented IIT Kharagpur at this International platform and glorified its participation. The team members feel proud to announce that IIT Kharagpur succeeded in defeating a team from Indonesia by 11-0 during a match in MiroSot. We were among the very few teams that had built their own robots from scratch. Most of the teams participating in the MiroSot league were end users of Industrially manufactured robots. Several Professors of International Institutions acknowledged our effort and commended our development. Our team is responsible for the Mechanical Design and Structural fabrication of the robot, Circuit prototyping and Embedded control, Image Processing as well as Soccer Strategy implementation via Artificial Intelligence and months of rigorous testing. Although we were not able to make it out of our pool and enter the knockout rounds, it was an excellent learning experience nonetheless. Fueled with energy ,motivation and determination, the group is now well on its path to improve the quality of robots and the strategy. The team is ready to expand its horizon with International participation not just in FIRA next year, but also in several other major Robot Soccer Leagues.    #iitkgp

I wouldn’t call it just an internship. Rather, I would prefer calling it a journey, a journey which taught me a lot of things. Though the work involved was not purely finance, the internship gave me a purview of the finance (banking) industry.  The selection process included two online tests (with questions based on Inductive/Numerical reasoning), two rounds of Case Study cum Group Discussion and a Personal interview session.  In the GD session, we were divided into groups of 6-7 and a case was provided which was to be studied in a stipulated time frame. After the initial study, we were supposed to discuss(30 minutes) about the case amongst us .Next, we were asked to present our discussion (5 minutes) post which we were asked questions from the panelists (10 minutes).The procedure was reiterated for the 2nd round of case study. The two topics involved were-a case related to System integration & Synchronization of a merged financial corporation with those of Barclays’s systems and a Mobile App Development – Security enhancement and related issues case.   After the two rounds, a shortlist for PI session was announced. The PI for me went on for around an hour and a half involving 2 rounds –HR and technical. The HR round involved some 25 questions like-Is success really essential in one’s life?, How will you proceed on the first day of your work with a company? Etc. The technical round tested if I was suitable for a hard core coding role or not.   After I was selected, I was allocated a team-Service Engagement Management (Corporate Banking) around March .The position offered to all internees from Kharagpur was Intern, Global Technology at Pune and the work was in the IT Services sector which did not involve coding essentially.   After I joined Barclays, I attended several orientation sessions related to finance, investment banking and Barclays. My team and my manager were very helping, supportive and co- operative. During my tenure with Barclays, I came to understand the financial/banking industry, the structure of banks, why technology is needed in banks, what are the future prospects in a bank (in the financial as well as technical profile). As I already stated, the internship was a journey and was not only about work. It involved several networking sessions where I got to meet Directors, MD’s from world over. Barclays also organized some soft skills sessions which helped me learn proper business communication ethics. The internship wasn’t all about work. It was about people, their experiences, travelling and parties!  To all the future applicants I would say, stay confident, speak well (both content and presentation wise) and the internship would all be yours!  As Balaji (my co-intern) says it – “Barclays is a place where you Work not so hard but Party really hard”.  Public Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur holds the rights regarding the use or distribution of this story.  #IITKgp #internshipstories

National Students' Space Challenge organized by spAts ( Space Technology Students' Society), IIT Kharagpur  Dates: 6th-8th September,2013 Venue: Vikramshilla, IIT Kharagpur  National Students’ Space Challenge (NSSC) has grown to be one of the prominent space-tech fest of the country. NSSC is a National level fest dedicated to the promotion of space technology in our country, held every year at IIT Kharagpur in association with the Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO). NSSC brings you a plethora of events to put a paddle to your mettle and compete against the best minds of the country.   NSSC ’13 is scheduled from 6th to 8th September this year and promises a prolific display of space engineering.  NSSC also brings to your doorsteps a series of workshops and guest lectures.   Workshops: 1.        Amateur Radio: 7th September, 2013 2.        Small Satellite Ballooning: 8th September, 2013 3.        Delta Wing Workshop: 7th and 8th September, 2013  Guest Lectures: 1.        Mr. Chander Bhushan Devgun: He is the first astronomer from India to have his astrophotograph displayed on APOD (Astronomy Picture of the Day). He is a passionate avid astronomer is armed with a degree in mechanical engineering, has 25 years of experience in observational astronomy, telescope making, and astrophotography. 2.        Dr. S Sudhakar: Director of the North Eastern Satellite Application Center (NESAC). He will deliver a talk on applications of satellites and space technology on a global scale. "One who wants to improve his coding skill as well as explore a financial sector, GS is the place to be" says Rickey Agarwal, Goldman Sachs Intern  The memories of the day when I was selected for internship with Goldman Sachs are still fresh as a daisy. Just like many other companies visiting our campus, routine events of CV submission followed by a PPT were scheduled for Goldman Sachs as well.  The seeking profile was for a technical analyst and the positions were open for students of all the departments. What followed after the PPT was a bi-sectional written test with aptitude and coding sections, each having a minimum cut off for qualification. The aptitude test was mostly based on basic maths of probability, pnc, speed and time, and had few CAT type LR question as well. The coding test was centred on C and C++; and focused mostly on finding the output of some code snippet and checking for errors. After an hour long test, shortlist for GD was announced. The students were divided into 2 different groups and the topic for discussion was “Is India ready to host Olympics”. After an intensive discussion of half an hour, guys who were able to manage their way out smartly and smoothly amidst commotion and aggression, made the cut to the stage of PI. There were 2 different interview panels, tech and a HR one. The tech interview was not just about testing coding skills, but a process to check the logical soundness and alertness of the interviewee. I was asked to write coding algorithms, prove mathematical theorems and had to face dicey Logical jugglery. Previous experience in coding could have an added advantage for this round. My HR interview was smoother. Complete CV was reviewed; previous internship and experiences were elaborated. The interview was a test for the soft skills, and the awareness one had about the firm. Some knowledge about GS helps to set a nice tune in the interview. One may expect to face couple of standard HR questions as well. After a long and an exhaustive procedure which went on till 4 am in the morning, all the anxiety and wait paid off with the knowledge of my selection dawning unto me.  I started my internship from 6th May. I initially used to ponder “This is neither core, nor tech – what am I doing in a Financial firm?” but trust me the place is brimming with technology. In the short span of 8 weeks spent at the firm, I had the opportunity of working with more than 14 new technologies, definitely an awesome place to be in.     The projects were all live and dynamic. I was involved in developing a new reconciliation platform for trade matching. The clear and direct reflection of making money from the technology was the most beneficial feature of working in a firm like Goldman Sachs. All the projects were real-time need based projects. The visibility of addition of value to the firm through my work made me appreciate it better. I worked with users abroad, went on conference calls with them to get feedback on my designs before actually pushing my code into production.   Every intern is assigned a manager and a ‘buddy’ similar to a mentor. Generally buddy remains a point of contact throughout the course of internship. GS takes lot of pride in its culture; and indeed their work culture is worth cherishing. Timings are flexible. Business learning session, coding session, contest, dinner, and lot many networking events were organized by the company. For someone who is a team worker, logically sound, fast learner, and wants to experience a corporate environment filled with fun and learning, wants to improve his coding skill and explore a financial sector, GS is the place to be.  Public Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur holds the rights regarding the use or distribution of this story.  #IITKgp #internshipstories

Professor Chhanda Chakraborti of the Dept of Humanities and Social Sciences, IIT Kharagpur was invited to XXIII World Congress of Philosophy, Athens, Greece which is organized in every five years by the International Federation of Philosophical Societies.She has shared her experience through this article.  "At the XXIII World Congress of Philosophy, Athens, Greece"  The world congresses of Philosophy are mega-events that are organized once in every five years in different parts of the world by the International Federation of Philosophical Societies. In 2013, under the auspices of Hellenic organizing committee constituted by the Greek philosophical society, the XXIII World Congress of Philosophy was held on August 4-10, in the city of Athens, a bustling city with an eminent tradition of art, beauty and philosophy.  Athens is a perfect location for a World Congress of Philosophy, because the city is considered as the cradle of western philosophy. Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, the three great and the most influential western philosophers, spent their lives as a philosopher in Athens. Socrates was born in Athens. Plato founded his Academy, a forerunner of institutes of higher education, in Athens in 386 BCE. Aristotle, Platos’s best student, joined Plato’s Academy in Athens in 367 BCE, and went on to found his own school, the Lyceum, in Athens in 355 BCE, after Aristotle’s celebrated pupil, Alexander, took the throne. .      The main theme of the XXIII World Congress of Philosophy was: Philosophy as inquiry and way of life. In consonance with the utterance of Socrates, that an unexamined life is not worth living, the theme was chosen to encourage Philosophy both as a theoretical investigation and as a practice in life. The aim of the congress was not only to act as a multi-cultural forum for philosophers from around the globe to meet and interact, but also to encourage deliberations on the role and responsibility of philosophy in addressing the contemporary problems, injustices, and conflicts, that plague the present world.  Being at the XXIII congress will be treasured as an exhilarating and a truly memorable experience. The venue was the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens campus, which is located in Zografous, in the eastern part of Athens. The Congress had over 3000 delegates from all over the world. Papers were selected by a distinguished panel of reviewers selected by the organizing committee. Each day the program was packed starting from 9AM in the morning to 7 or 8 in the evening. The mornings were kept for the plenary sessions, and the endowed lectures. The rest of the day was divided into numerous parallel technical sessions and symposia, which would be held concurrently in 1 hour and 50 minutes slots. Delegates were provided with the rare opportunity to listen to the presentations of some of the world’s most astute thinkers. During the lunch breaks and coffee breaks, the arena would buzz with the social interactions among the professional colleagues from all over the world. The day usually would end with a befitting closing event; for example, either some drama enacted, or a vibrant session at Plato’s Academy, or at Aristotle’s Lyceum. Through the days of the congress, the sunny sky and the azure sea of the Athens offered the perfect ambience for the profound and distinctive deliberations at the Congress.   The opening ceremony was held on the 4th August evening at the Odeum of Herodes Atticus, a historical stone amphitheater on the Acropolis Hill, against the magnificent backdrop of the illuminated Acropolis, the temple of Athena.  The occasion was graced by the presence of many dignitaries, including the Mayor of Athens. On the last night, a gala farewell dinner was hosted by the Congress for the delegates. Overall, the XXIII congress has been a milestone event. It reaffirmed the unique, shared dedication of philosophers to live and celebrate the life of the thinking person.  #IITKgp

Schlumberger has one of the most bizarre and interesting internship programs of all. It has a rigorous selection procedure.   Selection Process: 1.	Group Discussion: Just after the PPT (which you must attend), the list of shortlisted students was declared and selection procedure was in motion starting with GD. Completely abstract and vague topics were given such as Counter Strike, delta-zero, intentionally, so that someone has to take  the charge and shape the argument. It took place among groups of 7-8 students with a time frame of 10 minutes. The best way to nail such unconventional topics is to think out of the box or break into the literal meanings of the words and be creative. Be assertive, don’t be aggressive.   2.	Group Activity: The selected students were then divided into teams of 5 and were asked to make a movable car model out of metals, nuts and bolts, 2 groups at a time within 10 minutes. Prior to which, each individual was asked to make a point and endorse its model, and then remark and ask a question to the opponent team about their model. It’s not the model you make that counts, but the effort you make into building it, team spirit and the cohesiveness. Don’t quarrel or panic, appreciate others’ ideas and make valid remarks. Individuals were then selected for the PI and not the whole team.  3.	Personal Interview: Have a look into the company’s structure & organization, its policies and job profiles profoundly beforehand.The Interview was totally HR based. The company generally looks for a robust, industrious, confident student with a good presence of mind and will power. The interviewers will try to push you hard to subdue you like asking if you are ready to go to adverse areas like Iraq if recruited or if you can work for 46 long hours without sleep, but do not get depressed and show them that you are competent. Be prepared for any question to be asked from your CV. And you should effortlessly answer questions like, ‘Tell me about yourself’ and other generic questions.  Internship experience: I was assigned Coil Tubing in Kakinada (A.P.). SLB is all about extremes. My experience was a sinusoidal curve, reasonably gruelling or extremely fun. In field, I was not allowed do the main stream job much as an intern due to safety issues, but I got a lot to learn about the segment and other technical stuff. I, along with my co-interns did 3 projects which didn’t require much of my core engineering knowledge but basic engineering and physics; at the end, we had had a physical structure in the field out of the project work. SLB takes very good care of its interns. Food and accommodation were just awesome. Lunch time was TT time and dinner was pool time. More often than dinner in guest house, we used to go on treats from seniors, mentors. I met some really interesting people. Astoundingly, in our base, we had people from 7-8 different countries.  My mentors and manager were very supportive and really wanted us interns to learn and understand the SLB way of life. The internship was really an enriching experience for me.  I wish all the students appearing for SLB, all the very best. And if you are not sure if SLB is the place to be, summer internship is the best way to find out.   Public Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur holds the rights regarding the use or distribution of this story.  #internshipstories #IITKgp

The story behind Deutsche Bank Selection by Pranavi  Available Internship Profiles: Markets, Corporate Finance, Green Carbon                             Selection criteria: 1.	Written Test:  This test is to check the speed and problem solving capacity of the student. The test is usually tricky, based on reasoning and math and involves questions mostly from probability and statistics and permutations and combinations. Usually, at the end of the test, there are questions where you are supposed to give your views/solutions on a general topic (general issues).  2.	There was no Group Discussion, however there were 3 rounds of PI.  3.	First Round of PI : HR Round Questions are primarily based on ‘CV’ (Post Of Responsibilities).  This round is just aimed at getting a general opinion of the candidate, his/her interests, strengths, hobbies and questions on general situations including the motive behind interning at DB.   4.	Second Round of PI : Technical + HR Round Technical Part: In my case, I was asked to solve puzzles and coding questions. HR Part: Here focus is mainly on POR (Positions of Responsibility).   5.	Third Round of PI : Technical + HR Round  This is more like stress – testing i.e. how the performance of candidate under stress is I was asked 9-10 questions with very less time limit for each question .The questions were mainly  based on Probability and Statistics (Distributions – Properties) and also questions like ‘angle between minute hand and hour hand in a clock at so and so time’ were asked. After that I was asked few questions on my favorite subject.   HR Part was more to know about my failures and how I overcame those, the positives and negatives of me and where do I see myself in ‘DB’ based on the PPT given by them.  Tips for Applicants:  Be Confident on each and every point of ‘CV’. Give a glance on Probs and Stats – distributions.  Public Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur holds the rights regarding the use or distribution of this story.  #internshipstories #IITKgp

The first tweetchat on “Microsoft Internship Discussion” by Public Relations Cell turned out to be quite successful with active engagement from students across various departments.The next topic queued up is "Deutsche bank Internship Discussion". Please follow @IITkgp and #iitkgpchat on twitter to participate in the coming up tweetchats. We would welcome more involvement so that we can make this platform a place for our collective benefit.  In addition to the introduction of tweetchat, we are also in a process to share internship stories of former interns from various reputed organizations beginning with Microsoft Internship Experience. We humbly encourage all to make use of this opportunity to clear their internship related queries.  Present below is the first article of the series of Internship Stories by Shreeja Datta(intern at Microsoft-IDC, May-July 2013):  Microsoft hires interns for 2 roles- Software Development Engineer (SDE) and Software Development Engineer in Test (SDET).  Visual Studio, Bing, Windows, Azure are a few of the divisions which most of the interns are allotted to. I was a SDE in the Social Incubations division of the Bing team, and my work involved prototyping social interactive models on the Bing search page. Basically I had to make a lot of Web Applications in C#, and used a lot of APIs.  Internship Selection Criteria (as of 2012)  The Microsoft selection procedure is pretty straight forward. The company does not give much importance to what you have done in the past, provided you are confident of your coding skills. The entire selection procedure is based on your grasp on Data Structures and Algorithms. There is no HR round, nor any Group Discussion.    ROUND 1- Aptitude test • 15 questions. Logical reasoning, probability, permutation combination questions. Also some questions on basic knowledge of C. • Key is to solve questions fast.   ROUND 2-Written round • 3 problem statements, in 1.5 hours. • Proper code to be written for each (any language-C/C++/Java) • Emphasis given on algorithm, not syntax. • Very important to write comments or explain the logic behind the code in brief, along with the time/space complexity of the code. • If time does not permit, write the algorithm/approach for the problem.  ROUND 3, 4 - Personal Interviews • A problem statement is given by the interviewer. The most optimal solution is to be found, after discussing with the interviewer.  • Time and space complexity is to be analyzed. • These 2 rounds are more of discussions, than writing. • After the interviewer is satisfied with the solution, a code for the same is to be written (though emphasis is still on the algorithm and not the code). • Sometimes test cases are also to be mentioned.   ROUND 5 – Group round • A group of around 6 people are called in. • Everyone is given the same problem statement. • Without any discussion with either the interviewer or the other students, a code for the problem statement, along with test cases, is to be written within 20 minutes. • The code is then to be explained to the interviewer in 2 minutes. • Discussion is minimal in this round.  Once you clear the selection procedure, a whole exciting environment awaits you. The Hyderabad campus of Microsoft is pretty huge, and has a basketball court, volleyball court, tennis court, football ground within the campus along with pool, foosball and TT tables on all floors. The food was actually great, and one can simply not get bored of it. Despite the huge campus and awesome outings, the people in Microsoft were the biggest reason my internship was so much fun. A mentor and manager were assigned to me. Work timings were very flexible, however a very elaborate orientation along with mid-term and end-term reviews made sure that interns took their work seriously. The internship program in Microsoft was designed very thoroughly to balance work and fun. Lots of parties, team outings, hack days (with unlimited pizza) and movies made sure we had a lot of entertainment.  I learned a lot, and these two months allayed my fear about work life being boring. Overall, my internship in Microsoft turned out to be a very refreshing experience.  Public Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur holds the rights regarding the use or distribution of this story.  #internshipstories #IITKgp

The motto of IIT Kharagpur is "Yoga Karmashu Kaushalam" . The motto literally translates to "Excellence in action is Yoga" essentially implying that doing your work well is (true) yoga. It is sourced to Sri Krishna's discourse to Arjuna in Bhagavad Gita. This quote in its larger context of Gita urges man to acquire equanimity because such a soul endowed with the mind of equanimity allows him to shed the effects of his good and evil deeds in this world itself. Equanimity is the source of perfection in Karmic endeavors while leading to Salvation.  #IITKgp #FoundationDay #18August

With the Institute Foundation Day on 18th August 2013,its time to re-visit the journey of Indian Institute of Technology,Kharagpur. IIT Kharagpur started its journey in the old Hijli Detention Camp where some of our great freedom fighters toiled and sacrificed their lives for the independence of our country. The history of IIT Kharagpur is thus intimately linked with the history of the Hijli Detention Camp. This is possibly one of the very few Institutions all over the world which started life in a prison house. There were 224 freshers and 42 teachers in August 1951 when the first session started.The Institute started its academic programme with only ten Departments. On March, 1952, Pandit Nehru laid the foundation stone of the New Building.   #IITKgp #FoundationDay #18August

Dr. Pothula Srinivasa Brahmanand of IIT Kharagpur into Guinness World Records.  Agricultural scientist, Dr. Pothula Srinivasa Brahmanand has been entered into Guinness World Records in the category of Longest Speech Marathon. He received certificate from Guinness World Records, London last fortnight declaring the longest speech marathon in the world is 33 hour 46 minutes achieved by him based on his extempore speech delivered during 8-9 Sep, 2012 at KIIT University, Bhubaneshwar on theme "Science and Technology, Society and Human Development". He has broken the earlier record of 30 hour and 6 minutes. Heartiest Congratulations to Dr Pothula!  For more details, please visit: http://goo.gl/wun77

Seven leading Indian Institutes of Technology, Infosys, Tata Consultancy Services, Cognizant Technology Solutions and industry lobby NASSCOM are coming together to launch a bunch of free, online courses that could potentially help 100,000-150,000 people a year get high-quality education and make them job-ready.   Till now, IITs have been offering open courseware on the National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning (NPTEL: http://nptel.iitm.ac.in/), in the next phase of NPTEL, all these seven IITs and industry have joined hands to offer courses on the web-based MOOCs (Massive Open Online Courses) platform, which will also offer certification.

Collegepedia.in is a social initiative by a group of students from IIT Kharagpur with an aim of  making a lasting change in the Indian education system. To kick start their mission of free education, they started uploading videos on youtube for JEE aspirants who can’t afford high coaching fees for preparation. Till now, this organization has uploaded more than 800 videos and has got more than 700 thousand channel views with more than 3000 subscribers. The videos are made by the team of students themselves. The uploaded videos have got an overwhelming response from users in India and abroad and there have been a huge demand to upload more videos. At this juncture, the team has completed 20% of the syllabus and it needs your support to complete the JEE syllabus.   Alumni and others who can understand the need of such platform for students, please contribute through the link below so that the noble cause of free education can become a reality:  www.indiegogo.com/projects/collegepedia-in-making-free-video-lectures-for-needy-indian-students/x/3967516

Open Letter from an alumnus regarding Institute Director appointment, IIT Kharagpur [Hunger Strike and Protest March] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Dear KGPians, As you may be aware, Prof Partha Pratim Chakrabarti(PPC) had been selected by the MHRD Search committee and BoG, IIT Kharagpur as Director-Select for IIT Kharagpur on July 29th 2012. Almost a year has passed and he has not yet been appointed as the Director due to a long pending clearance from CVC. IIT Kharagur has been headless for over an year now since July 1st 2012! We have a unique opportunity to appoint Prof. P.P. Chakrabarti (PPC), a person of a rare caliber, to be IIT Kharagpur's Director. He is an exceptional scholar (President Gold Medallist, 1985, IIT Kharagpur), inspiring teacher (loved and respected by an entire generation of IIT Kharagpur students and researchers), outstanding researcher (one of the youngest winner’s of the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize, he has also published papers in internationally acclaimed journals, which are also widely cited), and an able administrator (Dean of Sponsored Research and Industrial Consultancy, IIT Kharagpur from 2004 to 2013.)   Today is a pivotal moment in IIT Kharagpur's history and its future as it embarks on Vision 20-20 - a bold initiative to be a top 20 institute in the world in the next 20 years. Such an inspiring vision requires an extraordinary person and a capable leader at its helm. PPC is just such a person and leader. He has the caliber to transform Nehru’s, BC Roy’s and our founding fathers' dream of building and sustaining an institution of global pre-eminence that is dedicated to the service to our nation into a reality.   His appointment is pending CVC clearance. For reasons unknown to us, CVC clearance is still pending despite IIT Kharagpur's Board of Governors (BOG) clearing PPC of any wrong doing once in March 2012 and again on March 23, 2013. Over the last few months as concerned alumni who want the best for the IIT instiution, we have filed hundreds of RTI’s to get to the bottom of the issue. We believe that IIT Kharagpur's Board of Governors was correct in clearing PPC of any wrong doing and is the competent governing body to make such an assessment. Please find the attached whitepaper which includes summary of the situation and the case and documents from the RTI’s etc. You may also read the document at the following link http://goo.gl/zQUjr  On July 29, 2013, it will be a year since PPC was issued the appointment letter! After July 29th, the matter is likely to get further complicated. In an unprecedented show of support for an important and urgent cause, IIT Kharagpur students, alumni and faculty members have started a PPC for Director movement.   This is a first of a kind movement that has brought Faculty-Alumni-Students together at any IIT for a shared cause. And, we believe that the media will have to play a very important role in having our voices heard and in getting PPC to assume the Director’s office by July 29th.  KGPians this is our chance to give back and make a difference forever in the direction of IIT KGP. The time is now! Please come out and support the movement: PPC for Director. The movement is being run by alumni, students, faculty and we are planning the following major protests in the next 2 weeks to make our point heard and have PPC appointed as director. There is a Hunger Strike by over 200 faculty (the official IIT Teachers Association) on the 17th July at IIT Kharagpur. Over 50 alumni and hundreds of students are also joining the protest in Kharagpur. Media is also being mobilized for the same. Please feel free to join us in Kharagpur on the 17th July. Also please connect us with your contacts in the media, or speak to the media directly. Please mail us with your details or details of your media contacts on ppcfordirector@gmail.com. We also have ready press kits which you can share with the media. The movement is planning protest marches across the country – Delhi, Bangalore, Kolkata on the 20th July. It is our time as alumni to join these marches and go forward. Please follow the links to register for the protest marches in your city. Delhi: 20th July, 7pm , India Gate http://goo.gl/yNFBf ; Bangalore:20th July, 10 AM, Freedom Park http://goo.gl/xFRHb ; Kolkata: 20thJuly, 10am Allen Park (Park Street) http://goo.gl/2uRTi if you would also like to volunteer in the organization of the silent marches and for the movement, please email us at ppcfordirector@gmail.com. Team KART-Formula SAE team of IIT-Kharagpur made some history for our institute this July at Formula Student conducted annually by Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE), UK. The formula style prototype race car which was completely designed and manufactured by the undergraduate student team, had cleared all the six scrutinizing inspections - Tech, Safety, Chassis, Noise, Brake and Tilt, as per the rules & norms governed by the Motor Sports Association (MSA) and Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE). The entire unit was overjoyed and filled with nostalgia when team's main driver cum team leader Mr. Ganesh Kumar Mukilan (Graduating 2013, Dual Degree, Mechanical Systems Design) drove the car at the endurance event on Silverstone racing circuit (Venue of the Santander British Grand Prix, Formula 1) .   The team also came forward with some impressive performances at the Business and Cost presentation events with standings of 43th and 46th in world ranking respectively. Overall position of the team was 67 out of 120 teams from 34 countries. The entire team heartily acknowledges continued support from SRIC Cell and encouragement from corporate sponsors namely, Skoda India, ONGC, Shah Coal Pvt. Ltd and Balmer Lawrie & Co. Ltd. without whom this feat would not have been possible. Crossing some major milestones this year, the team is in high spirits and is looking forward to improve significantly next year. Congratulations to the SAE Team!  #FSAE #IITKGP #IITKharagpur #Formula-Student #Silverstone

Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy was the second Chief Minister of West Bengal and the architect of post independent modern West Bengal. With the help of the other Indian educationalists, Dr. Roy formed Sarkar Committee in 1946 to consider the creation of higher technical institutions, along the lines of MIT, "for post-war industrial development of India." The Sarkar Committee recommended speedy establishment of major institutions in the four quarters of the country. On the grounds that West Bengal had the highest concentration of industries at the time, Dr. Roy persuaded Jawaharlal Nehru (India's first Prime Minister) to establish the first institute in West Bengal. The first Indian Institute of Technology was thus established in May 1950 in Esplanade East, Calcutta as the Eastern Higher Technical Institute (EHTI), later shifted in September 1950 to where it stands now at Hijli, Kharagpur as IIT Kharagpur. To honour Dr. Bidhan Chandra Roy, the area in front of the main building is named as Bidhan Chowk. Dr. Roy was born and passed away on the same day (July 1) at the age of 80. Today, we pay homage to this great man.

Subhojit Basu [2004/EE/RK] and Anant Choubey [2007/IM], alumni of IIT Kharagpur, are working on their start-up called ANTfarm in developing custom embedded system design based on swarm robotics. Subhojit’s interest in robotics goes back to his days in IIT Kharagpur, when he built the Robotics Club, now known as Technology Robotix Society. Their main product at present is Sumobot DIY robotic kit - which is a toy which can talk to the other toy in an authoritative way, or collaborate with other robots, move together to a location, find opponents, and attack the opponent. ANTfarm aims to bring down the cost to 10% of what is currently prevalent in the market and mostly be in the edutainment space.   For more details, please visit YourStory website: http://goo.gl/wM6Gz

Dr. Arun Chakraborty (PH/94/NH), Associate Professor of Center Oceans, Rivers, Atmosphere and Land Sciences (CORAL) has become first Vision 20-20 Annual Donor, under the aegis of Institutional Development (ID) Program of IIT Kharagpur  Employee Annual Giving is common with many corporations across the globe. It is also catching up with universities worldwide. Now the trend has been set by a faculty at IIT Kharagpur who has come forward to donate to the Institute annually through employee giving. Dr. Chakraborty has pledged to donate monthly, through payroll deduction, till his retirement. Our accounts section has installed this seamless process for donor convenience. His novel initiative has opened an entirely unexplored avenue of employee giving at IIT Kharagpur. Thank you Dr. Chakraborty.

A 45-acre plot has been earmarked for what promises to be a modern green building with minimal energy consumption at the south-east-end of the premises. Construction is slated to begin before Durga Puja.  The Centre and IIT-Kgp have chosen public sector enterprise HSCC for the project. HSCC provides professional consultancy services in the health care sector to both state-run and private hospitals. "It is in the process of finalising the architect who will prepare the building plan, according to specifications of our own civil constructions cell," said S K Som, director of the institute.

Mr. Soumen Kar, a PhD student(SRF) of Cryogenic Engineering Centre, IIT Kharagpur has been selected for IEEE student fellowship. He is the first Indian student to receive this IEEE award. IEEE(http://buff.ly/14OuKGV) is the world’s largest professional association dedicated to advancing technological innovation and excellence. The IEEE CSC fellowship is awarded annually to individuals for their contributions in the field of superconductivity based on novel and innovative concepts proposed by them, the authorship of a number of publications of major significance to the field of applied superconductivity and the presentation of a number of invited and plenary talks at major national and international conferences and meetings in applied superconductivity.  Hearty congratulations to Mr. Soumen Kar on his accomplishments and best wishes for the future.  #IITKharagpur  #IITKgp

IIT Kharagpur at FSAE 2013   Team KART-Formula SAE team of IIT-Kharagpur has been shortlisted for the Formula SAE-2013 and is all set to prove its mettle at the Silverstone track in UK. FSAE is an internationally organized educational motorsport competition in which universities from across the globe participate (www.formulastudent.com). The participating student teams not only have to make a performing, aesthetic, safe car but also analyze the aspects of production costs, fuel economy, recyclability and innovative use of electronics. At the previous editions of the event, TeamKART has been nominated twice for the Airbus Team Work Award, was among the top three rookie teams and among top ten cost-efficient teams. With its newly designed third car K-2, the team is all set to crank the performance up a notch this time.   2013 Formula Student competition is going to happen at Silverstone Circuit on from July 3-7, 2013, we wish the team all the best and hope that they will be successful in bringing laurels to the institute and to the country.

"Here in the place of that Hijli Detention Camp stands the fine monument of India, representing India's urges, India's future in the making. This picture seems to me symbolical of the changes that are coming to India." - Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, first Prime Minister of India, in the first convocation address of IIT Kharagpur in 1956. 'Chacha Nehru' has remained etched in memories of the children and students at IIT Kharagpur, that he has come across. We pay our homage to this great leader, statesman and politician on his 49th death anniversary.    Photograph: Pandit Nehru with the first graduating batch from IIT Kharagpur, at First Annual Convocation in the year 1956.

Let's stop child labour in our campus and neighbourhood.  Chotu CEO (Video Link: http://goo.gl/hC2fq), a simple but effective initiative by Freshjob.in in India to stop child labour in corporate offices/nearby canteens or shops by making the corporate people aware of it. Sir J C Bose Laboratory Complex, vicinity Vikramshila Complex, IIT Kharagpur. Empretec is the flagship capacity-building programme of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). Its aim is to promote innovative and internationally competitive, sustainable small and medium enterprises. Since its formation in 1988, Empretec has expanded to 34 countries, trained over 300,000 entrepreneurs and has helped to found or expand many businesses, creating thousands of jobs in the process, thereby contributing to the achievement of Millennium Development Goals. The program is being brought to India by International Business Facilitators www.ibf-group.ch.  At the heart of the programme is the Empretec Training Workshop (ETW). The ETW promotes a methodology of behavioural change that helps entrepreneurs put their ideas into action and grow. Therefore, Empretec is different from, but complements tool-room and specific skill-based programmes. The details about the workshops are given below:  i) Empretec India's 2013 calendar of events ii) Kolkata workshop announcement  If you are interested to participate or want to know more about the program contact Diti Mookherjee ditimo@gmail.com/ 9831153372

IIT Kharagpur grad Yogesh Ramadass (BTech/2004/EC/RP) nominated for Annual Creativity in Electronics (ACE) Awards 2013    KGPian Yogesh Ramadass (BTech/2004/EC/RP) is nominated by the Annual Creativity in Electronics (ACE) Awards 2013. He is the finalist under the category Innovator of the Year. He is nominated for designing energy-management ICs for energy harvesting and self-powered systems, pushing the boundaries of traditional power management systems down to the nano-power range. The energy-management IC allows electronic systems to be powered from ambient energy, without the need for batteries. This will create an eco-system for the emerging market and enable wider adoption of self-powered products. For more details, please visit our Alumni Portal: www.iitkgp.org. Winners will be announced on Tuesday, April 23rd, 6:30 pm - 8:30 pm at the Sainte Claire Hotel, San Jose during DESIGN West. All the best to Yogesh!     Reference: http://ubm-ace.com/finalists.php

If people can see your beauty, they can see your talent too.  An interesting parallel to this 'Dove Real Beauty Sketches Ad Campaign'...people who are unemployed, under-employed, or employed but unhappy often view themselves as less talented than they really are. Just as this video shows how women sell themselves short in the beauty department, the same can be said for millions of people out there looking for work and greater career satisfaction. They assume they are less talented, and it affects how they present themselves to employers. If people can see your beauty, they can see your talent too. But, none of it matters if you don't believe it. Start believing in yourself!

IIT Kharagpur will help the Garden Reach Shipbuilders and Engineers (GRSE) in Kolkata in designing the Navy's next generation stealth frigate. The over Rs 50,000 crore project, codenamed 'P-17A', envisages to build seven stealth frigates that will be more advanced than the three Shivalik Class ones (P-17) that the Navy commissioned in the last three years. The frigates under P-17A will also be capable of carrying the Brahmos cruise missiles. For more details, please visit: http://goo.gl/49qAX
