IIT Kharagpur alumnus, Arun Chillara fulfills his dream of making music.  KGPian Arun Chillara (BTech/96/CH/PH) describes his profile as 30 years of passion, 3 years of work and a dream comes alive. That’s the story of Arun, a graduate from IIT-KGP who revels in making music. It all started more than a decade ago with the title song Flying High composed in 1999, in a little village outside Vizag where Arun was working with an NGO. In the years that followed, amidst juggling career and family, various tunes came forth and other songs got composed. For more details, please visit: http://goo.gl/rjzf0

Applicants invited from 7th ASIAN SCIENCE CAMP - 2013 (TSUKUBA, JAPAN)  The Asian Science Camps aim at enlightening science talented youths through discussion and dialogue with top scholars in the world, and promoting international friendship and cooperation among the best young students of the next generation in Asia, Australia and Oceania. Every year the Department of Science & Technology (DST), Government of India is extending its support to 25-30 bright Indian students to participate in the ASC.  Its a week long programme, and all your expenses, including airfare are covered. In this regard applications are invited from students who are pursuing basic Science course in the 1st year of B.Sc / B.S. / Int. M.Sc. / M.S. program during the academic year 2012-13. Please download the application form from the given website link. Application Deadline: May 2, 2013.   Mrinal Mohit (www.facebook.com/wowitsmrinal), a second year student from the Department of Electrical Engineering (Instrumentation) have been to ASC 2012 at Jerusalem, Israel. Feel free to reach out to him for hearing his experience. All the best to the applicants.

IITians in tune.  Music has been the heart of KGPians right from the beginning with the commencement of Spring Festival in 1950s as an inter hall competition. Is it really to relieve academic pressure or is it something many of them love and are passionate about. IIT Kharagpur has diverse student societies in the field of dramatics, music, robotics, social, entrepreneurship, leadership etc. KGPians love to learn and explore their talents in different fields and gradually in 4-5 years of stay on campus they nurture them and transform themselves which makes them a great individuals cum engineers. Planning Commission conducts Hackathon for its 12th Plan at IIT Kharagpur  In a novel initiative the Planning Commission has reached out to the colleges and university students through an event called Hackathon to present the 12th Plan to public at large. The event activities involved many of young creative designers, coders, film-makers along with policy and development enthusiasts from IIT Kharagpur and other institutions like Jadavpur University visualized and narrated the 12th Plan through infographics, short films and support the initiatives proposed in the Plan by developing software applications. For more details, please visit our press release at India PRwire.

Prof. P.J Narayanan, graduate of the batch of 1984, boarder of RP Hall of Residence, from the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at IIT Kharagpur, is currently Dean - Research and Development of International Institute of Information Technology (IIIT-Hyderabad). Prof. Narayanan will take over as the Director of the IIIT, Hyderabad from July 24, 2013. Faculty Thought Leadership Series #2: Dr. Suman Chakraborty, Professor, Department of Mechanical Engineering, IIT Kharagpur (2002-Present)  Dr. Suman Chakraborty has been very influential and encouraging Professor at IIT Kharagpur. Dr. Chakraborty has been elected as a Fellow of the Indian National Academy of Science (FNASc), Fellow of the Indian National Academy of Engineering (FNAE), recipient of the Indo-US Research Fellowship, Scopus Young Scientist Award for high citation of his research in scientific/technical Journals, and Young Scientist/ Young Engineer Awards from various National Academies of Science and Engineering. He has also been an Alexander von Humboldt Fellow and a Visiting Professor at the Stanford University. He has 220+ International Journal publications.   The Institute Website Team, now called Public Relations Cell, met Dr. Chakraborty in August, 2012, to share his thoughts about 'Encouraging Undergraduate and Interdisciplinary Research work'. We hope his views will inspire the student and faculty communities.  Interviewers: Sarika Sivareena and Subhadeep Mondal.  Thanks to Technology Filmmaking & Photography Society for their support in video recording.

IWS#5:Mr. Shrey Goyal (Co-founder - AnaGenesis,Delegate at Global Social Business Summit & currently working with Yunus Social Business Fund Mumbai, Grameen Creative Lab. (April 6, 2013 - 06 PM - 06:45 PM IST)  Webinar Topic:' An Overview on Social Entrepreneurship.'  Shrey Goyal is a part of the Grameen Creative Lab team building the social business movement in India. Passionate about the social innovation space, he has worked across financial inclusion, energy, education, and social impact research, and has previously been engaged with iDiscoveri Education, the World Bank, Unitus, NCERT, Social Venture Exchange (Toronto), Villgro Innovations Foundation, and First Energy.  Shrey was invited to the "Young Challengers Meeting" to challenge political leaders from around the world, get together with CEOs from global corporations and meet Prof.Muhammad Yunus,Nobel Peace Prize Recipient  personally to discuss his vision for the future," followed by the Global Social Business Summit organised by the Yunus Centre and the Grameen Creative Lab in Vienna and his essay on "Work, Meet Life: Employees, Organizations, and Communities in the 21st Century" was adjudged to be among the top 3 globally at the Peter Drucker Challenge, winning him a round trip to attend the Global Peter Drucker Forum in November in Vienna.  Shrey is a graduate of the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) at Kharagpur. He initiated a rural clean energy project, Urja, which has been deemed an Ashoka's Youth Venture, and won the Youth Business Development Challenge at Oxford University. He also founded AnaGenesis, a Delhi and Boston-based social enterprise that provides research-based solutions and access to top University talent for social enterprises.  Shrey is a fellow of the Presidential Classroom program (Washington DC) and the Australia-India Youth Dialogue, and listed in Pinstorm's India's top 100 social media influencers. IWS#3: Mr. Arjun Malhotra, Ex-Chairman & Ex-CEO-Headstrong, and Co-Founder and Ex-Vice Chairman-HCL (April 3, 2013 - 06:30 PM - 07:15 PM IST)  Webinar Topic: 'Vision 20-20, How students can contribute to Vision 20-20 and Giving Back to the Institute.'  Mr. Malhotra graduated from IIT Kharagpur with B.Tech. (Hons.) in Electronics & Electrical Communication Engineering and received the Dr. B.C. Roy Gold Medal.  He co-founded the HCL group in 1975, taking it from a six-person “garage operation” to one of India’s largest Information Technology corporations. The first leading Indian entrepreneur to relocate to USA, Mr. Malhotra took over HCL’s US operation in 1989 and grew it to nearly $100 million annual revenues. A pioneer of the Indian IT industry, Mr. Malhotra founded TechSpan in 1998 with funding from Goldman Sachs and Walden International. The merger of TechSpan with Headstrong had built an end-to-end services organization. Mr. Malhotra is a Member of the Board of Governors, IIT (Kharagpur) Foundation, Member of the Board of Governors of the Indian School of Business, Hyderabad, Member of the Board of Governors of Rajiv Gandhi Indian Institute of Management, Shillong and IIM Udaipur. He founded the Prof. G.S. Sanyal School of Telecommunications at IIT Kharagpur through a personal endowment. In “recognition of his outstanding contribution and services to the Institute”, Mr. Malhotra was declared Life Fellow of IIT Kharagpur in February 2003 and has been awarded Doctor of Science (Honoris Causa) in September 2012. Dr. Haresh Lalvani, graduate from the batch of 1967 from the Department of Architecture and Regional Planning, IIT Kharagpur speaks at TEDxBrooklyn 2011  Dr. Haresh Lalvani's work lies at the intersection of Art and Science and is driven by a search to understand how nature designs its incredible creations using generative principles and formal codes combined with forming processes so we can design our own. Dr. Lalvani is mapping the morphological genome as the starting point for the genomic architecture. He is the inventor of ALGORHYTHMS and XURF product lines, both reminiscent of biological forms, developed in the ongoing collaboration with Milgo-Bufkin. His AlgoRhythm Columns are in the permanent design collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York. Dr. Haresh Lalvani is a tenured professor of Architecture at Pratt Institute where he is also the co-director of the Center for Experimental Structures. His work has been supported by NASA, NYSTAR, NEA, Graham Foundation, among others, and he received the Pioneers' Award from the Space Structures Research Center, University of Surrey, UK. He was an artist-in-residence at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, New York for a decade. He designed the award-winning Project X, a luxury apartment high-rise in Manhattan and recently completed a four-story residence in New Delhi. Prior to TEDx Brooklyn in 2011, Dr. Lalvani was a speaker at TED 2004, Monterey, California.   Read NYTimes Interview with Dr. Lalvanu about his famous SEED54 architecture: http://goo.gl/A2tBm and visit his design studio at www.lalvanistudio.com.

Institute Webinar Series of IIT Kharagpur    'Institute Webinar Series' is another initiative of Public Relations Cell, which is going to commence soon, to bridge the gap between the speakers and the students in terms of sharing of knowledge and experience in both ways. This webinar series will consist of a 30 minutes session on a particular topic followed by a 15 minutes Q&A, where the students can put forward his / her questions to the speaker on his session via the moderator. The speakers of this series will be very well renowned alumni of our institute in different sectors, eminent personalities from corporate, management, social and from start-up environments. The entire webinar will be streamed live, so that you can view it from anywhere on-campus. We hope that this series will help in the development of the students and faculties and active engagement of our alumni and stakeholders of our institute. Stay excited!

'Delhi Safari' won the Best Animation Film in 60th National Film Awards 2013    Mr. Aditya Nath Jha, graduate of 1987 batch from the Department of Chemical Engineering at IIT Kharagpur, is the executive producer of 'Delhi Safari' which won the Best Animation Film in the National Film Awards 2013. He is also the CEO of Krayon Pictures, a 3D animation studio that focuses on making original movies for the global audience. 'Delhi Safari' has won the Best Feature Film award at FICCI Frames 2012 and was also chosen as an 'Official Selection' at Annecy Film Festival 2012.     Mr. Jha started his career in the creative department of an ad agency and went on to work at Lintas, Rediffusion, Ambience and Ogilvy. He won over 50 awards for his work in print, radio, and television. Later, Mr. Jha was the global head of Corporate Marketing at Infosys. He was responsible for the global brand management of Infosys, its world-wide PR, its global online marketing and managing Infosys' presence at leading international events like WEF, Oracle Open World etc. He left Infosys after working for 7 years in 2011 to pursue his dreams of animation and creative development and started Krayon Pictures. Another person for KGPians to be proud about!

From Rags to Riches - Webinar by Vicky Roy, conducted by Student Welfare Group (SWG) IIT Kharagpur    Vicky Roy was born in abject poverty in rural India. He arrived in Delhi aged 11 and lived and worked on the railway platform. He later went through a rehabilitation program through the Salaam Baalak Trust and studied photography both formally and informally.  IN 2007, he held his first solo show in India and in 2009, was chosen for a mentorship program by the US based Maybach Foundation, wherein he photodocumented the reconstruction of the World Trade Center in New York, for six months. His works from the “WTC: Now” Series were exhibited at the WTC in New York and at the American Center in New Delhi. His works have been a part of important international shows, including exhibitions at the Whitechapel Gallery, London and the Fotomuseum, Switzerland. He has received many awards and accolades including the Time Out Magazine recognizing him among 25 achievers Under 30 in 2009.    Vicky is indeed a true example of rags turned riches & a clear demonstration of the fact that with enough passion & endevour, nothing is impossible. Join us today at 6:00 pm Vikramshila V3, where Vicky will be sharing his journey. You can view his photography works at: www.vickyroyphotography.com. Join the event page at http://on.fb.me/YnXjoJ.

Chittagong won three awards at the 60th National Film Awards 2013.    Bedabrata Pain is graduate of 1986 batch from the Department of Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering at IIT Kharagpur. He went to Columbia University, New York and received his M.S and Ph.D in Applied Physics in 1992 and joined NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology. Bedabrata Pain had worked for NASA for 15 years as senior research scientist before quitting NASA in December 2008 and following his dreams of becoming a movie director. Bedabrata directed critically acclaimed film Chittagong starring Manoj Bajpai, Vega Tamotia, Nawazuddin Siddiqui, Barry John and Dibyendu Bhattacharya. He shot the film Chittagong with the same digital imaging technology that he with other NASA scientists had invented.    After years of excellence in the field of academics with over 87 invention patents to his name, we are now proud to say that he has conquered the world of movie direction with Chittagong winning the Golden Lotus for the 60th National Award as the best first film of a director - Dr Bedabrata Pain.  The song "Bolo na" fetches the best lyricist award to Prasoon Joshi and the best playback singer to Shankar Mahadevan.    Earlier, on March 3 2013, Chittagong won the Audience Choice Award at the 19th Sedona International Film Festival, Sedona, USA. Before that on Dec 13 2012, Chittagong won both the audience choice award and the Critics' award (Piaggio Foundation Award) at 12th River to River Florence Film Festival and on Feb 7 2013, Chittagong "Bolo Na" won the music award for the best raag-based song of 2012.

Faculty Thought Leadership Series of IIT Kharagpur    Thought Leader is terminology for a person who is recognized for having progressive and innovative ideas. Typically thought leaders have proven themselves in the business, academic or political sphere through successful implementation of their ideas. Through effective communication and clarity of purpose, they effect change and are considered exemplary leaders.    Some of our faculties have been the Changemakers of our institute through their leadership in the fields of management, research and collaboration. The Institute Website Team, now Public Relations Cell, had commenced this interview series with an aim to inspire the students and faculties by sharing the thoughts from the desk of Changemakers!

Webinar by NASA Senior Scientist conducted by spAts | March 15, 2013  Dr. Joseph A Nuth is Senior Scientist for Primitive Bodies at National Aeronautics and Space Administration - NASA, Goddard Space Flight Center. Dr. Joseph is going to deliver a talk on the topic "Laboratory Astrophysics is Not an Oxymoron" on Friday, March 15, 2013 from 6:00 pm - 7:30 pm at Vikramshilla V2.   Talking about laboratory physics, there is no need to duplicate the exact conditions found in an astrophysical environment in order to perform experiments that yield interesting and very pertinent results. Laboratory astrophysics supplies the basic data required to model processes in astrophysical settings and occasionally reveals surprising behavior in physical systems that require more sophisticated explanations than initially expected. Dr. Joseph will discuss in detail about this on Friday. Be there to be a part of this exciting session!

IIT Kharagpur wishes Happy International Women's Day.    International Women's Day (IWD), is marked on March 8 every year. In different regions the focus of the celebrations ranges from general celebration of respect, appreciation and love towards women to a celebration for women's economic, political and social achievements. The UN theme for International Women's Day 2013 is "A promise is a promise: Time for action to end violence against women," while International Women's Day 2013 has declared the year's theme as The Gender Agenda: Gaining Momentum.    IIT Kharagpur has a total of 1557 female students with Masters New Students Intake (Women) - 255, Doctors New Students Intake (Women) - 141 and Undergraduate New Students Intake (Women) - 163.

A group of seven research scholars and one professor from IIT Kharagpur participated in the KIZUNA Bond project between February 4-12, 2013. This project, conducted by JICE (Japan International Cooperation Center), aimed at showing the efforts underway at disaster-affected areas which are vigorously making recovery initiatives in the wake of the Great East Japan Earthquake that occurred on March 11, 2011, and to promote understanding on reconstruction in Japan. This was the third batch from India and included 63 students and 6 supervisors from nine IITs. The group with coordinators in traditional Japanese Kimono dress at Hotel Kanyo, Minamisanriku, Japan.

KGPians securing third in the National Finals of the 6th Henkel Innovation Challenge.   Sourav Shaw and Keshav Pratap Singh of IIT Kharagpur came 3rd at the national finals of the 6th Henkel Innovation Challenge held at Mumbai on February 8, 2013. 10 teams were shortlisted for the finals out of over 800 registrations. This business challenge was to present an idea for a product that could be developed in 2050. The duo presented their idea of waterless bath with their product named 'Fa Aquadry'. Sourav is a final year student from Department of Electrical Engineering and Keshav is a 4th year student with B.Tech in Biotechnology and M.Tech in Financial Engineering.

IIT Kharagpur Team 'Changemakers' Advances to Regional Finals of 4th Annual Hult Prize in response to President Bill Clinton’s Food Poverty Challenge.    Team Changemakers include Anuraag Gutgutia, Abhishek Jha, Gaurav Dahake, Siddharth Verma and Rohit Shah. The Hult Prize is the world’s largest student competition and crowdsourcing platform for social good, recently named one of the top five ideas changing the world by President Bill Clinton and TIME Magazine. Each team selected was chosen from more than 10,000 applications received, totaling over 350 colleges and universities, representing over 150 countries. The Hult Prize regional competitions will take place on March 1 and 2, 2013 on Hult International Business School’s five campuses in Boston, San Francisco, London, Dubai and Shanghai. The team from IIT Kharagpur will compete in San Francisco. All the best to the IIT Kharagpur Team! For more details regarding Hult Prize, please visit: www.hultprize.org

Bitwise 2013 - Computer Science Department, IIT Kharagpur  Bitwise is the annual online programming contest hosted by the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Kharagpur. A challenge for the world's best programmers to solve a set of tough algorithm-intensive problems in 12 hours, and notorious for its last-minute winning entries. Bitwise 2013 is scheduled to be held from 1600 hrs IST, 10 February, 2013. This year's competition is sponsored by Google, Inc., with prize money worth over USD 4,000. Alumni Mentorship Programme of Alumni Cell, IIT Kharagpur.  Students’ Alumni Cell takes immense pride to inform you that we have successfully commenced a new phase of the Student- Alumni Mentorship program. After benefiting over 400 students, we take this intrepid step to contact maximum possible number of alumni and hope that the programme could transcend everyone’s expectations. Initiating the voyage of life as a wide-eyed boy peddling through his dreams of serving the nation, you have come a long way since. spAts is organizing a webinar by Dr. John Mather, a Nobel Prize laureate in Physics on 17th January, 2013 from 7:30 pm at SN Bose Auditorium on the “History of the Universe from the Beginning to End”.   John Cromwell Mather is an American astrophysicist, cosmologist and Nobel Prize laureate in Physics for his work on the Cosmic Background Explorer Satellite (COBE) with George Smoot. In 2007, Mather was listed among Time magazine's 100 Most Influential People in The World. Mather is also a senior astrophysicist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland and adjunct professor of physics at the University of Maryland, College Park.

Mayank Tibrewala (B.Tech, Aerospace Enggineering / Azad / 2009) emerges as the top scorer from West Bengal with 99.98 percentile. Did You Know? Fact#1  The Ministry of Education issued a notification on November 11, 1950 and then _________________ was re-named as Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur. The new name became a benchmark for all such technical institutes that were set up later. The IITs project an all-India character as well as a unified brand. In fact, they constituted a system popularly called as the 'IIT System'.  What was re-named to Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur?

IITians struggle to live up to families’ fat pay package dreams  Students say reports of Rs 80 lakh pay packages not only put them under unnecessary stress because of expectations from family and society, but also present an unbalanced picture to aspiring IITians and their families. Parents expect a lot from their children, when the reality is that only a few students land up the job that pays between Rs 60-80 lakh.  The broad spectrum of opportunities, cross-cultural experience, and the overall development an institution like IIT provides to students in its 4 or 5 years of study to develop his / her potential can't be measured in terms of pay package. What are your views regarding this?   Reference: The Times of India, December 11, 2012 http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JTS8yMDEyLzEyLzExI0FyMDA2MDA%3D

Transform Urban India - National Student Challenge, 2012  An initiative by the Indian Institute for Human Settlements (IIHS) to elicit innovative ideas and solutions for urban issues from students across the country. The finals of the event took place at the IIHS Bangalore campus yesterday. The first prize was shared between teams Mool-a-Roop and Kumej both from Balwant Sheth School of Architecture, NMIMS University Mumbai. The runner-up was team Urbana from IIT Kharagpur, who had presented a solution on building a comprehensive waste collection cum recycling system with a modular scalable business model in Kolkata, but also applicable to any other urban setup. For more details, visit the link below.

2012 Placement Updates  Day 1 & 2 of placements at IIT Kharagpur this weekend ended on a high note for many. With 31 companies coming on the first two days, the number of offers made on the first day was 131, which  is the highest number so far. Big firms like Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Schlumberger, Deutsche Bank, IBM, Capital One, Rio Tinto, ITC were some of the firms that hired students on Day 1. On the second day too, big firms continued to pour in at the campus placement's office. Samsung, Flipkart, Times Internet, E-Bay, American Express were some of the firms that hired on Sunday. At the end of Day 2, 188 students have been placed.

Vision 20-20    Last Saturday, during its 58th Annual Convocation Ceremony and closure of IIT Kharagpur's Diamond Jubilee celebrations, a document was released to take the institution to higher level. If everything goes as per plans, IIT-KGP will be in the list of the top-20 educational institutions in the world by 2032. Work on this document started in 2011 when IIT, Kharagpur's Diamond Jubilee celebrations began. Pranab Mukherjee was then present as the country's finance minister. On Saturday, he released the document as President.    Honorable President strongly recommended "more collaborations, exchanges and cross-pollination of ideas with the best minds in India and abroad" and asked the IITs to take the lead in ensuring "continuous revitalisation of institutions through research, experimentation and innovation".

Born without vision, Pratish Dutta, 23, has completed his M.Sc. in Mathematics from IIT Kharagpur, and won the Jagdish Chandra Bose Memorial Gold Medal for his excellent academic performance. Pratish was awarded the degree and the medal at the convocation ceremony held at the institute a few days ago, presided over by President Pranab Mukherjee.  Suffering from retinoschisis — an eye disease characterised by the abnormal splitting of the retina's neuro-sensory layers resulting in a loss of vision — he does all his mathematical calculations mentally and then dictates them to a scribe during examinations.  Pratish now wants to complete his Ph.D. in Cryptology and Network Security from IIT-Kharagpur itself. All the best to him!

A large spread of the classroom content of the Indian Institutes of Technology shall soon be available at a click of the mouse, through the IIT open courseware.   The National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning (NPTEL) — an initiative by IITs and ministry of human resource development — is readying an offering of 1,200 courses by December.   NPTEL already has 9,600 videos of about an hour's duration each for around 250 courses. The subjects range from electronics, mechanical, aerospace to civil engineering. "The content is delivered by some 1,400 faculty members from across seven IITs and IISc. We have also discussion forums where students can ask questions to faculty members," says Mangala Sunder Krishnan, professor of chemistry, IIT-Madras and national coordinator for web courses, NPTEL project.

The government and the IIT Council have consistently maintained in public that experts at the Indian Statistical Institute had approved their plan to compare scores across different Boards. However, ISI Calcutta experts had actually cautioned the government *against* comparing class XII exam performances across India's 29 school boards for admissions to the Indian Institutes of Technology and other engineering schools – but their concerns were ignored. Other suggestions by the expert panel were similarly ignored as well… http://www.hindustantimes.com/HTNext/Education/IIT-admn-reforms-Panel-ignored-experts-concerns/Article1-882375.aspx

Following in the footsteps of IIT-K, the Senate body of IIT Delhi has rejected the new IIT entrance exam format in favour of its own examination for entrance to undergraduate engineering courses next year. Sources add that other Indian Institutes of Technology including Bombay and Kharagpur are also likely to follow suit and hold their own entrance exams. IIT Bombay Senate is expected to hold a meeting on this on July 6, sources add.

The IIT-Kharagpur Teachers’ Association has threatened to go on a hunger strike if the Centre does not roll back the common entrance test decision though the institute’s senate conveyed its support to the proposal earlier this month.  “The IIT-JEE is the best exam system in the world. It ensures the quality of our student intake,” Teachers’ Association General Secretary Proshanta Guha said.

The IIT Kharagpur administration allegedly created a false impression that its faculty supports a Union government proposal for a new joint entrance exam for the IITs that has triggered fierce internal turmoil inside the institutions.  Several IIT senate members have said the HRD Ministry is trying to impose the new exam pattern on the IITs with little debate, lack of consultations with faculty — through a process facilitated by IIT directors who have ignored faculty views.

Rejecting HRD minister Kapil Sibal's 'one-nation one-test' proposal, IIT-Kanpur decided to conduct its own entrance exam from next year. The decision, taken at a meeting of the institute's 210-member senate, has been termed as a very important development by IIT Delhi alumni president Somnath Bharti, who believes "other senates are likely to follow the suit".

Alumni members of the Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) are gearing up for a legal recourse on the changes to be introduced in the joint entrance examination with effect from 2013.  IIT Delhi alumni president Somnath Bharti told Business Standard, "We will have a meeting tomorrow at IIT Delhi campus to work out the modalities of which court to approach and decided on the petitioners."  The new format would increase dependence on coaching institutes and would be subject to the varying standards of Class XII boards, bringing down the standard of IITs. IITs have technical leadership and by doing this, Kapil Sibal would be jeopardising the vision Nehru had while creating IITs as a centre of excellence, he added
Moments from Pan-IIT: Arvind Kejriwal recollecting how IIT Kharagpur shaped him as a person

As the Institute turns celebrates its Diamond Jubilee, we are looking at establishing at least eight new departments and schools and a new complex housing several state-of-the-art laboratories. The new departments and schools as planned include: Energy Science and Engineering, Biosciences, Engineering Entrepreneurship, Environmental Engineering, Nano science and Technology, Engineering Design and Manufacturing, and Embedded Electronics Controls and Software.

Pradeep K. Khosla, B.Tech. (Hons) in Electrical Engg. from IIT Kharagpur (1980) and Dean of Engineering at Carnegie Mellon for nearly eight years, has now been selected to be the eighth Chancellor of UC San Diego. He has been the recipient of the prestigious Academic Excellence Award at the 2009 Pan IIT Conference, the distinguished alumnus award by IIT Kharagpur in 2006, and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. We wish him all the best!

The Indian Institutes of Technology are set to open their first overseas campus in Mauritius. This campus will be set up in collaboration with Mauritius University with support from the Indian as well as the Mauritius government, and shall be named International Institute of Technology.

IIT-Kharagpur is all set to setup a medical school and hospital. MHRD will table the amendment Bill to the IIT Act in the monsoon session. A medical degree in India needs the MCI certification. IIT-Kgp’s application was pending so far due to a tussle between MHRD and the MCI, now resolved: While IIT-KGP remains under the MHRD, the new curriculum and degree certification will be approved by the MCI.

Professor Partha Pratim Chakraborty, Dean of Sponsored Research & Industrial Consultancy (SRIC) Cell at IIT-Kgp, is now part of the 10-member advisory panel for overhaul of higher education in West Bengal.
Prof. R. Krishna Kumar, Department of Engineering Design, IIT Madras, in defence of the IITs…

Shiv Nadar, founder of software major HCL, appointed the chairman of the board of governors of the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur. "It is an honour to be entrusted the responsibility to further advance the global stature this great institution has built already," said Nadar.

Legendary investor Warren Buffett's annual letter to shareholders of his company Berkshire Hathaway, awaited with much excitement by the market, has had one constant over the years: his lavish praise for Ajit Jain, the IIT Kharagpur grad who heads Berkshire's reinsurance business and is tipped as the one to succeed Buffet.

When Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee announced a grant of Rs 200 crore to the Indian Institute of Technology-Kharagpur in his Budgetary speech, he facilitated more than just infrastructure upgrade at the institute. The Budget grant of Rs 200 crore will help the premier technology institute achieve its long standing ambition of opening a medical college.

Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee, while presenting the budget 2011 Monday, announced Rs.200 crore as one-time grant to IIT-Kharagpur. "It will help us in renovating various old buildings of the institute which need major renovation," said A.K. Majumdar, deputy director of IIT-Kharagpur.
RP Hall's Rangoli (2010) featured in Ripley's Believe It or Not! http://comics.com/ripleys_believe_it_or_not/2011-02-20/

Two elephants, including one that killed a villager, last evening ambled into the IIT Kharagpur campus, triggering panic and prompting the authorities to switch off lights.  Forest officials tracking the tuskers’ movements asked the IIT authorities to switch off all lights except those near the north gate through which the animals had entered.

via Indian Institutes of Technology: HT reports on Indian Football League (IFL) at IIT Bombay, based on the English Premier League, with managers bidding for players, and teams even named after famous European clubs such as Manchester United and Barcelona.

Many congratulations to Indian-American researcher Amit Goyal, named the '2010 Innovator of the Year' by leading technology publication R&D Magazine, touted as the 'Oscars of Innovation.'  An IIT Kharagpur alumnus, Goyal is a researcher at the US Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee and is widely regarded as an international leader in the field of high-temperature superconducting materials.

via Indian Institutes of Technology: Congratulations to IIT Madras alum Prof. Subra Suresh, former dean of engineering at MIT, nominated by President Obama as Director of the National Science Foundation, USA, the top science and technology research body in the world. Suresh was confirmed by the U.S. Senate on September 30, 2010, for a six-year term and sworn in October 18.

A panel inquiring into the death of Rohit Kumar, the third-year BTech student who died on March 22, 2009, having suffered brain injury after falling from a rickshaw, has blamed the institute hospital and pulled up Madhusudan Chakraborty, who is now the IIT Bhubaneswar director. The two-member committee has said that Rohit, when he was being driven to a Calcutta hospital in a non-critical-care ambulance, lost his life because of laxities in health care facilities on the campus.

via Indian Institutes of Technology:  Founded by Bhalchander Vishwanath ( Indian Institute of Technology Bombay '92, Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore '96), United Prosperity aims to combat poverty in a unique yet simple and powerful manner, and is looking for your support to win $250,000 at Chase For Giving - VOTE for United Prosperity. Please vote at the given link — It does not take more than 30 seconds. Your vote will make a difference to the lives of poor entrepreneurs across India.

via Indian Institutes of Technology: Nitin Nohria, an IIT alumnus, has been appointed as the 10th Dean of the Harvard Business School. Nohria received his Bachelor of Technology degree in Chemical Engineering in 1984 from IIT Bombay, which awarded him its distinguished alumnus medal in 2007.

Many congratulations to Maulik Kamdar, Sisir Koppaka, Ramkumar Ramachandra, Anurag Priyam, Sanket Agarwal, Amit Shanker and Naveen Kumar Molleti of IIT Kharagpur for being accepted for Google Summer of Code '10. Wishing you all the best for the program and for your future endeavors.

Two months after the Health Ministry snubbed the Indian Institutes of Technology’s plan to offer courses in medicine, the Union HRD Ministry is all set to amend the IIT Act to allow IITs to start medical schools. IIT Kharagpur had signed an MoU with University of California, San Diego, last year to help it set up a medical college. “Appreciating the fact that the modern trends in medical education and research in technology and medicine in all the developed and most of the developing countries are seen hand in hand, the government proposes to incorporate ‘medicine’ in the IIT Act. The programme will bring the two diverse, yet important disciplines of medicine and engineering together,” D Purandeshwari, MoS for HRD, said in the Lok Sabha on Wednesday.

Dr. Kenneth S. Sajwan, a professor at Savannah State University, has received an award from U.S. President Barack Obama for excellence in mentoring. Dr. Sajwan, nationally recognized as a leading scholar and researcher in the field of environmental science and having been featured in more than 100 publications, is an IIT Kharagpur alumnus. Congratulations!

The Dean of Student Affairs, Prof. Souvik Bhattacharyya has circulated a notice inviting students to participate in a survey on student life at IIT Kharagpur . Students may submit their evaluation at http://www.dak.iitkgp.ernet.in/survey. In case of a problem with the proxy use http://144.16.206.211/survey. Login using your roll no. as the user ID and your date of birth(in the ddmmyyyy format) as the password. Submit your feedback before 2PM on February 11th Thursday. The Dean claims that your feedback will go a long way in improving student life on campus.
